question: Do I need a dual bevel miter to use this effectively? I can understand it giving me the correct angles for one side of a corner, but what about the other?
answer: M. Rees, No, you don't need a dual bevel saw to use this tool, but one would give you more capability. The tool measures the corner and gives you the saw settings to cut each piece of molding so that each piece makes up one-half of the corner joint. Because one corner cut will be left handed and the other right handed, you have to change either the saw settings (left/right miter/bevel, but the same number of degrees) and/or the position the molding is held on the saw to make the correct cut. There are several websites that explain cutting and installing crown molding. www.altereagle.com/How_to_install.html www.extremehowto.com/xh/article.asp?article_id=60354 Some of the miter saw manufacturers have instructions on their site.

question: Can it be use on a two zone system?
answer: If you're asking whether one unit can independantly control two separate heating/cooling zones, the answer is no. For two zones, you'll need to purchase two thermostats. I've just completed a two zone installation in my home this weekend. Be aware that, unlike the Nest, these units do not communicate in any way with each other. Thus, for instance, when unit one is heating it will show both heat and fan active, but the other unit will show both as idle.

question: How do I get the max heat out of my wood stove
answer: Providing you have a good draft; 1) Well seasoned firewood is key. the only sure way to know for sure is to use a Firewood Moisture Meter to test the moisture content in firewood. If your fire isn't burning well and continually needs attention like poking the fire or opening the door to get the fire going then it's very likely that your firewood isn't seasoned well. 2) Try splitting the firewood into smaller pieces and loading the wood stove with more smaller pieces than a few large ones. 3) Certain firewood puts out more BTUs than others. In most areas there isn't much of a choice but when you do have a choice try to get the firewood that produces a higher BTU output. IE: Oak is better than pine. 4) If your chimney has a slow draft you may need to clean the chimney.

question: how to take apart the rose shell from the rose chassis
answer: To get the round cover off, you need to remove the lever and shaft assembly on one side of the latch. You will need a 2.5mm or 3/32 hex key to remove one of the levers/shaft piece. (these are supplied when you buy the set new) There is an hex screw on one lever/shaft assembly look for it on the right side of the shaft. Undo the screw and slide the lever and shaft assembly off. Carefully grip the round cover and turn it counter clockwise while pulling it toward you-it is a friction fit and should come off easily. A pair of rubber nitrile gloves can help you "get a grip" -do not use any metal tool like pliers or a screwdriver as the cover is light duty and easily damaged Once you remove the cover, you will see the 2 phillips screws that hold the latch together. There is no need to remove the other cover on the other side as the lever/shaft assembly on that side is fixed permanently anyways

question: can white coated racks be put in dishwasher
answer: I don't know since I have stainless steel racks. Our kitchen has no stainless steel in it, so I was a little concerned about stainless steel racks in the almond enameled sink. My concern was unfounded. First off, the racks sit at the bottom of the sink and are not noticeable at all unless you are standing at the sink. For what it's worth, the reason for getting racks in the first place is to avoid scratching the enamel sink. Buying racks with a coating of any kind seems only to perpetuate the scratching problem by protecting the sink but pretty much guaranteeing the racks will scratch over time. When you consider that your sink strainer is most likely stainless steel anyhow, stainless racks fit right in. Whichever rack you buy, I think you'll find it will be one of the smartest purchases you've ever made.

question: Can it be used over recently (4 yr old) alkyd stained redwood
answer: Hi Richard, All I can tell you about the product is what I said in my review. I would think it could be used on redwood. But I don't know for sure. Look on the can and if you can't find the answer then call the company or ask someone at Lowe's or Home Depot. Be sure to get their answer in writing for your benefit. I know you're not suppose to apply it to a new deck. You need to wait for the wood to dry out. The stain with the sand is sticking fairly well on our deck floor but the regular stain without the sand is horrible. I contacted the company 5/14/13 and the manager didn't get back to me. I have contacted again 5/17/13 and a different employee promised to handle it for me because he claimed the manager was out of the office after that first day 5/14/13 when I first contacted them and he was still out. I forwarded the same email to the second employee at Synta which contained pictures of my deck which the manager asked for. They called me on 5/21/13 saying they couldn't open the pictures in my email. I resent it from a different email on the 21st and I am still waiting to hear from them. I bought my stain mostly from Lowe's and a little from Home Depot. I talked to Lowe's and they are the one's that told me to contact the company and I was told by the Lowe's employee, that if the company doesn't do anything Lowe's would take care of it. I feel the company should be responsible, not the store that sold it. I was also told by the second employee I spoke to from Synta that the stain usually only lasts about 3 years. I asked him, "Then why do you warranty the stain for 10 years if it only lasts 3 years?" He didn't have an answer for me. I am starting to think I am getting the run around from Synta. My suggestion to you is to try a different product. But read lots of customer reviews on any product you choose. There were not many reviews on Restore when we bought it. There are tons of bad reviews now. I remember reading a review that someone wrote about the poor customer service from Synta and that nothing was being done for them. Another reason I think I'm getting the shaft from Synta.

question: Does this only read from left to right, or will it work on a left tilting table saw blade
answer: Short answer, it'll still work. It measures the difference between whatever surface you used as a reference and the surface you are measuring. So if you use the table saw deck as a reference surface, then stick the gauge to the blade, it doesn't matter which direction you tilt the blade it will still measure the angle of change from the deck reference. answer: You have to be creative. you will still want the magnets to line up so if you want the opening in the middle of the skinnier doorway, start there (adhere the top of the meshes making sure the magnets are meeting and the bottom of the mesh is barely touching the floor). then place the velcro on the edges of the door opening (door frame), then peel the backs off of those velcro strips on the door frame and stick the mesh to the sticky back. then trim any excess. if you're a seamstress, you can measure and put a hem on where you plan to put the velcro for the edges of the door frame. should be a relatively easy but detailed project. OORRR... if you don't want to trim the excess and there's enough wall to keep the mesh spread out, you can just attach the velcro to the edges of the mesh to where it lands on the wall.

question: What if I accidentally turn the handle below the lowest setting, like all the way down to the initial mark below 25 flb?
answer: Will still work but accuracy will be compromised as calibration was set at it's lowest setting to it's highest . question: I'm not sure what size to get. How does one choose the correct size?
answer: Grabbed the info below off the internet. What's My Size? To find out your glove size, measure (in inches) around your hand with a tape measure at the place indicated by the red line (just below the knuckles). You should use your dominant hand, the right if you are right-handed, and the left if you are left-handed. * NUMERIC SIZES: These are the same as your measurement in inches. Round up or down to the nearest size. * LETTER SIZES: Use the chart below to convert inches to letters. Round up or down to the nearest size. MEN'S SIZES size inch* cm* XS 7 18 S 7 1/2 - 8 20 M 8 1/2 - 9 23 L 9 1/2 - 10 25 XL 10 1/2 - 11 28 XXL 11 1/2 - 12 30 WOMEN'S SIZES size inch* cm* XS 6 15 S 6 1/2 16 1/2 M 7 18 M/L 7 1/2 19 L 8 20 XL 8 1/2 23 * HALF SIZES (if available): Round up to the nearest half size.

question: What is the steel
answer: I found this on the Internet. The Gerber website claims it is a 3-inch 7Cr17MoV steel blade. Another website describes 7Cr17MoV steel as the Chinese equivalent of the AISI 440A stainless steel. From the Customs Tactical website I found this description: "440A is one of the workhorses of the Sports and Tactical Knife industry. The majority of entry level knives use either 440A, 420HC or AUS-6 steel. 440 is a medium carbon, martensitic stainless steel that is very corrosion resistant and extremely tough that can be hardened to about RC58. While not considered a premium knife steel, 440A still has some very good properties for cutlery use. It takes a very fine edge and will easily pop the hairs off your arm if heat treated properly, and is more corrosion resistant and tougher than 440B or 440C. 440A is rarely used by custom knifemakers, and is usually only used by production knife companies. Some of the Knife companies using this steel include Kershaw, Gerber and Buck. http://www.faq.customtacticals.com/steels/stainless_440a.php I honestly cannot say I know much about this blade but I have used it. It seems to keep a sharp edge and I was happy with the knife. A good, not great, knife for the money. As stated above, this knife is not a custom knife but is a production knife. Of course this should be understood for the price it is being sold for.

question: There was some sediment in our water that we put into the Berkey. We have noticed a flow reduction. May filters be cleaned? 3 mo old. filter
answer: The filters micro-pores sometimes get clogged up with calcium deposits or other stuff. I take my filters off and scrub the outside with a white scotch-brite pad. Then I run a lot of water through the filters, priming them at least 60 seconds. Berkey recommends doing this if the flow rate slows. Not sure about sediment, but I would try cleaning the filters, as above and then see if it clears up. Good luck

question: where are danze faucets manufactured?
answer: Introduced to the U.S. in 2000, Danze is a name under which the Globe Union is growing a brand identity in the U.S. It is the most actively promoted of the many faucet, fixture and accessory brands owned by the gigantic Asian company controlled by the Ou-yang Ming family of Taichung, Taiwan. Globe Union is the dominant faucet manufacturer in Asia under its GOBO brand. Its faucets are made primarily in mainland Chinese factories by its subsidiary Shenzhen Globe Union Industrial Corp. of Shenzhen, China (with a small bow to Canada for some automatic faucets). Globe Union is a full line manufacturer. Its products range widely in quality, an effect of making products at every price point. Danze is positioned as Globe Union's upper tier faucet line. As a whole, the Danze line seems to be well made. The quality is very good for the price. Many of the faucets are very stylish, and while Globe Union in the past mostly copied existing European and American designs, the company has recently begun introducing its own styles and they are good, some are even excellent. Danze, unlike other Globe Union brands like Fusion, has been a marketing success, having grown to impressive proportions in a dozen years with hundreds of brick and mortar retailers and a strong internet presence. It has been so successful, in fact, that Globe Union appears to have made the decision to throw all of its marketing muscle behind Danze and phase out other, less successful brands. We can no longer find Ameristream faucets anywhere, although its showers are still available. Brands such as Water Ridge and Corrego are now for sale only by discounters: Water Ridge has become a Costco in-house brand, and Corrego is sold by Sam's Club. Other Globe Union faucet brands have been merged into the Danze line. The former Fusion Hardware Group, Inc. was disbanded by Globe Union in 2012 after selling its Door Hardware division to Schlage Locks along with the right to the Fusion brand name in 2010. The Fusion faucet collections, including Bella Villa, Colonial Crest, River Rock, Sonoma, South Beach, St. Charles, Samui, Lilly, and Bordeaux, have been taken over by Danze as of 2012. Many of these are starting to appear at deep discounts from internet retailers, suggesting they they are being phased out as existing supplies are exhausted. Globe Union seems to have conquered the parts and warranty issues that formerly plagued the company's products. Parts, warranty support and installation help are available from on-line sources and at 1-888-328-2383. Other than for general questions, you will need your brand name and model number to get any assistance. We have had reservations about the quality of Danze faucets in the past, but they are now largely gone. In the past we saw the occasional defect that suggested spotty quality control at the Chinese factories that make Danze, but we have not seen any lately. Our recent experience with the Danze line has been favorable. The product line contains a full range or faucets from economy to luxury, so it falls generally in the middle-high range of quality. American made faucets comparable to Danze include California Faucets, Delta, Elkay, and Moen

question: Is the epoxy waterproofing easy to peel back or cut off for soldering and/or snap connectors?
answer: Absolutely! I peeled mine back for soldering almost all of my connections. Do be forewarned, the 3M sticky adhesive that comes will all strips like this is rather useless in most applications. Yes, it will stick to a surface if gravity is holding it to that surface; otherwise you will need something else. I used this stuff in my car so the extreme temperatures caused the 3M strip to not only come apart from it's mounting surface, but from the LEDs themselves. I bought some double sided tape from the hardware store and cut it to appropriate lengths and widths and haven't had problems since. Also, it really doesn't matter what kind of tape you use, if the surface is contoured it won't adhere for more than a day. If the lights are hidden, you can use clips to hold it in place. Your only option might be glue. I've used a lot of this stuff and love helping others do the same. If you have any questions, feel free to ask. Ask here, or email me directly (amazon username @gmail.com)

question: I have a single throw wall switch for a chandelier with 2 positions, one position half power, one full power. Where can I find such a switch?
answer: I don't think it's possible to do what you want there...but keep in mind I'm no electrician. What I'm thinking you're describing is basically a light that has it's own control to half the power. The light switch simply sends the power to the unit or does not (when it's off). To the best of my knowledge, the only switch that could even come close to what you want is a dimmer type switch but as you may or may not know many "lighting appliances" warn that a dimmer switch cannot/should not be used with them. Even if it was ok, it would not instantly cut the power in half, you would have to approximate half if half was important to you, if it's simply dimming that would be nice to you...I would suggest checking the chandelier's installation instructions and see if they emphatically state that you cannot use a dimmer switch with it.

question: Is this real stainless steel or is it a faux finish that will flake away over time? How does its weight feel when you hold it?
answer: Hi Dave, Good question. It's Stainless steel. In fact, it's 304 stainless steel. Here is a quick read about 304 Stainless: Grade 304 is the standard "18/8" stainless; it is the most versatile and most widely used stainless steel, available in a wider range of products, forms and finishes than any other. It has excellent forming and welding characteristics. The balanced austenitic structure of Grade 304 enables it to be severely deep drawn without intermediate annealing, which has made this grade dominant in the manufacture of drawn stainless parts such as sinks, hollow-ware and saucepans. I hope that answers your question. Thanks! Michael Weir Kitchen-Classics

question: what is exactly included this unit? When I install it outside, do I need anything else?
answer: The unit comes with an indoor temperature control module, 10 ft of thermostat wire to connect to the temp control module, and a brass valve for the gas line. The unit does not come with hot/cold water valves or pressure relief valve. I purchased these separately as a kit (Webstone 44443WPR 3/4-Inch IPS Isolator EXP E2 Tankless Water Heater Service Valve Kit with Clean Brass Construction) from amazon for ~$100. One may also need to purchase a longer length of thermostat wire if the temperature control module will be placed further than 10 ft away from the unit. The unit was fairly easy to install if one has some basic electrical/plumbing knowledge. There is also a series of ~6 videos on youtube detailing installation of an outdoor rheem tankless hot water heater which I found helpful. I purchased this unit a couple months ago to place at my camp after my hot water heater died. This unit has worked perfectly and would definitely recommend this product

question: Will it work to hold lids from pots and pans if you side the lids behind the bar? I plan to install them on the inside of a cabinet door.
answer: It would depend on what kind of lids you have. Every set of pans is different. This would add a great deal of weight on your door and hinges. It will also take up the first 4 -5 inches of space inside your cabinet. You could purchase a vertical rack for stack your lids on their sides. I stack my lids upside down on my pans, stacking with the largest pan on the bottom and the smaller on the top. Type in "storing pan lids" on Google and click on the first link. I see your idea there, but there are also others. An 18" door would only hold two lids. A closet door could handle the weight for this idea. I personally wouldn't do this on a cabinet door. Hope this helps!

question: What is the difference between this one and the Geberit UP320 Dual-Flush Tank that is less expensive?
answer: The less expensive model 111.335.00.5 is for installation in 6 inch deep walls. Note the different design of the more expensive version that enables the 4 inch waste pipe to run "through" the middle or the unit instead of the less expensive model where the waste pipe runs "behind" the frame, taking up more space. In addition to the waste pipe position, the more expensive version features Geberit's UP 720, which again is not as deep as the UP 360. If you don't already have 2x6 walls then installing the cheaper deeper version will mean you have to steal 2 inches from the wall on which your WC will hang. This could be beneficial if one of the shower walls shares the same wall - you could create a deeper more useable tiled niche.

question: can I use this product on the epoxy floor in my garage.?
answer: Yes, but you will need to make sure the garage surface is free of any oil or any type of residue. It will also be an advantage to feather sand the floor to break the sheen of the current coating to give our sealer a "mechanical" bond or anchor to ensure adhesion. After cleaning the floor, you can rent a rotary (slow speed) floor sander with about 80-100 grit sand paper. Just make sure the sheen on the floor has no shine. Hope this help, EnduraCoat

question: Can you plug it into a regular outlet?
answer: Yes it is normal house circuit, but a regular 15amp circuit will not be good enough. You will have better luck with a 20amp, You can tell by checking your panel box to see if you have a 20amp breaker or fuse controlling the receptacle you plan to use. A 20 amp circuit will be connected to 12 gauge wire which is what you need to carry that much electricity. DO NOT just replace a 15amp breaker or fuse with a 20amp without making sure that that the wire is heavy enough to carry the 20amps.

question: What about 3x3 handmade ceramic tiles?
answer: I would say no. Anyway I would not recommend it. I tried it on 12"X 12" tiles and it didn't work well at all. The tiles would break not on the line I scored and sometimes were jagged. I would recommend a wet saw. There is nothing that cuts better than a wet saw. You can cut angles, notches, small pieces easily. The tile cutter score's the tile and than you have to try to snap the tile evenly the rest of the way. A wet saw cuts through the tile with a nice clean cut. I bought a Kobalt 7" wet saw at Lowe's for my floor tiles for 189.00. It went through the tiles like paper. You can buy a wet saw for under 90.00 that should do what you need. The cheaper saw should be plenty for what you need. If you plan on using the saw again sometime in the future than get one like mine. The higher the price usually means better. The cheaper wet saws that I mentioned got good reviews and should be more than adequate for your 3"X3" tiles. You can buy a tile sizer to compliment the saw for 42.00 or less. This holds the tile so you can cut pieces of tile between 6 inches wide all the way down to almost nothing. You can look and see how it works at Amazon. You don't have to worry about fingers. I've never used one but I'm sure they work well. Sizer makes one. I bought the Md professional tile cutter because I never used a wet saw before and was intimidated in buying an electric wet saw. It was very easy to use, not intimidating at all. If you plan on using a cheaper wet saw check the reviews and buy accordingly. The reviews on the cheaper wet saws they are cutting through 12" and 18" tiles. They are good for a 3" tile also. You are not saying what a handmade ceramic tile is. I do not know what your handmade tiles are, but I assume they are fairly strong and have the same consistency as a regular tile and won't crumble when you cut them. If they are the same consistency as a regular ceramic tile the wet saw will work. Are you worried about the 3" size or are you worried that handmade tiles might be delicate. If you can cut them with a grinder and they don't just crumble than you can cut them with a wet saw. You can cut mosaic, ceramic, porcelain, glass, etc. with a wet saw.

question: Will this mount to a werner 22-ft aluminum 300-lb telescoping type ia multi-position ladder

If you blow up the pictures on the Little Giant ladders it is compatible with, you will see aluminum block sockets on the ladder that this plugs into. I ordered one for a LG ladder that was not compatible and had trouble figuring out why since my ladder looked exactly like the compatible ladders. I'm sure it was a liability issue since providing brackets have required some drilling into the existing ladder. It is also possible there is more internal reinforcement in the ladder at that attachment point ... so you can blame the lawyers for LG not providing brackets. In my previous research I did come across one person that fabricated brackets ... but it sounded like he did some machining of some block aluminum to do that.

question: Does this come with all the mounting hardware? Do I need anything else to make this function as it is advertised, IE Batteries, wire, etc. ?
answer: I recommend you read my review. I managed to make this work but DO NOT EXPECT the solar to do anything at all. The panel it comes with is only 1/3 the power required to run the system. It is a 10W panel and you need 30W. They will happily sell you additional panels. The batteries are also worthless. The system has no way to charge them. You actually need to connect them to an external charger to do this. The solar won't charge them. They will also sell you a solar charging module. In the end I removed the solar and the batteries and have it wired to A/C power. Oh and another thing, I have replaced the main control board 3 times since I bought it. The customer service to make this happen as horrible. I am now out of warranty and if the system dies I will simply spend the money and replace it with a higher quality one. Now I am basing this on the kit I purchased 2 years ago. It would be nice if they have changed it but I would not count on it. I hope this helps.

question: How do you know what size to get for yourself? I need a sizing guide...

question: My kit came with no instructions. Should it have? I am somewhat familar with repair kits but want to be sure I am clear on how to use this one.
answer: No. There is no need for instructions since the procedure is obvious. You use the awl with the twisted shaft to enlarge the hole after you have removed the nail or other item that punctured your tire. Then take the lubricant that is provided and lubricate the hole using the awl. After the hole has been lubricated You thread a fiber plug into the needled shaft and insert it into the puncture until half of the material is in the tire then twist the shaft one quarter turn and withdraw the shaft and cut the protruding material even with the surface of the tire with a razor blade and the repair should be complete.

question: how to figure out when it's the time to replace?
answer: If memory serves me correctly the manufacturer suggests changing them at a six month interval. I would imagine that would be driven by two things, the capacity of the filter to do just that - filter, and I'm guessing here but perhaps the propensity of contaminants (e.g. mold) to grow on any surface that has become moist. Keep in mind that I am speculating on the second driver. So, if you have a typical family (which I'm sure is what the time frame is based on) I'd suggest changing the filter at Thanksgiving and July 4th, which are easily remembered dates and approximately six months apart. I happen to live by myself so I tend to change mine when I remember (I really should write it down, perhaps on the back of the mirror of the medicine cabinet) but let it go for longer than six months. I can say that I have never noticed a problem. I've had mine for at least four years. And yes I mean the filter head, not an individual filter cartridge. Hope that helps you Jenna.

question: Can the combs of a mandolin penetrate the weave of the glove to some extent or is the mesh tightly woven? Thanks
answer: The mesh is pretty tight. I think it would work well to protect your hands from the combs of a mandolin. When I try to poke the tip of a sharp knife straight through the weave only 1/8 inch pokes through. It could go through the glove and cut you but it wouldn't go very deep. And you would really have to work to get a knife or other sharp object at an angle that would cause it to go through the glove. Also the weave is a bit thicker, the links overlap slightly, when the glove is relaxed, giving you more protection. When the glove stretches over your hand as you are using it, it opens up to a single link but this stops most sharps just fine. Hope this helps!

question: Are the four boxes Plano 2-3750 or at least are they interchangeable with them? They measure 14" x 9.25" x almost 2" high.

However the dividers that come with 3750 and 3700 are not interchangeable, because the 3700 sections are wider than those in 3750. The sectioning of 3700s differs from 3750s in that it has 4 identical, permanent sections running lengthwise, with 11 parallel, evenly spaced slots for removable dividers (the front row with the latches is missing 2 slots in front of the latches).

question: Will this black light detect mold?
answer: Ya know, while I wasn't looking for mold, I think any UV light will make mold fluoresce. It has something to do with the wavelength of the light and the biologics in the mold. So double check this light's nanometer spectrum of light before buying. I'm thinking this model would detect mold. However, I'm not sure what color mold fluoresces. The tough part is so many things light up sometimes you don't know what you're looking at. Comet (the cleaner) fluoresces. Lots of minerals in cleaning solutions glow. Glue. Lint. It's pretty dizzying in certain areas. I found that the "pattern" of whatever is glowing is just as important - if not more - than the glow. Mice and rat urine trails almost always start with a wider more circular area then "trail" in a direction while diminishing in presence. I would think mold, undetectable in natural light, would glow in a pattern that looks like mold growth. Hope this helps and good luck.

question: is it true only a 15.75" max crosscut? I need to cut 3/4 birch at 16"
answer: If you are cutting your 16" Birch square (90 degrees) then you can also just lift the front of the board slightly (about an inch or so) to finish your cut. You have to be careful that the back of the board remains seated against the fence and remains flat to the table. I've been using this method for nearly 20 years with my Makita LS 1211 which only crosscuts about 14". If you aren't cutting square then you have to flip the board over AND switch it from end to end to finish your cut. That can get tricky if you only have 1/4" of board left to cut.

question: i do have a 30 Amh 12 V battery .. how much Amh this pump pull?.. thx
answer: hey Eric, I never put a amp gauge on it so i couldn't tell you how many amps it draws. However -I've started and run this pump from a little 7 amp 12 volt batteries that are use in alarm panel and such. they sell the 7 amp at like radio shack and home depot. i get them from work as well as 24 amp size too. the 7 amps I usually use when i only have to pump 5 gallons or so-works fine for that -then i top off charge the 7 amp... the 24 amp battery's use for other chores. when I have large pumping chores i hook up to a regular deep cycle battery. so your 30 amp should have no problem running the pump -but how long is another question. also if you do use your 30 amp and its NOT a deep cycle battery i'm sure you will kill it if you run it for extended period - (say a regular garden tractor battery is just for starting purposes and not extended running.) i tried to give you as much information as possible as i could i don't have the pump locally with me to read the spec label or put a amp gauge. Jerry

question: I cannot find key blanks for this lock. Who is the manufacturer?
answer: I have one of these switches in service. They certainly were sourced from China,would be my guess. As far as duplicate keys, I would suggest you find a lock shop, as the key is a really different type than any I've ever seen. Wallyworld, and the common 'big box stores' would not likely have this (weird) key blank. A shop devoted to locksmithing would be the best bet on sourcing a key(s). This key blank is very uncommon as you've probably found. There exists absolutely no 'brand' markings at all, just "7306" (on my key) which would be the cut code. It is also a double cut key, as you can see. A real 'brand X'. Even the head of the key is a PITA. I had to drill out the silly narrrow slot to get it on my key ring. I wish you luck!

question: Does this light detect ringworm?
answer: A quick answer is, I don't know. I don't have ringworm or a suitable fluor around 360 nm to test it on. However, the Woods lamp that is used in vet offices etc has a rough range of 330-390 nm with an optimal wavelength around 365. It appears this works well for most ringworm that can be analyzed this way (bearing in mind that not all ringworms fluoresce or are diagnosed this way). The LED in question is 395 nm, which is about 30 from the Woods lamp optimum. Since most uv lights have a range of at leeast 10-30 nm, this one might work, but again, it might not. It is inexpensive, and can detect scorpions by the manufacturers demo, so maybe it would work. There is probably a difference in intensity from the woods lamp, since that one is a higher power, though the LED (and 21 of those) are pretty intense also...Its cheap enough that if it didn't work, you've lost $9, $15 with shipping...sorry I can't be more specific and say yes. But it really depends on the ringworm and at what wavelength it fluoresces...I did medline and pubmed searches but couldn't find anything more specific.

question: When cutting small 12" pieces to an area ,what is the proceedure for soldering when you DON'T want to use quick connectors ?
answer: Connectors are a hit our miss, so soldering is the way to go. Cut the strips the size you want then scratch a small area with a razor knife down to the copper base then put a dab of flux on that area and add a dab of solder with a hot soldering iron. This is called tinning. Do the same to the wire that you are using then take the iron without adding more solder and touch both together. Here's a picture http://www.irv2.com/attachments/photopost/data/500/HPIM0973.JPG

question: Can you use two solar panels to charge the 2260? Can you use solar + car simultaneously?
answer: Sorry, can you say what the 2260 is? In general, it's possible to run identical panels in parallel, although there are some risks if they aren't generating exactly the same voltage. Typically, circuits with two generator sources (batteries, for example, but solar panels follow the same basic rules) use some mechanism to deal with different voltage outputs. The simplest is to just put a small-value resistor or diode in series with each generator to prevent the one with higher voltage from damaging the other. On your second question (car + solar), I don't know for sure, but I don't think it's a good idea, because your car's alternator will produce a higher voltage than these panels, and they will look like a load to the alternator, running current backward through them. That's probably not a good thing. As before, you could put diodes in series with the panels to prevent "reverse bias" and possible damage to the panels. I'm not actually aware of products that you could use for this purpose for cars. It's probably a bit too sophisticated for such a "low tech" application (stuff like this exists for solar systems for home power). But diodes should work fine. I think somebody in one of the reviews or questions mentioned a solution like this. It's cheap and easy (parts available from Radio Shack, for example).

question: What is a hard start kit, what does it do and why is it needed?
answer: The compressor, outdoor fan, and indoor fan all have capacitors. Rather than a long technical explanation, just know that the cap helps the motors run more efficiently and cooler. It's a good thing. A hard start basically gives the compressor a huge kick in the butt of current when it starts to help it get up to speed. Then it's out of the electrical circuit until the next start up. It's common to add a hard start to and older compressor that IS having a problem on start up. The comp is old, internal clearances are larger and it needs a kick to get it started. It's not uncommon for an new "tight" compressor to need one also. And, some units come with a hard start from the factory.

question: Is this for a furnace?

question: Is this needed if you have a table? If I end up getting the table, is there any benefit of having the guide as well?
answer: If you plan you use your router exclusively in the table you will not need this. However, in woodworking, you either bring the tool to a large piece or bring a smaller piece to the tool (for ease and safety). So, if you will be working primarily small to medium sized pieces, a table alone should be fine. However if you plan to work large, long pieces that are less than portable, the edge guide is ideal for that! Having both would help add versatility to your shop!

question: what's a heat ice method in cutting glass

question: How tall of baseboard will it cut (standing vertically)?

I would recommend you step up to a Sliding compound and poss. 12 inch if deep base and multiple miters are on your schedule? question: is this waterproof?

Know that I am merely pointing you to the manufacturer's website which is the entity that makes this claim / statement. question: Can this door chime be installed vertically or horizontally?
answer: It can NOT be installed vertically [long side of cover running vertically up & down], because the wooden cover hangs onto the doorbell metal structure via a metal clip that is mounted for horizontal mounting of the wooden cover. I doubt you could move that mounting clip to the short side & mount that way & have the doorbell chime work properly, because there doesn't appear to be any way for the clip to hang securely on the doorbell frame; and I doubt the chime piston would function well if the metal doorbell structure was mounted sideways which would mean the chime piston had to strike sideways instead of vertical. Of course you could call the manufacturer & ask their customer service. We no longer have the install instructions. Perhaps the manufacturer has a "vertical mount" model--I don't know. I will try to post a pic of the mounting clip installed inside the wooden cover.

question: Will a Milwaukee battery pack, CAT. #48-11-1820, work on this saw?
answer: The M18 Red Lithium compact battery, 48-11-1815, works with the saw. I'm not sure about the 48-11-1820, which is the 2.0 version of the same compact battery. I expect it will work. Milwaukee advertises the compact battery pack will not work with the sawzall. They claim you need the full size red lithium battery. This is not correct. When I considered buying the sawzall, I already had a drill & driver set with 3 compact batteries. I wanted to use the same batteries with the sawzall. I contacted Milwaukee to determine if the compact batteries would work with the sawzall. They initially said no, then finally confirmed it would work. They said they discouraged people from using the compact battery since the sawzall has a heavy power usage and the compact batteries do not last long with the sawzall. Personally, I prefer the compact battery over the full size battery. The compact batteries are much lighter and easier to work with over the entire day. The batteries charge quickly. With the drill / driver combo, I will work in the morning, charge the batteries over lunch, work in the afternoon and charge again in the evening. With the sawzall, I will use one battery til it goes dead (approx. 30 min), pop in a different battery and put the dead battery on the charger. By the time the new battery is dead, the battery on the charger is recharged and I swap them out. In several years I've had very few times where the compact battery goes dead and I cannot continue working. If I will not have access to an electrical outlet for the charger in my work area, then I charge all three batteries beforehand and plan accordingly.

But I think the main difference is the texture of the candle. Both are wax, but the regular is smooth and the deluxe has some texture, seems more like a real candle. The deluxe comes in the round white box and the regular is in the square black box. I am answering this from the point of having bought several of these (LOVE THEM). question: How many bulbs can be controlled from one remote?

question: will it fit MERV 10?
answer: MERV Rating is a good way to help judge the effectiveness of the filter. MERV means Minimum Efficiency Reporting Value which was developed by the American Society of Heating, Refrigeration and Air Conditioner Engineers - ASHRAE. MERV values vary from 1 to 16. The higher the MERV value is the value the more efficient the filter will be in trapping airborne particles. Another consideration is air flow through the your HVAC system. Leaving a dirty air filter in place or using a filter that is too restrictive may result in low air flow and possibly cause the system to malfunction.

question: would this work for square acrylic tubing?

question: I ordered this based on good reviews but it doesn't snap on to any of my 5 gal buckets, tried Ace, Home Depot and a Leaktite Multipurpose???
answer: I just received this tote-able toilet seat and found out why there is so much confusion about fitting these onto a bucket. Perhaps some of them are a little easier but mine seemed impossible. I weigh over 250 and I was unable to press the seat onto the bucket in any way shape or form. Then I discovered the secret on mine was to not press the seat onto the bucket but to press the bucket onto the seat! After doing it this way I was able to fit the lid onto every bucket I had in my house which included buckets from Aubuchon, Walmart, VIP, and Home Depot. A small person may need to improvise with added weight or the help of a second person but this is how it worked for me: 1) Lay the seat onto firm but soft flat surface (carpet) upside down with the lid opening tab facing away from you and the hinge toward you. 2) Loosely place the bucket upside down onto the center ring of the seat with the bucket handle lined up with the seat lid tab (away from the hinge). 3) Kneeling behind the hinge of the seat lay your chest on the bucket so the bucket lip closest to you pushes into the seating ring first. 4) Slowly rock your weight forward pushing the lip of the bucket into the ring working both sides toward the front. You can run your fingers behind seam as it closes but do not let your weight get in front of the seam or the back will pop back out. 5) As the rear and sides of the bucket lip slide into the seating ring you will be able to look down at the front of the bucket and see the lip bulging out over approximately 6 inches of the front of the ring when it is almost seated. 6) When the lip is no longer slipping into the seating ring, smack the bulging part with your fist or a rubber mallet, which will pop it into place with an audible snap.

question: Does the solar panel and fan all included in the price of $412? Ready to run?
answer: Yes, for our project it included all [Solar panel, Fan Unit, screws and cable] the parts, but that said, our high peak wall vent was just under the roof peak facing, correctly, to the south and we snaked the 10'+ Solar panel, mounted high up on the roof almost to the peak vents, and wired/plugged it in thru the roof top vent down to the attic and over to the Fan/vent. [If your fan and panel are NOT that close you may need to buy/extend the two wire/cable. Plus with full sun we can hear the fan running in the bedroom below, but is NOT very loud and only in the day time. Also we had to use cut down, scrap 2" X 4" boards to "pad" down the 3" bigger square vent grill to make it fit the fan unit and be air tight, which of course did NOT show from the outside and we made the vent removable with 4 screws and caulking for outside access to avoid the attic insulation and long crawl space to get to that end.] During a new roof install the roofer noted this fan would have worked better if we had the correct eave vents vs. the side wall vents on each end wall for roof longevity AND for removing excess heat. [The small solar panel was easily removed/unplugged to put on the new roof.] The 70 deg. Temp. cut off Sensor stops the unit from working in the colder months which was an extra $16... http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0002YVUOO/ref=oh_details_o03_s00_i01?ie=UTF8&psc=1 AS ALL WAYS - SAFETY FIRST WITH LADDERS AND ROOF WALKING !!! [We used a contractor which added about another $250 due to the vent carpentry work and our inability to run the roof/ladders.] Bigger question: NOT sure how long the payback will be, but did reduce the temp. some on the upper floor bedrooms where all the house heat goes with our poor/undersized central HVAC system. This was purchased to be an HVAC power saving device.

question: where is the positive solar input screw?
answer: Jay I have 4 of these Might Mules for several years now. I am going to give you my answer that worked after I vent. Mighty Mule has an advantage because of market share -- the clicker, parts, batteries, etc. all at Home Depot, Tractor Supply, etc. And they have been reasonably reliable. I can see from the DVR and magazine size instruction booklet that they have had customers provide feedback that the user interface is not "5 star". At least it is not for me. I think I finally assumed in the black and white documentation that black meant black and white meant red and put the black into the insert toward the top and red (or positive if using different color wire) is beneath it. I think I reversed it once and the good thing is it just blows the fuse which is easy to change. Another good thing is you have the 500 which is way easier to deal with than the 350 by far. I have two other things to add. When the thing starts beeping at some point (and it will) the first guess is always the battery, they go out between 1-2 years. Sometimes it will jam and it will be necessary to unhook the arm and manually screw it in a few rounds or so to get it unjammed then hold the close set button down to clear then reset the closed position. Reading the beep sequence guide in the manual was, for me, interesting. I hope Mighty Mule has a social media group that reads these posts and will see I am not flaming them. If I bought a 5th unit it would be a Mighty Mule. BUT, I would pay them $100 to get a "500 Plus" for which there was an LED read out of status, well marked and easier interfaces. I have to pull out the manual every time one of my 4 goes on the blink. Come on Mighty Mule ... congrats on achieving market share dominance now fortify it by improving user interface. Hire someone from Apple engineering to oversee moving to a more fool proof (I am the fool here, not Jay) interface.

question: I'm debating between this breaker bar and a t-shaped / 4-way one. Which tool is easier to loosen extremely tight tire lug nuts?
answer: this one by far, long and away. hands down, no contest. the length of, and pivot point (elbow bend to handle), is so different on matters of physics and my actual personal experience. It's also a well made heavy duty and heavy tool. I bought this specifically for a motorcycle wheel i couldn't get off and had broken a two quality (but obviously wrong) tools on trying to get it off. this thing took it off so easy, with so little pressure from me, that my whole world view changed. A few months later a friend called with a flat and i brought it just in case and i was again very impressed with the physics power of this thing. In that situation I we had a 4-way and it failed to break 2 of the lug nuts and so i broke out the 24 inch and they came off like butter. ___NOW!!!! the only down side is that you will need to buy a socket bit that fits this bar (it's 1/4 inch drive and not the usual, house hold 3/8 inch)....and also the socket bits that fit your needs/lugnuts/whatever... and this may include needing to get 'deep socket' set or bit. They are cheaper to buy a set off of amazon than in a hardware store and it's usually safer to just get the 'deep' since they work on all bolts and nuts...they're just a little heavy. You might also want to pick up some adaptors for both ways so your you can use all your socket wrenches with all the bits. you need a 1/4 inch to 3/8 and a 3/8 to1/4, you can skip the latter if you want but i'd really suggest getting the 1/4 inch to 3/8 so you can use this big bad boy with all your sockets. good luck and please don't hesitate to ask anymore questions.

question: Why is a "jumper" needed on the other 3 way switch? How come the other traveler wire isn't connected?
answer: I am not an electrician, but if you google "PLS750C1000 manual" you can see the wiring diagram for an Existing 3-way Install and follow as I try to describe why a jumper is needed. Starting from the right hand 3-way, power comes to the switch, is jumpered across the Common terminal and the Traveler terminal that goes to the timer switch's Line (black) wire. In effect, this bypasses the right hand 3-way providing constant power to the timer's Line, regardless of the 3-way's switch position. The 3-way's other Traveler terminal connects to the timer's 3-way (yellow) wire, and the 3-way switch basically acts like a single pole (regular on/off) switch. If you look at the electrical flow, it goes into the 3-way's Common terminal, then depending on whether the 3-way is switched one way or the other, power either goes to the timer's 3-way (yellow) wire or does not go. That is, the yellow wire is either "on" or "off". (For what it's worth, when the yellow wire is off, power is going through both the switch and jumper to the timer's Line (black) wire. When the yellow is on, power is going through only the jumper to the timer's Line (black) wire.) I have not confirmed this with Honeywell, but I believe the timer looks at its 3-way (yellow) wire for a change of state. When there is a change of state on the timer's 3-way (yellow) wire (from off to on, or from on to off), the timer sees that change and changes the state of the load from whatever it is currently to its opposite (That is, from on to off or from off to on). So, hopefully that answers why the jumper is needed on the other 3-way switch. And that also kind of answers why both travelers are not connected as they would be normally. It's basically because of the timer's design. I hope this helps. If not, I would do as another respondent suggested and call or email Honeywell. They were good at timely answering a wiring question I had, since my setup matches neither their Existing 3-way nor their New 3-way diagrams precisely.

The scope caps are one piece black rubber with rubber straps between the rubber lens covers. They looked good at first, but taking the caps on and off, flexed the rubber and the paint flaked off.. question: hi, can i interface it my chevy volt homelink garage opener with aleco ac2700 gate opener by using this interface?
answer: It is possible, but you will want to check with Chamberlain first to see if it requires a repeater kit. In 2007 they introduced a new security scheme, and Homelink provided compatible equipment, but not all car manufacturers started using it right away. In fact, as late as 2011 some car makers were still using the old Homelink technology that would not work with the new Chamberlain stuff "out of the box". So you will want to confirm with both Chamberlain and Chevrolet if your year and model car will be able to transmit the new codes. If not, there is an add-on repeater that will receive your Homelink signal and translate it to the new Chamberlain security codes, but it is about $50 retail itself. However, this unit IS what you would be looking for to attach to your gate opener to receive signals from your Homelink or a remote. Sorry I can't give a more definitive answer, but there are a lot of variables. May be better to buy one locally that you can return easily if you cannot get your Homelink to work with it.

question: What are the items included in this kit?

question: I don't have a basement, can this be stored outside? Are there other suggestions for placement?
answer: Yes, HDPE is UV stable and used for outdoor water tanks. The main issue is freezing. If your emergency water is a block of ice, you can't use it until it thaws. If you have space outdoors and freezing is not an issue, then you should look at other HDPE water tanks which hold more and/or are less expensive. You are paying a premium for this tank because it is designed to be as large as possible and still fit through a 30" wide residential doorway. If you don't need to pass through a 30" doorway, there are better choices. If you don't have room indoors and freezing is an issue, then another option is an underground tank but it would need to be buried below the frost line to avoid freezing, and you need some kind of pump to bring the water up out of the ground.

question: there seems to be a problem: the women feature and the regular feature target the same area.We can't understand why , any fixes for this?

question: Can this be used in a shower if well sealed?
answer: No. It is incredibly porous. There is no amount of sealing that could change that. The texture of the tile makes it nearly impossible to clean. Also, the way the tile is situated on the mesh combined with the texture/varying depths of the tile makes it incredibly difficult to grout, which is problematic. I wouldn't recommend this tile in a food prep space because it can't be cleaned - it will harbor bacteria and other debris. If use this in a shower, you will probably end up with a mold issue or other water damage. This tile would be best suited as an accent tile on a mantle, backsplash for basement bar, etc.

question: Stupid question, but I am at a loss. I believe the batteries go in one end of the flashlight but I can not get it opened. Is that where they go?
answer: Hello sir, First of all no question is stupid especially if it gets you out of a bind. Yes, the batteries are to be placed in the aft end (the screw cap opposite the bulb) of the unit if it is like a standard maglite. I shipped mine down to Haiti and did not open them up but I have had many others and they always opened up from that end and there is no reason to believe they go in the bulb end as there is a mechanism for the switch and the bulb socket on that side. The positive side with the nipple goes toward the bulb. If this is a new unit and never has had batteries this is unusual but as the other guy said it can be very, very tight when new. If it is a used unit that someone gave you and it has batteries in it the possibility exists that the batteries exploded from heat and the corrosive affects of the chemicals has jammed the threads of the end cap. This happened to me a couple of times here in south Florida in a hot work van over the summer. Try to coat the threads with something not to heavy (light grease or a nickel or copper based never seez compound come to mind) in the future. This will help.

question: Will it fit 2-1/2 in drillpress

question: Does anyone know the exact measurements of the sink so I can tell my cabinet maker the drop and hole size?

question: Do I need to somehow disconnect my old built in receiver? 3 screws on opener and 3 screws on new receiver...what do i do? tried separate and combined

question: what`s the difference between the model DCD 985L2, DCD985M2, DCD985, and the DCD985B
answer: The DCD985L2 and the DCD985M2 are the exact same drill. Only the batteries are different. The M2 comes with 4 Amp-hour batteries, and the L2 comes with 3 Amp-hour batteries. Naturally the 4 Ah batteries will last much longer than the 3 Amp-hour batteries, and since the size and weight of the batteries is the same, the DCD985M2 is a superior drill. The DCD985B is the bare drill only, without any batteries or charger. The part number DCD985 is not a legitimate DeWalt part number, because it is only a partial of the other three. Hope that helps.

question: Is this available now?
answer: Amazon says one to three months, but I suspect it will be sooner. Amazon already got the review samples from Dremel and is shipping those out. So they are definitely ready for production. I checked and my local Home Depot doesn't have them but the nearby Lowes does. They don't have any user reviews yet though. Amazon tends to overestimate delays rather than not meeting promises, and I can't think of why Dremel would send review samples unless it were planning to send them out very soon. If you have specific questions, you might want to wait until the reviews start coming in, or brave it and get one locally if a store has it. You can expect to see reviews coming in perhaps as early as next week, and almost definitely by the following week. I know it's been a while since you posted your question, so if you got one by now you may want to write your own review. If not, if there's something specific that you want tested, you could post here. I can't promise anything though but it would be nice to know how people plan to use it.

question: Do you guys experience any wobble side to side when making cuts? Overall do you regret buying the saw compared to a standard circsaw and hommade edge
answer: When I first got the saw, yes there was a lot of side to side wobble. I pulled the plastic strips the saw runs on off and placed them as far apart as possible. The saw is now rock solid when it's on the rail. Another change I made was I cut out about 1" of the spring that holds the saw in the up position. This still holds the saw up but drastically reduces the wrist fatigue when using the saw. It makes it much easier to hold down when reaching across a 4' wide sheet. (Check out https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=vqqcmC5UY5E) After making these changes, I have absolutely no regrets in purchasing this saw. I'm much happier with it than a homemade edge guide and a standard circular saw. Hope this helps.

question: What is maximum size drill will fit in chuck?
answer: The driver takes 1/4" bits so it will take any sized drills that have a 1/4" shank. I have up to 2 1/2" wood bits with 1/4" shanks that can be used in this driver but I don't know that I would. You can also purchase a 1/4" drill chuck that will take any size drill bit; this tool will then be limited only by what size drill the chuck can handle. I have drilled 1/2" holes in wood with this driver but with anything larger, I wouldn't be using this driver anyway. I would switch over to a 120v electric drill. So, I guess it really boils down to what you plan to do with this driver. I use it for screws most all of the time but if I need to drill some holes it will do the job very nicely. For larger holes use larger tools. Hope this helps.

question: How hard would installation be for someone with no knowlege or experience in working with wiring?
answer: There are problems with doing this task beyond the wiring. You will be working on a ladder. You will be working poking your head through the fan blades to access the dome where the fan attaches to the ceiling. You will be twisting wires together and fastening them with wire nuts. You should disconnect the electricity supplying the fan. And finally, and possibly most difficult for a lady is you may need to lower and lift the weight of the assembled fan. If you can follow the wiring directions, that last item could be your biggest problem. If you still have the fan original installation instructions (or if you can find them online), study how the fan is mounted to the ceiling. If you need to lift the weight of the fan at any point, you might want to have this done. If the dome drops or snaps or unscrews off of the ceiling (and slides down the pipe holding the fan) then the task is SO much easier and I would say you could do it. If that is the case, ask at your hardware store how to use wire nuts to fasten stranded wire to solid wire and stranded wire to stranded wire and go for it.

question: Always on??? How do you prevent battery drain when not in use?
answer: The unit is always on... and always ready to use. Whenever I pick one up I always put it next to a light switch or socket to see if it lights. That's the extent of my checks. Amazingly, my first unit had the batteries in it for 7, possibly 8 years. I simply never thought about it until my son asked me about the batteries when I gave him one. He's had his for 3 years now and he has not changed the batteries. My son also bought the other version with an on/off switch when he couldn't find the 2AC at the hardware store; it works fine too, though he generally uses the 2AC. Fluke mentions a low energy circuitry... whatever they designed, it works superbly and has identified countless hot circuits I presumed were hot. And saved me from a few hot circuits I thought were cold. The oldest unit I own is probably a dozen years old.

question: I have a lathe with a 1/3 HP 6.6 A split phase motor 1725 RPM It has pulleys so is a pain to change speed. Will this work to slow it down?
answer: The only one I know about was an easy solid state construction project way back in the '90s. It had only a handful of components, including a triac, a silicone controlled rectifier (SCR), a potentiometer (variable resistor) and about 6 resistors and capacitors. It was in a book of simple electronic projects. I built it in an hour (once I had the parts). Unfortunately, I lent it to someone who tried to use it with a 5HP elevator motor. That slagged it. The other responder to your original question is WRONG. Any speed controller that reduced voltage, also reduces available torque. That'll work for a fan because the load is small & balanced. That isn't very desirable in a lathe motor as it will stall the machine if anything but the smallest cuts are attempted. The solid state controllers such as the one sold by Amazon interrupts the AC waveform to a greater or lesser extent, thereby allowing full torque at any speed (& smooth operation at even slow speeds). I'd Google "solid state AC motor speed controller", sift the hits for any mention of "DC" - which would rule it out for your application. Check out what's left for your motor (check with the seller as you did with Amazon). BTW, the reason your lathe has gears (or pulleys) to regulate speed is because, until Triacs, there was no other way to slow an AC motor & retain necessary torque. Good luck.

question: Can I use this with a Black and Decker corded drill? Model DR350FD 6 amps with a "removable chuck"?
answer: Sure, any chuck will clamp on to it. I just went out to the garage and tried it. It works fine. There are six flats on the Milwaukee 90 degree unit and three moveable flats on the three-jaw chuck. It grips fine; no adapter needed. Clarification: the input shaft can be driven by a standard three jaw chuck from a cordless or corded drill driver. The output however, requires a 1/4-inch hex adapter to be able to grip a drill bit. The one I purchased is a Milwaukee 49-22-1560 1/4-Inch Chuck Attachment, cost $26 a little over a year ago. Hope this helps. Winds up being a little pricey, but sometimes it's the only way to get the job done.

question: How many hours of use from one set of batteries?
answer: Not sure of the exact number but I use mine to illuminate my Lyman case prep station and I can use it an hour or so at a time for months without changing batteries. In my opinion the battery life is above average when using a quality, (not necessarily expensive) set of batteries. I buy all my batteries thru Amazon, including those I use in my insulin pump. Always buy name brand but they are still a fraction of the price of local sellers. AAA, AA, CR2032, LR44, etc. I use for optics and other things and at the price I get them on Amazon, I can buy enough to never worry about not having what I need at any time. I elaborate because a crappy battery will give short life in the best of devices. A decent or really good battery will give long, long life.

question: what is the max. depth a person can drill in cedar?
answer: Cedar would not be a factor in depth. The depth would be reliant on how far down the cutter is set, the length of the spindle in the chuck and the circumference of the hole (a smaller hole will hit the back end of the cutter bar when you reach that height). Unless you have cedar thicker than two inches and are making holes smaller than two you should be fine. However if that is your goal a Fostner bit would be more practical.

question: does this blade remove 1/8"
answer: Zachary, I used this blade to cross-cut bamboo flooring and it did an amazing job. The actual width of the cut is a little less than an 1/8". The term for the width of a cut is Kerf. This precision cut blade is manufactured to have a kerf of 0.102". This is about 1/64" narrower than a 1/8" wide cut. Remember that precision cuts you need a quality miter saw and saw blade.

question: How do you joint a board wider than 6"?
answer: jointing edges are not a problem but face jointing over 6 inches presents several problems. First you run one side through then run the other unplaned area through. You need to take a pass one after the other to keep them even. You should be sure to adjust the fence to 1/2 the board's width so that you are able to be uniform in the passes. Ideally you should use a surface planer or large drum sander greater than the dimensions of the board you wish to plane

question: Where are Jet tablesaws manufactured?
answer: JET Equipment was born in 1958 when the founder of the company, Leslie P. Sussman, took the first Boeing Jet Airplane trip from Seattle, WA to Japan. JET began as a small dealer of manual chain hoists and trolleys; sold from a single hardware store in Tacoma, Washington. Over the years, JET has carried everything from electric chain hoists, air hoists. Beginning in the 70's JET introduced a full line of industrial air tools and material handling products which included paving breakers and backfill tampers and forklifts. By the early '80s, as JET continued to grow, the metalworking products became the core business line. And 5 short years later, JET launched it's woodworking product category rounding out the largest breath of product categories under one brand. JET pioneered the import business by working with overseas suppliers. We are proud to say we still do business with one of our original suppliers. In the 90's JET grew from being just an importer of high quality machines and tools to designing and manufacturing its own products to stringent specifications. We are have an expert team of engineers both in the USA and overseas and a world-class supply chain ensuring prompt delivery of quality products. Over the years, our colors have changed from blue, to green, orange, and finally white that you see today on most of our products. Our product lines have grown, and the distribution centers have expanded; but one thing has remained the same. JET still carries the same message of quality product, with the best features and benefits in it's product class; all the while providing excellent service. We pride ourselves on bringing new products to our consumers and working with world class distributors.

question: Are the individual sockets adjustable, can they be spread out, swivel, twist or are they fixed?
answer: Even though they appear to have a seam that looks like it would contain a hinge joint, neither the angle of the four sockets, nor their spacing are adjustable. The rectangular slot-like aspects on the side of each socket are the joining points between the plastic base of the sockets and their cylindrical extensions. This dovetail design provides more stability than other methods of joining two pieces of plastic together.

question: My flashlight is takes a C size battery. It's no bigger than 1 1/2". Will this holder be to big for my flashlight? If so do you have a smaller one?

question: What is maximum height for top step when being used as a stepladder?
answer: When set up as a stepladder, the "nominal" step-to-step distance is 12 inches. On my Werner MT-22, I measured the actual floor-to-step height as follows: Step 1: 11-1/2" Step 2: 22-3/4" Step 3: 34" Step 4: 45-1/2" Step 5: 56-1/4" Step 6: 67-3/4" Step 7: 79" Step 8: 90-1/2" Top Step: 102" I expect that the step-to-step distances would be the same (or very close to same) on the MT-13, MT-17, and MT-26, although the number of steps would of course be different. By the way, it's a superb ladder! Stable, rugged, versatile, easy to set up, easy to store, and (worth saying again) very stable. Well worth the price.

question: Anyone having the same problem as me ? I'm so used to using a rafter square on my left hand as a guide and using a corded saw on my right to cut 2 x 4s, but having a hard time adjusting to holding the square with my right and using the saw with my left...
answer: Ditch the square, follow your line using the cut guide at the front of the base plate. You'll cut much straighter that way than you will watching the blade cut the line. The only time you should be watching the blade is when you start and finish the cut. A speed square is handy for getting that extra precise 90 degree cut, but there should be a point where you don't need it for most framing related cuts. If what you're doing requires an extra precise cut that will be seen, I don't see why you can't still use the square in your left hand, just let your waste fall to the right. You could also just get used to cutting with your opposite hand, it's good to be ambidextrous with a circular saw.

question: How do I know it will drill straight? And is there a limit as to how thin of a drill bit it can take?

You can straighten by chucking up a rod and tapping with a hammer while watching a dial indicator (see YouTube for more details). The included chuck only goes down to 1/16" I think. But you can get any number of specialty chucks. Jacobs brand chucks are pretty much the standard. FYI, you need a Morse 2 tapered arbor for this press.

question: I have to glue three broken fingers to a polystone statue. Does this "instant" CA glue need an accelerator, or is it actually "instant"?
answer: An accelerant isn't necessary at all, BUT if it difficult to keep the part in place and tight then it is handy. I have used them when gluing tiny parts that can't be held in place easily. Remember to put the pieces together first and flow in the CA glue thin (fresh bottle is best). If any ends up on the outside for ceramics you can scrape away with a razor blade carefully (let it cure overnight) or use the solvent carefully making sure it doesn't get to the glue joint. For tiny things using a wooden tooth pick to carry the glue work well, just put a puddle on some tin foil and pick the liquid up with the pick and the crack will suck it in. Hope that helps.

question: Is the charger available separately? I lost mine.
answer: Don't know. A charger of the correct voltage, and connecting plug, could be found from an electronics store. Amazon may have a compatible one. There are also ones made of a variable voltage, and a selection of power plugs. If yours is not working, check both of the wires for continuity from the base of the transformer to the plug. It is common for a wire to break at the base of the plug in transformer, or the base of the plug. Usually can be fixed easily. The little wall wart power supply rarely burns out. question: looking for small stock (jewelry/ hobby applications) - what is the smallest stock this ring roller will take?

question: What temperatures are required to cure the paint multiple times at various temperatures in an oven? Will the final coating survive any contact with food?

question: Is there an adapter plate for a standard 3 hole 4 inch bathroom faucet? Want to use in pedestal sink. I like the look, and it has great clearance.
answer: This does NOT come with an adapter plate since this is made for a single hole install. You can get any escutcheon to make the single hole design work where there are many counter top holes present. The one I used was "8" Kitchen Sink Faucet Hole Cover Deck Plate Escutcheon, Brushed Nickel" found here: http://www.amazon.com/dp/B005GLWFC4/ That install was for a kitchen sink that was to have light use however. Choose a look which is good for a pedestal sink. Most hardware and big box home improvement stores have escutcheons and such to allow changes like this (three or four hole settings taking a single hole faucet). Just be sure you seal everything, facet bottom and escutcheon, with plumber's putty or clear silicone as you may need to. The included lines are long enough to work with mounting this on top of an escutcheon and have no issues. If you are not doing this yourself, ask the plumber who you'll hire to do the job about his ideas and send him a link to the Amazon page. The normal install is just put this on the surface of the sink in a single hole. Any minor change, like an escutcheon or other small elevation for this to sit on, does not effect the working of the faucet however.

question: What is lowest the float switch can be installed? Have 15" betwn the bottom of the pit and the drain tile. Will the float be below the drain tile?
answer: The overall height of the pump is 12". It is not necessary to mount the switch to the pipe coming out of the top unless you have a very narrow diameter opening. If that is the case, the water level will reach 12 to 14" before activating pump. If you have a 10" or greater diameter opening, you can mount the float switch, using a long zip tie, to the top of the pump casing (you can see bracket on top of float switch in picture), the pump will activate at approximately 4.5" water level. You can slide the float switch further down, but the pump will run more often. The float will be below the drain tile. I have two of these used in conjunction with a 12v backup. They were purchased on Amazon and I am a satisfied with them. The float switches are mounted to the casing.

question: In an area under the bathroom . It's isolated as far as access. I'd need to drill a hole and drop the leads through. Probably doable? Size drill hole?
answer: A one-inch hole would be plenty. If you would prefer a smaller hole, how about: 1) Clip the cable so that the sensor plate is no longer attached. 2) There are two wires in the cable; clip one of the two wires 1/4" shorter than the other. 3) Strip off some insulation from each of the two wires. Be sure not to strip so much off the longer wire that the shorter wire can touch the longer wire's bare metal, and thus sound a false alarm. Once you've done that, you could probably shove the wire through a very tiny hole and it would still do a fine job of detecting water.

question: What is the CRI?
answer: The color rendering index (CRI) of a light source is a quantitative measure of its ability to reproduce the colors of various objects faithfully in comparison with an ideal or natural light source. It is significant because it has been the most difficult metric for incandescent replacement light bulbs to match (while maintaining high efficiency) and therefore the most frequently ignored. For that reason, LED light bulbs with a high CRI can be worthy replacements for incandescent light bulbs. Most LED lights do not have a CRI above 90. However, CRI is a poor indicator of the perception of light produced by LEDs, and scores as low as 25 can produce vivid-appearing white light, while high-scoring sources can still be very poor at rendering reds, including skin tones. [2]

question: I got this switch so when door is closed light comes on ,discriiption says it does that but have no instruction how to ?
answer: Albert, the switch is a spring loaded button that goes in the door jam above the hinge, or on the closing side of a sliding door. The switch, in the natural position with the door open and plunger extended, will turn the light on. When you close the door, it will press the switch and disconnect the circuit. I will give you some heads-up advice - if you have a solid wood frame and are doing this as an addition to a swinging door, you will have to cut a large chunk out of the 2x4 frame so the switch will fit. I installed this on three closets. It's an awesome little device, but just prepared to tear in that corner of the door, make a little mess, and do some patch-up work. If you want the switch to turn the light on when the door is closed, rather than when the door is open, you will be better off buying the correct switch. There is no way to reverse the function of the switch.

question: What EXACTLY is the purpose of these glasses? A lot of reviewers said NOT to use them for night driving or driving in general, so what then?
answer: These are indeed not suitable for driving as they almost fully block blue light! These are primarily protective glasses and they provide good "physical" protection against anything that can get into your eyes (e.g. in a lab or manufacturing area). The secondary 'property' of these specific pair with orange lens is to block blue light. In certain industrial environments continuous and/or high level of blue light is present which can cause damage to, or at least fatigue of the eyes. So, the blue blocking property helps to mitigate that for the workers. Now, most of the consumers here (me as well) are buying these for their blue blocking capability and not the physical protection. Generally, the blue (and green to some extent) light is one of the causes of eye fatigue for individuals who work in artificial light (e.g. fluorescent), and with computers (the monitor being the source); therefore, some people are getting the glasses for helping with that. Another interesting advantage of wearing these is for those people like me who have delayed sleep phase syndrome: it has been found that these individuals can benefit from reduced blue light, a few hours before sleep. By reducing the blue light with these glasses, the amount of disturbance to the sleep is reduced - at least it is working for me. - For reference on the protective property of the glasses please visit "http://uvex.us/uploadedFiles/ProductConfiguration/ProductLiterature/skyperfamily.pdf" - For reference on the lens tint property please visit "http://www.uvex.us/uvexlenstechnology.aspx?id=4178" - For delayed sleep phase syndrome and the effect of blue light please check: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delayed_sleep_phase_disorder#Non-pharmacologic Cheers, hhsquall

question: Thanks Dan H but (1) Does that make the box 60 amp total. (2) My 220v output is 20 amp, am I limited to 20 amp load or 40. (3) can I change to 30 amp output so I want overload and trip the breaker? My generator is 7500 watts I shouldn't overload it but...
answer: This power distribution box converts a 220V input feed with a neutral conductor into multiple 120V output circuits that are GFCI protected and over-current protected at 20 amps. If your generator can output 20A at 220V, then you can theoretically connect up to 40A of load at 120V via this distribution box as long as your 120V loads are balanced on a per phase basis. To ensure system safety, your generator output must have a 30A 2-pole circuit breaker (20A or 25A would also be fine) to ensure the per phase current never exceeds 30A, which is the rating of the twist-lock input receptacle.

question: Can I use this to seal the cut ends of pressure treated timbers
answer: Hello Thomas; Yes it will work on pressure-treated wood butt-ends (but pt wood is specifically designed to resist sub-grade rot, so if your pt wood is degrading that seriously, you might want to consider replacement. If that is not possible use several petrifier treatments - letting each cure before applying another - maybe 3 treatments.) The stuff really does stiffen crumbling/rotting wood, but it is not a cure-all for wood that is completely decayed. If you are looking just to seal the butt-ends of pt lumber, I would consider something like Woodlife Coppercoat Green Wood Preservative ( chemically similar to the original pt but green in color, which gradually fades to clear - two coats) or Ace WoodRoyal Waterproofing and Protector/Toner for decks, etc. (comes in a number of semi-transparent toner colors (less toxic, but less durable - two coats). Hope that helps.
