question: can you measure hex drill bits.
answer: You sure can Judy. The hex shape is for a slip free fit in the drill chuck. It usually has zero to do with the bit size. Whether your bit is a twist or forstner, all measurements should be made at the cutting end of the bit. I use inexpensive calipers (Standard fraction units for fractional bits, Metric for metric bits)purchased at a hardware store. Hardware stores also sell a drill index for checking bit size. It's a flat piece of either steel of plastic with hole punched in it with corresponding size next to the hole. Hope this helps.

question: Why are these 20V kits from Dewalt not available from Amazon directly and why are the prices from 3rd party so much more expensive? New line coming out?
answer: If you see a Dewalt drill on Amazon that Amazon says it is out-of-stock in their inventory, there may still be a third-party selling it. What's more, sometimes third party sellers team up with Amazon, so then the item will be held at an Amazon warehouse and will be shipped by Amazon. This is a partnership that allows for third-party companies to offer products through a trusted seller like Amazon, while still being actively involved in the actual sale of their items. In terms of pricing, we are unsure if there is a new Dewalt line coming out or not any time soon. It's very likely, however, but pricing in general - especially in used merchandise - is incredibly competitive. Competition sometimes forces extremes, with people vastly undercutting prices or vastly overpricing items to try to swing average prices in a certain direction. It's also possible that what appears to be a very high price was the average price not too long ago, but extreme undercutting dropped the average price artificially, and chances are the price average will eventually rise back up to where it should be. Thanks for your interest, and I hope this helped!

question: can the motion sensor be overrided / i.e. can you have it come on and stay on?
answer: No, you can't override any of the activities except to turn on or shut the entire unit off using a pin switch. The switch disconnects the battery so the light doesn't come on during shipment or handling. It arrives in the "off" position and you must turn it on after installation or it won't work. If the light were to remain on, the battery would discharge in an hour or two and the unit would turn off. The brief "on" time is to preserve the battery life so it will function most of the night. It will emit a glow (low power) as soon as it gets dark so you can actually see in the immediate area. It will brighten for about 30 seconds when the motion sensor activates it. The glow is about like a 10 watt bulb and the bright is about like a 60 watt bulb. Hope this helps.

question: what does without overflow mean

question: the heat fan light unit I am looking at, the Panasonic FV-11VHL2 WhisperWarm requires a 20 amp circuit, but this switch is rated for 15amps.
answer: Do NOT put a heater rated for 20 amps on a 15 amp circuit. It should trip the circuit breaker bc you are overloading the circuit. Better to call an electrician for a solution, which will probably include running a new 20 amp circuit, dedicated to the Panasonic FV-11VHL2. If you already have a heater in the bathroom, choose a Panasonic fan that doesn't include a heater, then you probably could use the 15 amp circuit, depending upon what else is served by that circuit.

question: What is the beams distance on the highest output and is the beam focused or wide? I also would like to know when switching outputs does it go through each till i get to the desired output or does it switch to the output i want when needed
answer: The beam illuminates a 125 yard bard side extremely well. I rate well as being as good as nearly as good as daytime visibility. The beam it puts out is wide and non-adjustable. I would assume that it is non-adjustable to keep from having focus problems due to the bulb configuration. It cycles through the modes each time you depress the button, The way it cycles is Hold for 3 seconds(exits Lockout of it is turned on), 1 full push on/of, 1 half depression cycles through modes 3L, 150L, 600L, 1850L. With the flashlight off if you push and hold it will be on turbo mode (3800L). To lock turbo mode on you need to hold the button down and release half way and then repress the button, When in this mode you can half way depress the button and and change between 3800L and 1850L. For special modes the light can be on in any mode push the button all the way down twice quickly(a little tricky at first it needs to be quick). Then half depressions cycles between strobe, beacon and SOS. All special modes seem to us 3800 lumen. Pushing and holding the main button down for 3 seconds will enter Lockout mode. If left in standby mode the blue ring around the power button will flash. If you leave to standby or Lockout when turned back on it will go to the last mode you left it in. This makes it easy for finding the thing in the dark. Now to the OLED control button in any mode(except special modes) a push cycles through Head temp in C, #### lumens level ##, #.##V, Battery indicator, and Hours left at current level ###H. If the OLED goes out a push of the button will display the last displayed mode. If the light level is changed it will always revert back to Level screen. This flashlight does not have any type of auto level setting. On a final note it is a nice flashlight and I have tried its underwater function and also dropped it in oil(on accident) and it didn't hurt it any. Some oils will damage the optics of the glass so not really recommended I'm sure.

question: Is the u/l rating based on the the canister itself or the propellant inside? the b500 is similarly priced so wondering what the catch is.
answer: Most fire extinguishers carry a UL rating. Most states require extinguishers to be UL listed before they can be sold to the public. "UL" stands for Underwriters Laboratory, a worldwide organization that researches and tests the safety of a variety of objects, including fire extinguishers. UL fire extinguisher ratings fall into two classes: Class A and Class B:C. A fire extinguisher typically carries both classes on its UL label. A UL rating may look like: 4A:60B:C. Class A refers to the amount of water the extinguisher is equivalent to; one "A" is equal to 1.25 gallons of water. The B stands for the square footage the extinguisher can handle when operated by a professional. The C indicates that the extinguisher can be used on electrical equipment.

question: Will it prevent back flow with or without zero pressure?
answer: Yes. It operates on a simple principle, pressure from the desired direction passes through while pressure from the opposite direction is blocked and will often activate a release causing "backflow" water to be drained off. Note: If, for example, a hose is attached that has a nozzle at the opposite end, that is closed, then the hose will pressurize and retain its pressure. If the faucet (with the back flow device installed) is turned off, the pressure will remain in the hose until the nozzle is slightly opened (or a connection is loosened) then the internal valve will release the hose pressure through the relief 'vents' in the back flow preventer. This device meets building requirements in many localities where a back flow preventer is required on outdoor water faucets. I use mine with an RV, so that water from the RV side does not enter the city water source side of the valve.

question: Could you hang a heavy piece of wood shelving with these? The shelf measures 34" long, 2" thick, and 12" deep. Would it pull out of the studs?
answer: Hi, I have not tried to hang a shelf but I have hung small cabinets with a cleat. I have a cabinet hanging on a cleat in my home. It has been hanging without problems for a couple of years now. The cabinet is about 20 inches wide, 30 inches high, and about a foot deep. The cleat is 18 inches wide and has about 6 anchor screws evenly spaced sunk into the wall. The difference with a shelf is that a shelf does not have sides and so the tendency to slant forward is very high and would happen with just a cleat and a board. If I were to do a shelf, I would put wood brackets on the sides so when the shelf is on the wall, it won't slant forward because those wood brackets will prevent that. I think doing it this way you can use the cleat but otherwise I wouldn't do it. Even using the side brackets the shelf with a cleat will stick out some from the wall, just a bit, because of the cleat thickness. That means you'd have to adjust the brackets somehow to level the shelf so it hangs properly. I hope this all makes sense to you. Good luck.

question: I need two door bells. Will the chime work with two and can I purchase a second doorbell?
answer: check out ITEM 5 BELOW.... Functions Instruction 1.Door Chime Operation Press the push button on the Transmitter unit once, it sends a wireless signal to the Receiver which will sound. The sound will stop as soon as the melody ends. For repeat sound, press the button again.Hold the button in will NOT repeat the sound. 2.Melody Selection There is a melody selector located at right on the back of the door chime. Press the selector to change different melody. 3.Sound and Flash There is a switch at left on the back of the Receiver. Slide the switch to the left position, the Receiver will work only with sound; slide to the middle position, only LED flash; slide to the right position, sound and LED flash. 4.Volume Adjustment There is a volume button between melody selector and sound-and-flash switch. Press it to adjust the sound volume to be high, medium and low. 5.Auto-learning Code Button There is an auto-learning code button at side of the receiver. If user wants an additional Transmitter to work with the Receiver, he or she needs to press the auto-learning code button once and the Transmitter can work with the Receiver. 6.Nameplate There is a nameplate position on the Transmitter.

question: can the low heat temp be set below 55 degrees?
answer: Unfortunately not. They made a mistake and didn't even make it an "installer" option to lower it below 55. They try to give a technical argument that it prevents the possibility of condensation damaging the heat exchanger in your furnace. That is B.S., but even so, the user should have the ability to do it if that doesn't apply in their particular case. There is a work-around where you can intentionally un-calibrate the thermostat to actually be 48 degrees when it "reads" 55 on the display. However, this is not very practical if you have other people using the thermostat that are not aware of this intentional mis-calibration. My solution for the vacation home in Tahoe was to use the Honeywell Z-wave thermostat. They allow you to set it down to 40 degrees. It's not as well integrated with the Nexia system that I'm using, but I am able to remotely control it in the way I need. Good luck.

question: For two bath condo and laundry room which one do I need
answer: I would suggest that you read the Steibel Eltron literature to choose the unit (there is a sizing chart), and discuss the specifications with your plumber and electrician. A major consideration is the electrical service. You will need to plan on the electrical service installation to be done by an electrician. None of the units are just plug into the wall sort of thing. It is possible that your current panel may not handle the required service. the cost of the electric install and any upgrades needs to be considered. That said, we've had the Tempra 24 Plus in service for 3-years now and it is excellent meeting the needs for unlimited hot water at precise temperature for a 3-bedroom house. Do I want somebody to turn on the washing machine while I'm in the shower? No, but aside from that pressure drop and then lowered flow from opeing too many faucets at once, the hot water tempertures are maintained. Working well for us since we have variable inflow temperatures to the hot water heater since we run wood fired hot water based hydronic heating for the house. The input water temperature to the hot water heater ranges from 60-degrees to 112-degrees. The digitally controlled Tempra 24 Plus has three heating element chambers that kick on as needed to provide water at the temperature setting that we choose to set at 115. Very efficient even though it is electric since it only uses as much energy as need to reach the setpoint.

question: My FocusPro thermostat communicates with an EIM (THM5320R) first, and I have three of these pairs. Do I need one gateway (THM6000R) for each EIM?
answer: One gateway (THM6000R) can handle up to four EIMs (THM5320R). The EIMs have been paired previously with your thermostats (in this case, the FocusPro series). Now all you need to do is to pair the gateway with each of the EIMs individually. You press the Connect button on the EIM first, once the EIM green light starts to flash, press the bottom of the gateway, and the green RedLink light on the gateway will start flashing. Once that becomes solid, the pairing with that particular EIM is done. You can press the Connect button on the EIM now to exit the pairing mode of that EIM. You may then repeat this step for each of your EIMs until all are paired. At this point, you may connect your gateway to the internet router or switch, and its Internet light will start flashing, first in amber color, then in green. You should then proceed to set up the Honeywell account online to add the device (your gateway) and input the MAC ID and the MAC CRC when prompted. Once the device is accepted, the Internet flashing green light will turn solid green and you are all set. You should then see all your thermostats on your app.

question: what else do i need such as bronze colored drain trim?
answer: If for new construction, you will need a waste and overflow rough in kit for under the under the tub. You will also need the waste and overflow trim, but this finish does not match oil rubbed bronze drains. It is a more gold color than traditional oil rubbed or venetian bronze drains. Jaclo makes one that does match but it is not budget friendly. Consider using a white drain trim kit if your tub is white. If you are having a building inspection know that the rough in valve does not have stops on them. Stops are required by law in many counties across the country. Stops allow you to 5urn off water at the fixture and not at the main to your house. Lastly, do not use any cleaners on this finish. You will void the warranty and destroy the finish over time. Use only car wash or other mild products. If you would spray the cleaner directly on the hood of your car then you can use it on the tub shower trim.

question: Is this light fixture dusk to dawn?
answer: There is an option from Dusk To Dawn, in fact the front and back of the box mentions it. If you want the Dusk to Dawn option you must enter 'Manual Mode'. Manual Mode only works 'AT NIGHT' because daylight returns the sensor to AUTO. Flip the light switch off for one second then back on to toggle between AUTO and MANUAL MODE. Auto Mode - On time 1- 5 - 10 Minutes (Motion sensor) Manual Mode - On time (To Dawn) *Resets to Auto Mode at Dawn* Note: When first turned on wait about 1 1/2 minutes for the circuitry to calibrate.

question: Since the pump isnt needed daily, its easy to forget about. Is there anything I need to check regularly (quarterly/yearly) to ensure the pump is still working?
answer: As with all backup systems of any kind, you should occasionally check its operation. I check mine about every 6 months, especially in early spring when most of my water starts to come in to the sump pump. All I do is unplug the main sump pump and wait to make sure the basepump kicks on. If there is no water coming into the sump, I have to run a garden hose into the sump to test it. The first year I had it, one of my tests failed because I must have not clamped the float down tight enough and the float got caught on the side of the sump wall and wouldn't raise but that was my fault for not tightening down the clamp enough. Thats why its always good to test any backup, no matter what it is.

question: Will it hold Duo Fast 5012C 20 gauge 3/8 inch staples with 1/2 crown?
answer: I looked and measured. This can hold staples NO WIDER than 3/16ths inch. It can hold staples NO LONGER than 9/16ths inch. They are flat topped, not "crowned" --that is, the top of the staple is not for wire or cable, is is flat. The channel in which the staples travel is also flat. If you tried to use cable staples it would jam. You can use staples that are less than 9/16ths long, but they must remain 3/16ths wide. That size serves well for carpet and very, very light construction. I strongly discourage use of wider staples. Even 1/4 inch might be too tight. 1/2 inch wide is utterly out of the question. ---

question: What is the current draw with no load (vampire current, I think they call it)?
answer: If the charger was 5 years old, you might attribute about 2.5W to 'vampire'. New charger blocks have effectively cut the loss to <.5W. This is advertised as "Smart chip recognizes and optimizes the charging requirements of individual devices" ... most any power supply logic chip sizing amperage to specific device would switch off current flow to the primary coil, if no device detected. At that point, the chip power draw would be >.01W. If you assume worst case that it draws say max 1W, the annual cost on the electric bill would be about $1.

question: Is it easy to install?
answer: Absolutely. All shower heads are as long as the plumbing is already in place. Remove the old head first. You might need an adjustable wrench to loosen the nut. Use an old rag or cloth between the jaws to keep from damaging the old and new heads. Remove any old plumbing tape thread around the threads of the supply coming from the wall. Apply new plumbing tape (very cheap and very necessary to prevent leaks.) Couple of wraps around the pipe should do it. Screw the new shower head on using the cloth with the adjustable wrench to tighten. Do not over tighten, just snug it up good. You're done. Take a shower. The bracket is part of the whole set so nothing extra. My very girly, 49 yo sister-in-law installed it by herself.

answer: You don't mention how wide or deep the crack is but... I wouldn't apply this thicker than 1/4" to 1/3" at any one time. So if the crack is deeper than that mix up enough filler to fill to that depth using the edge of a putty knife to push it into the bottom of the crack. Let it cure and then apply another layer. Repeat until the crack is filled. After the final layer has cured, sand off the excess. This assumes of course that the crack is not still growing larger.

question: Have multiple cracks on a hilly long driveway. Any idea on methods of pouring or sraying?
answer: Same situation I faced -long and hilly-. 1st use a good pressure washer to open and get read of all loosed material. Don't be afraid if you see that most of your pavement is going away... is worth to clean well. For filling, this product will only help on less than 1"cracks. For wider or potholes, you need to use patch ready mixes (like stone grade crack fillers) sold at Home Depot or Lowes and for medium size, a bulky crack filler material (i.e. Latex-ite Trowel Patch). I had to do it throughout the summer and let good time for drying. Most cracks re-appeared smaller and then, I had to filled them again. I finally covered with a high quality driver sealer and is so far, working good. Finally, it is a lot of work! think twice if you dont want to use professionals but they won't probably do it as good as you when properly repaired.

question: I have an Allistar model ARD 11A with Pulsar receiver. That's about all I know about it. Will this remote work? What are dips?
answer: Not familiar with the ARD 11A perse, but that shouldn't matter as that is the garage door opener itself. The Pulsar Receiver is what receives the signal from the transmitter (the remote). So there are a couple things you need to know that I can't tell from your info. Pulsar makes several different receivers. The newer ones for Allistar door openers are called MVP (they have the logo right on the unit) if this is what you have it will be a learning unit (I,e, one that reads the code from your remote). They do not have dip switches there is a simple procedure to setting the remote up with a number and then pushing a button on the receiver to have it learn the code its transmitting. DIP switches come in several forms but in general are just a row of little manual switches (some with two positions up or down referred to as + or - usually, or three position up down or middle +.-,0) regardless these are switches that you set in a pattern of your choice on both the receiver and the remote so they are coded the same and the receiver will recognize the remote. The newer learning units do not use these. This remote does not have dip switches but can work with a DIP switch type receiver if you set the DIP switches in the receiver first then follow the programing steps with this remote. None of this matters if you receiver is not one that is operating on 318 Mghz which this remote uses. That is the primary question if they don't work on the same "wavelength" they can't talk to each other. The Pulsar unit should day on it somewhere on the back what frequency it is. I do think that 318 is typical for allistar but not certain. Worst case is you have to get this remote and buy a new MVP receiver as well. Hope this helps.

question: The unit came with a hexagonal looking black plastic stick that is around 4 inches long... what is the purpose of this? The manual doesn't mention it
answer: That is the Lockout Pencil. It is the tool to lock or unlock the temperature. Here is the info from the manual on how to use it: ACTIVATION OF LOCKOUT FEATURE 1. Adjust the temperature set knob to the desired tip temperature. 2. Apply the Lockout Pencil to the ESD symbol on the front panel until the LED starts slowly (5 Hz) blinking Red. Remove the Lockout Pencil within 2.5 seconds and the temperature setting will be Locked in. The indicator LED will be Red and turning the temperature set knob will have no effect on the tip temperature. 3. Reverse the lockout by applying the Lockout Pencil to the ESD symbol until the LED is slowly blinking Red. Remove the Lockout Pencil within 2.5 seconds and the temperature set knob will function normally and the indicator LED will be Green. Note: If the Temperature Set Knob has been adjusted during the Locked Mode, the station will control to the new set point, once the Lockout feature has been disabled.

question: Has anyone had this jam? I used it once, shot about 50 nails and now it wouldn't shoot a nail. There is no nail jammed. Help?
answer: Yes unfortunately it jams quite frequently especially if it is held upside down. I ran into your problem after about 4 brad nails. If there isn't a visible nail jammed then there is a problem with the steel "hammer" that goes up and down to shoot each nail off of the "stack" you load. If you pull the cover back as if you were loading new nails you'll see all the way to the front where each nail is supposed to go down into the point and eventually the wood a "stainless steel" flat piece. This "stainless or silver" steel piece was what stopped the nail gun shooting in my case...it failed with the CPO reconditioned model and I had to take it to a Bostitch authorized repair shop to get it replaced. In the meanwhile I purchased a new one and never had the problem. Its frustrating but its nothing they said I could fix and Bostitch probably overlooked when they were "reconditioning" the nail gun. Good luck!

question: I would like to have two of these installed in two attic rooms, so the bottoms would show. Could they be covered with a louvered grill and be okay?
answer: I'll try and break the tie. Its an electric fan mounted in a heavy aluminum base (I dont think the pictures do them justice, these things are pretty big) that requires sunlight to shine on one side in order to work. IMO it doesnt really make any more noise than any other fan that moves a similar amount of air, my fridge is way louder. You would wind up with a 12" or so circular hole in the roof that the fan is fastened to the outside of; you would need to put some sort of grill over the inside of it to keep fingers out of the spinning blades. It probably would not amputate a finger but could easily make a nasty cut. Plus its not the prettiest thing on earth to look at. You will also need a substantial source of air into the room otherwise you will be creating a suction. If the two rooms are connected you could swap the wires on the motor of one of them (would require some electronics skilz) and have one suck and the other blow and get a draft through the area. You will also need to provide a way to close it off completely in winter to avoid letting cold in. You could put a switch on it in conjunction with the closing mechanism so it doesnt run when closed. Additionally roof vents (powered or not) are not as insect proof as window screens, the openings are bigger. Might be a consideration for inhabited areas.

question: the two batery is incluided?
answer: Yes it has two batteries. The -21 or -22 sets should include two 4.0Ah batteries. If not than don't get it. I have this same set. Had for almost two years and it's darn good. Awesome tool that surprises me every time i use. I drilled through a 4x4 with ease. Hot knife through butter. Impact driver has plenty of power too. Batteries charge fast. I have yet to use a full 4.0Ah battery load. Just never needed it. Plenty of power and a really great electronic battery control system that protects the battery and the tool. Others couldn't make that claim when i bought mine. You can Compare milwaukee tools and read up on the specifications at http://www.milwaukeetool.com/compare-products?skus=2691-22&skus=2697-22 A 5.0Ah battery is planned to be released very soon. For home use only the 3.0Ah battery is more than enough. I would suggest that you compare prices before you buy. Some times you can get great deals here and some times you get great deals on Ebay. Sometimes buying the parts individually can be cheaper. The price you list is a great price but check anyhow. It ain't going away soon - you got time to check. Milwaukee Tools are (typically) Guaranteed for 5 years. Milwaukee batteries vary, 3.0Ah 2 yrs warranty and the 4.0Ah is 3 yrs. Register your tools at https://www1.milwaukeetool.com/HeavyDutyClub/Join.aspx you can have a safe place to store and recall you tool information to provide the insurance company or the police or for your own records in case you need it. Milwaukee will stand by their tools. They have for years. I've used Milwaukee in industrial applications for decades and they never ever let me down. Since you have two batteries Might want to consider the Fuyel version for impact wrenches too. Beats the heck out running air hoses and air compressor worries. But you need to be the judge for yourself what you'll accept. I have the 2763 and the Fuel saw. They work! The Fuel model is typically more expensive by almost up to $100 more. Unless you can get a really great deal on a "new set" priced within $75 of the non-fuel or you DON'T plan to use it everyday for work "i would not recommend buying the fuel version". Price and Use are the only real Driving Differences between the two types for the homeowner experience. Everyday Work -- Get The Fuel Version - You wont regret it. The drill driver with hammer function is the only drill driver i would recommend, Fuel or Non-Fuel versions - get the Hammer Drill Type! Never know when you'll need it and it isn't that much more. The Fuel drill Driver is lighter, stronger and the motor vent is on the sides of the back handle verses the non-fuel model which has the vents out the back of the handle so if you press on the back of the handle while drilling you could block the motor vent and damage the motor over time. Sure hope this helps.

answer: sure - a pool table is heavy - it would compress the foam and in a very short period of time - the compressions would actually hold the table in place... (i.e. it would be harder to move it because you'd have to lift it up out of the indentations. You would never be able to slide it out...) I have my elliptical on the same type of foam - just not as pretty as the wood colored mats - and its not that noticeable - unless you want to move the item at a later date... once indented to that degree over time - I dont think it will ever float back up. I use the pretty wood colored mats in my main room - so I can hang out on the floor an be comfortable. They're great!

question: How do you step onto this platform from the ladder step?
answer: Once in place, the platform is designed to fold into the ladder which allows you to use it as a normal step. To use the platform, you go up the ladder to the first rung after the platform and then use your foot to flip the platform out. You can then step onto the platform. To flip the platform out of the way again, you just step up the next rung again and use your foot to flip the platform out of the way again. This allows you to step right past the platform on the way down. There's a vg video on this at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=raQtR9BVjV0

question: I have put in the code, and closed the cover, but we are having great difficulty opening the cover, and getting to the keypad panel, any suggestions?

question: Is this acrylic gloss? And does this work on plastic surfaces?
answer: I always buy gloss. I am not aware if it comes in satin or matte finishes. There are so many different types of plastics that I cannot say that it works on "all" plastics. I have sprayed it over THIN washes of acrylic artists' paint on canvas and other materials. I have had problems with spraying this over over acrylic clear sprays, like Krylon Crystal Clear. Sometimes the paint surface buckles. I have sprayed it over DRY gold and metal leaf with good results. It also seems to work over DRY gold size, a type of varnish. I have also tried it on fiberglass furniture with high gloss finishes. Sometimes it will not take on this type of surface. I have also sprayed it on small pieces of metal jewelry (but usually prefer not to do this). Hope this helps. You should probably experiment in scraps of different types of plastic.

question: I bought a coaxial splitter and the cable image looked snowy. Would I have the same problem with the switch?
answer: Its possible, it depends on how well the item is made really and where the problem lies. My problem with this item was because I think the back metal was touching the internal wires by accident. If the splitter serves no other purpose for you, you could try doing the same (get to the insides) to see if this is the problem, or there is something else wrong inside the unit. If all the cables work without the splitter, then it does sound like it is the splitter somehow, but there is no real guarantee that a different online product will be more successful. Might try a store where you can get a return maybe? Also note that a splitter is not the same as a switch. A splitter sends the same cable data to multiple units while a switch selectively merges different cables into 1.

question: I have 60 SF of concrete countertops to fabricate and then use this tool to finish, shiny. Will the pads in this package last for that SF?
answer: Barry if you use the water I don't see any problem. I have done about 60 SF of counter top and about 30 LF of 4" edge. From the appearance and feel of the pads they should easily do another job probably several more. I started out using the cup wheel to aggressivly get down to the aggregate - after doing about half of the top I started using the 50 grit pad as it is easier to control the depth and not nearly as aggressive. I have some pictures of each stage if you are interested. A word of caution - depending on how you plan to seal and finish your tops I would caution you about going beyond the 200 grit. Remember you MUST seal concrete or it will stain badly with spills - grease etc. I'm using a water based acrylic sealer which can be applied even after 800 - 1000 grit polishing. If you haven't already poured your tops make sure you use a good concrete mix. I used the big box 4000 PSI mix and added about 12 % portland type II cement to each bag. That gives you a denser concrete that is easier to finish and slightly more impervious top. I'll gladly answer any additional questions.

question: Anyone else have to connect two hot and two neut 12 gauge wires to the thin wires that came with this outlet? How did you do it?
answer: Turn the power off and twist the two hots together, twist the two neutrals together, and wire nut the leads off the outlet to the twisted wires. The little orange wire nuts won't be big enough, so you will have to get different wire nuts. The neutral could still have a load on it, if it is shared with another circuit, so you might be better off hiring an electrician to change it out for you.

question: the specs are bleak does it have a 3 jaw chuck like the picture? and a live center? also is a 4 jaw chuck available for this item?
answer: The specs ARE bleak! Yes, it comes with a 3 jaw chuck as in the picture and a live center. A 4 jaw chuck is available. Oddly it comes with NO cutting tools -- but other than that, everything is there. In fact, there are so many of these machines in the U.S. market now and all of them made in the same factory in Shanghai, that there is virtually NO accessory that would make any sense that you can't buy. Search for 'little machine shop' -- you'll find a company that carries virtually all of it. I'm trying to think of a sensible small lathe accessory that you couldn't find for these machines -- I REALLY don't know what it would be. You can get steady and carriage rests, larger chucks, faceplate and dogs, collets, I have heard of a toolpost grinder but haven't seen that, various sorts of tool posts, an adapter to use it as a milling machine, metal gears to replace the plastic ones, metal knobs (same deal) ... You get the picture.

question: What is the difference between 18 gauge brad nailer and 16 gauge finishing nailer? I need to install trim, build bookcase and install decking floor
answer: Brad nails are formed from a fine 18 gauge wire, while finish nails are made from heavier 16 or 15 gauge wire. Finish nails are the correct choice for fastening larger crown and baseboard trim, brad nails are used to install smaller trim to help prevent splitting and to promote a cleaner looking job with less touch-up work after the nailing is done.

question: Can I use this product to patch hairline cracks in an old cement laundry sink?
answer: I never tried to do that, but I don't think it would be too good for that since it is mostly relatively coarse sand and the like which would not easily squeeze into a fine crack. Even Portland cement, which is finer may not penetrate well enough, though you might try that, hoping to preserve to some degree the appearance of your sink. But if looks aren,t too important perhaps clear liquid epoxy would seal better, or even a liquid super glue. Also, I suppose that you could later scour the "glaze" of glue off of the surface with scouring powder and elbow grease. The method would be to use as little glue as possible,yet to try to "rub" it into the crack.

question: minimum cfm requirements
answer: Here is the answer from the Paslode site. As you will see, it depends upon the number of nails driven per minute. The F350S is a stick nailer not a coil nailer, so the nail magazine must be reloaded about every 75 nails. If you were nailing off flooring or decking, the rate of fire would be much higher than just building walls where the gun must be moved to a new joint location. 13. What size air compressor do I need? You can use the following formula to figure out the size air compressor you need. The Number of Tools being used X the Number of Nails each tool will drive per minute X 1.2 X the Amount of Air per Shot (SCFM) at the operating pressure. This number is found on the chart in the tool schematic and parts list provided with the nailer. For example, if you have two F-350S tools each driving 20 nails per minute with the compressor set at 90 PSI you get: 2 X 20 X 1.2 X .082 = 3.95. The compressor needs to deliver 3.95 CFM at 90 PSI. If you operate the tool at 120 PSI at the same rate the number will be higher: 2 X 20 X 1.2 X .108 = 5.2 CFM. When selecting an air compressor be aware that as the air pressure (PSI) increases, the delivery rate (CFM) goes down. Most compressors will rate the CFM at 50 PSI and at 100 PSI.

question: I've replaced my bulb with one of these but it doesn't work and now I can't remove it. Anyone else have this problem or know how I can remove it?
answer: One reason these might stick is due to excessive heat. Make sure the bulb and fixture is all the way cooled down before you wrestle with it. Expect to have to give it a good twist for it to release, the heat can almost weld it into place. Since the bulb is dead, don't worry about touching the glass. But don't touch the glass on new bulbs! Because they get super hot, any amount of oil from your fingers will kill them within a short amount of use. Also, there are 2 different kinds of these bulbs, one kind twist locks in and another just plugs straight in. If you push the twist lock bulbs into the plugs they will jam. You can work them loose with jiggling or crush the glass with pliers and pull out the pieces. It's not elegant but it's the only way to free the prongs. Hope this helps.

question: Does this unit provide protection for every circuit in your panel or does it only protect a limited number (e.g. 2) of the home circuits?
answer: The installation of the unit uses two adjacent breaker positions. Because of the design of breaker panels, two adjacent breaker slots places the surge protector across both of the utility poles of a two phase system which most homes have. Any incoming surge on any circuit in the panel will be "seen" by the protector since they are all connected to it, so therefore it works for surges in the entire home. Keep in mind however that surges can be generated from within the home and therefore sensitive electronics may also need to be protected by additional surge suppression equipment. Internally generated surges can wreak havoc on equipment before the surge reaches the Levitron system but external surges will be suppressed within the limits of the unit, before entering the house.

question: Does it detect radiation from radon gas?
answer: Radiation exposure from radon is indirect. Radon has a short half-life (4 days) and decays into other solid particulate radium-series radioactive nuclides. These radioactive particles are inhaled and remain lodged in the lungs, causing continued exposure. So in theory, the sticker should detect this radiation, but in my opinion the sticker is not a good choice for use against radiation from radon gas since most of the radiation is released in the lungs and may not be detected by the sticker which is outside of the body. My source is Wikipedia, so consider this information to be "opinion" only.

question: can I use this sander for polishing cars?

Additionally this sander is a 6 hole vacuum unit and placing a polishing bonnet over the intake might cause the sander to overheat. question: diameter
answer: diameter [dahy-am-i-ter] noun 1. Geometry . a. a straight line passing through the center of a circle or sphere and meeting the circumference or surface at each end. b. a straight line passing from side to side of any figure or body, through its center. 2. the length of such a line. 3. the width of a circular or cylindrical object. Origin: 1350-1400; Middle English diametre < Old French < Latin diametros < Greek dimetros diagonal, diameter, equivalent to dia- dia- + -metros, derivative of mtron meter1 Can be confused: circumference, diameter, radius, tangent. question: Does this work for reverse-threaded applications?
answer: I don't know why their customer service told Buck that info. In his review, he described the correct way to reverse it so that it does work for reverse-threaded applications. Reversing the head is the proper way to adjust the wrench to torque left-handed threads. The torque mechanism only works in one direction - clockwise is the default direction. Some wrenches have a push-through drive to get bi-directional torquing, but this one has a reversible head (some wrenches can't be reversed at all). It's not a big deal to reverse it. Doing so essentially "turns the wrench around" so that it will torque in a counter-clockwise direction. A "reversible ratchet head" feature is not the same as a "reversible ratchet" feature, and their product features clearly state it has a reversible head. Simply reversing the ratchet mechanism with the toggle only allows you to ratchet in both directions - it does not provide for torquing in the reverse direction.

question: What would the largest diameter rod that would fit in the hook? I have a 1.25 inch diameter road that I would be hanging the hoist from and was wondering if the hook will fit.
answer: No, it won't work. the inside diameter of the hook is just under 1". Probably 15/16". However, there is enough room to swap out the hooks for larger ones. the eye of the hook is pinned with a bolt. Remove the bolt and go a size up. The existing hook eye has about 1/8" clearance one each side of it with the bolt in place. so, you should be able to go up a size or maybe 2. ... or just use a 15/16" rod and shoot a smaller elk (deer, bear, rabbit, whatever). Hope this helps.

question: Sounds like the Stihl MS180C is too weak (32cc). Would it work just for a trial run? What 20" (but not too $$$) saw is recommended?

question: Sorry, if this is dumb, but when you use this sharpener, does it leave little bits of metal?

The amount of iron filings is dependent upon the size of the blade, how dull it was, and the number of blades you sharpen in any given setting. question: I am hooking the dust outlet to a shop vac and am getting shocked. How do you recommend avoiding this?
answer: What you are experiencing, Peter, is static electricity. Basically you have tiny particles carrying a charge, rubbing against a surface, building a charge by friction. A friend of mine touched a metal piece of furniture behind our shop vac, and got a nice small shock - and that was in Austin, which is not too dry. My experience with static electricity is that it is worst in dry and cold places, wintertime being it. Alas, in theory there should be a way to ground, but I have little experience, let me see... Aha, searching the internet for shop vac static discharge there are several suggestions - I am not allowed to post links here, so you'll have to search by yourself.

question: Will the Fantech DBF 4XL Dryer Booster Kit w/FG 4XL Fan with for a gas dryer?
answer: I am personally using it with an electric dryer but I see no reason why it wouldn't work for a gas model. It is operated by pressure differential rather than current sensing, it is all metal construction so even if the gas exhaust is hotter it should be OK. The directions say it should be a least 15 feet of duct length away from the dryer anyway. I guess it might draw hotter air into the duct but you should make sure the ducts are well cleaned out when you install it. I'm very satisfied the dryer works faster, runs quieter and we do not get lint accumulating around the duct connection at the back of the machine. You might also check with your dryer manufacturer in case they have any concerns.

question: can it detect levels of 20,30 or 40 ppm of CO? I know alot can only detect 70 ppm of CO or above...but I'm concerned of a small CO leak of below 70.
answer: This unit probably detects CO at less than 30 ppm, but is not allowed to display that level unless a button is pushed. In this case, the peak level the alarm detected since last reset is what will show, not the current ambient level. From 30 to 70 ppm, the display can show the ambient level, but the alarm will not sound until it's been in that range for 30 days, as mentioned. At 70 ppm, the alarm is not to sound for at least an hour, and no more than 4 hours. That's UL requirements, which most codes across the US adhere to.

question: I have a Keystoker Stove the gear motor is Merkle-Korff 4509UI-040 is this it? This is a coal stove not a Pellet stove.
answer: Tough to be really certain without more info. Most of these motors will mount up okay, but they differ in rotation speed, output shaft size, rotation direction (this is easily reversed, though), output torque, constant -vs- intermittent duty... See if you can get some more info from the Keystoker site on the motor specifications. Most important are rotational speed and output shaft size. Pellet stoves need different gearmotors than coal burners, and they can differ by function, too. You really need more info before you can be sure. 'Course, at this low price, you can always try it and see; if it doesn't fit, return it and try again.

question: will this work on a 3200 hd lincoln welder ?

I cant remember if it is a 3 pin or a 4 pin plug. You will need to hook these wires inside under the hood where the existing wire feed motor is located. I hooked jumper wires inside and ran them to the outside and installed but connectors on these wires and also the wires that the 3 or 4 pin connector was attached to. question: Can The Compressor Be used with Other Spray Guns Like this One ? http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00B... I read in a Few Revies that it DOES NOT Paint Ceiling Properly, One reviewer stated that you need an "airless spray gun" See Post here...

The reason being, the (power unit) compressor and the supplied gun are designed to work only with one another. If you've notice, the hose size on the 'HomeRight C800863' spray gun is comparatively smaller to the one of the Black and Decker gun. If you can find a reducer attachment for the Black and Decker power unit (compressor) to match the hose size of the 'HomeRight C800863' spray gun, then it might work. There's no guarantee though that it will. I haven't tried painting ceilings with this product yet; hence, I am unsure about your second question. I hope this helps!

question: Would this be suitable for 12v halogen setup, say in an RV or boat?
answer: I ordered mine for controlling LED strip arrays, but there is no reason why this product could not control any type of lighting that uses 12 VDC as long as the current limits are observed. From an initial contact with this firm, I understand this device has a maximum rating of 60 watts, which would equate to a current draw of 5 amps at 12 VDC. As an electronics technologist of long standing, I normally would not run any controlling device at any more than 80% of it's maximum load and would prefer to use only 60% of load maximum for long life. That would mean no more than about 35-40 watts in normal use. Hope this helps...

question: How do I prove to a TSA agent that this is approved for carry-on? There's no logo or info on that topic on the Wallet Ninja itself.
answer: A message from the manufacturer: While flying with our tools it is important to stay informed​​​. Though TSA does not provide an official approval certificate on any of its items, the only thing we can ensure is that our tools will fit inside of their guidelines. Most TSA Agents are uninformed themselves and will use a conservative approach​ when dealing with an unknown situation. It's a lot easier for them to say something is prohibited and move on than doing their due diligence. ​According to the official TSA website (http://www.tsa.gov/traveler-information/prohibited-items)​ Scissors - metal with pointed tips and blades shorter than 4 inches are allowed, but blades longer than 4 inches are prohibited NO OK Our tools meet the guidelines because 1. There are no actual "blades" or sharp edges, the entire unit is rounded off with soft corners 2. The entire tool isn't longer than 4 inches. Metal with pointed tips shorter than 4 inches is very much permitted. These 2 points alone should be enough to make your case. Remember, TSA Agents don't have these rules memorized, so it is important that you do!

question: is it normal for this dector to read 16 parts per million when i push the peak level button?
answer: Yes, 16 ppm is not an unusual reading. That is the peak reading, not the current reading. Many activities in a home can cause a short spike in CO levels, and 16 ppm for a short period is nothing to worry about. However, with this detector, you don't actually know how long you've been exposed to 16 ppm, and if it is a constant exposure, it exceeds EPA and WHO exposure limits for 24 hours.

question: Will this glue bond quarter-rounds to ceramic tile?

If you can help it perform the operation at night - the intention is to have it cure for as long as possible - undisturbed... Good luck.

question: Is the green tripper on and the red tripper off
answer: Ha Ha...that's the way it's SUPPOSED to be, but I found that the set I ordered worked just the opposite way. You can put one of them in place and see if it will trip on or off; I think you'll find that the red turns on and the green turns off. Also, they're visually a tad different, so once you figure out which is which, you'll be able to just "eyeball" them to distinguish them. Apparently, this mistake arises because different timers are engineered differently. This was a minor "head scratcher", at first. But with a little old-fashioned observation, investigation, and experimentation, it solves easily enough. Good luck!

question: What connectors are required to split this into 3 different lengths and with an appropriate driver is this tape capable of being dimmed from the switch controlling the driver?

And yes the driver itself would need to be cabable of dimming the leds or if you are simply are going to feed them with 12Volts then you can but a simple dimmer switch in-line with the common feed and dim the leds that way with no driver at all. I personally bought a controller from Custom Dynamics to make my LED strips strobe, dim, and change colors.

question: I bought this surge protector for my $3999.00 orig cost LCD tv. I had a surge and my TV blew out, no picture anymore. What is the warranty???
answer: You have to have completed the product registration and connected equipment Registration sections of the Surge Protector Registration card, signed it, and mailed it back to Globe Electric within 30 days of purchasing the surge protector. If you have not done that, there is no coverage under the limited lifetime warranty. If you have done that, then the surge protector light on the unit must not be showing "protected" anymore if a surge has truly occurred. If it has occurred and someone continues to use the surge protector anyway, the warranty is void. Finally, you have to submit a claim under the warranty within 15 days from when the surge occurred by sending them a copy or the original receipt for the surge protector purchase and a brief, written description of how the damage occurred. If no original receipt for purchase of this unit can be sent with claim, it will not be covered. Per the warranty, you can call their customer service (1-800-361-6761) to receive a Return Authorization number to send the surge protector back. That's just for making a claim for the surge protector. For any equipment connected to it, you must do all the above PLUS provide original purchase receipt for the damaged item, plus you must have made a claim for the damage to this item with whomever your power company is FIRST that they have denied to you IN WRITING, then you must have also made a claim through the product manufacturer SECOND that they have denied to you IN WRITING, and have also filed a claim through your homeowners or property insurance which they have denied to you IN WRITING. These actions must be completed when making a claim through them within 6 months of them issuing you a Return Authorization number. Then, they require the manufacturer of the damaged item or one of their authorized service providers to assess the damage and provide a written repair estimate & technical assessment, both of which needs to be sent to Globe within 6 months of you making the claim. Personally, if it was me, and I wanted quick resolution - I would just claim it through my homeowners/property insurance company, pay my deductible and be done with it.

question: Hello, does this item attach directly to my 7424xp polisher? 5/16-24 spindle thread. I would prefer the hook and loop style thanks.
answer: Easy part first: Yes, this model is a hook surface. Hard part: If your polisher has its anchor above the surface of the pad, i.e., you can see a screw holding it onto your spindle, then NO, it will not fit. This item is designed for orbital action that uses a "soft center", i.e., the cushioned material covers the entire pad surface. If this describes yours, it attaches underneath the dust skirt and requires a very thin-profile wrench (which should have come with your polisher.) Hope that helps. . .

question: How well would it work to paint over black plastic drums? These will be used to plant garden plants in so they will be out in the weather year around.
answer: As Krylon Fusion is advertised as "Bonds to Plastic" and "The no-prep, superbond paint for Plastic", I'd guess that it should work well on 'plastic drums' used for outdoor garden planters. I used Krylon Fusion to paint Trangia (polythene) fuel bottles (originally red) with green Fusion paint, even after online research told me "paint would not stick to polythene." I wanted to visually distinguish 'alcohol fuel bottles' from 'coleman fuel bottles'. Due to the polythene material, I allowed a longer (overnight) drying time, and applied two coats. I've been very pleased and impressed with the results, and the paint seems to be fairly resistant to fuel that spills onto the paint. I don't know your plastic drum composition, but I'd guess Krylon Fusion should work pretty well for your use and outdoor environment.

question: What is the maximum temperature raise difference?
answer: From my experience this is not a fixed value. If you set the flow switch at 0.5 GPM and the temperature at max, when you are flowing at a rate just above the 0.5 GPM you can a 90 Deg. F rise per the book. If you increase the flow rate above 0.5 Deg. F the temperature rise will decrease below 90 Deg. F. I have discovered that if I am using only the hot water and decrease the flow rate the temperature goes up. Note: 1 BUT will raise 1 pound of water 1 Deg. F; 1 gal = 8.34 pounds of water. Good luck with your unit, so times getting the proper balance between hot and cold water is a challenge.

question: Do the leds glow red or are they completely IR? Are they visible to the human eye?

You should buy the best camera you can then worry about the illumination after it is up and running. A high quality day/night camera with a very low lux rating (<0.001) can produce amazing images in very low light. The better the camera you start out with the more effective the illuminators will be.

question: i bought a leafblower and battries at a garage sale but the batteries die out after short length of time do you think it,s the battries or the leafbl
answer: If the blower does start up, but dies after a short period of time it more than likely is the batteries. Try one to start with. I had the same problem and it was the batteries. Leave it on the charger long enough to get a charge also. I think offhand it is about 2-3 hours to charge, but I usually leave it on the charger for a day or two. They are ni-cad batteries, and can and will develop a memory if not discharged completely. It made all the difference in the world to have the new battery. My old ones are about 6 years old and only hold the charge for a few minutes of blowing before dropping off to almost nothing.

question: If this stone so excellence, Could this totally replace 8000 grit japanese stone?
answer: It depends on how polished you want the tool to be. Obviously 1000 grit is not 8000 so if you want that refinement the answer is no. However, personally I used to use aluminum oxide sand paper on a 3/8" piece of glass to sharpen chisles, plane irons, gouges, etc. finishing at about 320 grit. To me it was good enough for bench chisels and carving tools. At 1000 grit, the diamond stone is way better and it cuts in a fraction of the time. I tend to want to be practical at the quality of a cutting edge and not at the expense of time. I can sharpen a bench chisel in about 5 minutes with the diamond stone. I can't come close to that with water stones. They are too slow for me.

question: Hi :-) Your murals are quite beautiful. I would like to place one on my exterior adobe wall. Do you think this is a possibility?
answer: Dear M. Ankney - I am just a consumer who purchased the dolphin paradise wall mural and put it in my daughters room on the wall. The mural is beautiful and we are very happy with it. However, any exposure to rain or water of any kind would ruin the mural. The glue is water soluble. For example - when we were installing the mural some of the color came off with just a few wipes of a damp cloth...maybe it was because the material was wet from the installation process. Also, if the exterior wall of your adobe has a very rough texture I think it may be difficult to install the mural without tearing it.

question: Can this detect X-Ray radiation?
answer: You are looking at a low-frequency EMF meter. It measures EMF from mains electrical devices and other (very low frequency) EMF sources. You can use this type of meter to check EMFs from mains electricity, power lines, high voltage lines, electrical installations, sub-stations and transformers, house wiring, domestic electrical appliances TVs, computers, office equipment, factory machinery, vehicles (cars, trains etc). This meter is not designed to measure ionizing radiation (x-rays and gamma rays), or radio-frequency / microwave radiation, unless specifically stated.

question: Does the dimmer on this switch work with dimmable LED or compact florescents?
answer: Well.... Sort of. I connected it to a ceiling fan with three 5w LED bulbs and it flickered. I then replaced just one of the bulbs with a conventional incandescent bulb and it worked fine. My guess is that there is a minimum load level that has to be there for it to work properly. A 15w load was apparently too small, but when I added a 25w incandescent bulb that increased the load, it worked fine. So if you have a load over 15 watts, it should work with dimmable LED bulbs. As for compact fluorescents, I have no experience there. I do know that the bulbs would have to be specifically labeled "dimmable" for you to even have a chance for it to work. I suspect that you'd still need a load greater than 15w like what I had to create with the LED bulbs. Hope this helps...

question: There are two versions. EA8 and EA8W. The EA8W has a neutral white LED. Do you/will you carry that one?
answer: It is a matter of personal taste, and of situational need. The EA8 is about 7% brighter than the EA8W, and has a slightly longer throw (beam distance). But the EA8W is better in foggy or rainy conditions because it does not cause as much light to be reflected back at the user, therefore providing better visibility under those conditions. And the EA8W provides (for many people) a more accurate color rendering, much like sunlight, while the EA8 is a brighter but colder light and tends (for many people) to cause colors to "wash out" a bit. I personally have the EA4 (4xAA), which is the "little brother" of the EA8, and so far I have not missed having the EA4W (neutral white) version.

question: changing rhe lightbulb: Can anyone tell me how to remove the glass bulb to change the lightbulb inside?
answer: I figured it out--for MY fan, anyway. The globe is held in place by three "tension clips" that hang down and press outward on the globe, to hold it in place. You have to firmly grasp the globe and wiggle it downward, ensuring you hang on to the thing positively, so you don't drop it. For someone a bit fearful, this might be a two person job, one to grasp the fan housing and hold it steady, the other to pull firmly on the globe and wriggle it free. If you do it once, you'll never forget! I put a flourescent candleabra bulb (it had a double base on it, the wide and the small--and my fan takes the small) and screwed that firmly into the fixture. I was 'just' able to fit the globe back on. It's probably the only thing that doesn't thrill me about this fan--otherwise, I like it.

question: Can the CFL bulbs be dimmed by the 99019 Remote Control. If not, are the CFL sockets compatible to incandescent light bulbs?
answer: Per Casablanca Fan, the Model 99019 Remote Control is their newest, best, and easiest to use control. This system controls four fan speeds in forward and full range light dimming. To better adapt to the changing world of light bulb technology, this control system features a CFL Auto-Detect feature that prohibits light dimming if non-dimming CFL bulbs are used in the fan. It also is our first control that eliminates dip switches and frequency interference through the use of Learning Code Synchronization. Similar to garage door programming, the fan and control are paired together when installed with a unique pairing code automatically. To increase flexibility, this control system can be used in Indoor to Damp location environments.

question: What wall thickness and thread type is required for 1-1/4" solid galv pipe used to drive this well point deeper than 3 ft (using drive coupler)?
answer: You must buy a drive cap and drive couplings. Since the drive cap gets pounded pretty good I used a short sacrificial nipple with the drive cap and threaded that into the drive coupling. question: Where is this made (i.e. Country of origin)? Thanks in advance.
answer: Not marked on Kit, but found this elsewhere: Most DeWalt power tools are now assembled in Mexico, China, or Taiwan from components manufactured in Mexico, China, Taiwan, the Czech Republic, Brazil, Korea, Japan, Thailand, or the USA. Before 1984, DeWalt power tools were manufactured in Canada, the USA, and the UK. In 1984, DeWalt's parent company acquired the woodworking and power tool assets of the German manufacturer ELU. After that acquisition, DeWalt routers and a few of their other power tools were manufactured at former ELU factories in Germany, Italy and Switzerland. Starting in roughly 2000, DeWalt gradually moved most of their power tool assembly plants to Mexico, China, and Taiwan. In April 2011, Stanley Black & Decker (DeWalt's current parent company) launched a line of hand tools under the DeWalt brand. Most of these hand tools are manufactured in China, Mexico, Taiwan or Thailand. A few hand tools (such as their retractable knife, tape measures and screwdrivers) are assembled in the USA from globally-sourced parts. As of January 2013, a few DeWalt power tools are still manufactured in Europe. The DWS520 track saw and certain compact SDS rotary hammers (e.g., D25313) are manufactured in the Czech Republic. The 3 HP DW625 plunge router is still manufactured in Italy.

question: Hi, anyone here has any idea how the Olight R40 compared to the Olight M22 WARRIOR (besides the extra 150 lumens)

The M22 has a very deep dish smooth reflector with slightly larger dia that beats the R40 in throw. The M22 is set up with tail switch and grip ring for "cigar grip" in handgun shooting. The M22 has more aggressive crenellations that are blackened stainless steel. The M22 head is designed with the most heat sink grooves of any flashlight I've ever seen. They get hot! The R40 must be new and Olight web site is down at the moment. Also you should know that the top lumen rating is only for like the first 6 min of use. The lumens are close enough it wont make a diff. Make your choice based on the features you need. I personally don't care for side buttons.

question: Can the shaft of this motor be spun mechanically to generate power out the back?
answer: Not really - the motor is geared the wrong way to do this. It's hard to tell from the picture, but the darker section from which the motor's shaft protrudes is actually a cylindrical gear box, and it is geared to give mechanical advantage to the motor behind it. You would have to spin the shaft with so much force that the power you got out of it would probably not be worth it. What you want is setup where that gear arrangement was reversed. Then a very little input would result in a productive output.

question: what would be the minimum measurement for a vanity for this sink?
answer: It depends on where you plan to position yor faucet with the bowl and what you find aesthetically pleasing. Personally, I would say 19" x 19" would be a minimum. It would allow for a bit of additional space around the edges, and you could position a faucet coming out of the wall instead of the vanity. Or if you want the faucet coming out of the vanity itself, allow additional room for that space. Of course, you could go bigger or smaller than this--bigger if you require space for toiletries; smaller if you are good with a "pedestal" look with the vanity smaller than the bowl radius. Keep in mind you need to account for the space needed for plumbing underneath, which will vary. Some people like the look of exposed plumbing, in which case the vanity will not need to be large enough to encase it. Others will want all of that covered. Your personal preferences will come into play with all of this. One thing to keep in mind is that this is a beautiful, substantial bowl, so even if you have a small vanity, it will have sculptural appeal. Hope that helps.

question: Will one bag of resin work for a 5600 Fleck unit? What's best advice for emptying old unit and refilling new product since thre are no directions?
answer: yes, one bag is plenty for this unit. You have to screw the meter/top off the top of the tank; it just screws/twists off like any bolt or cap. Then take out the long tube from the tank. The old resin will be kind of mushy and slimy mixed with water. I just dumped it into plastic bag that I had cut some small holes in the bottom to let the water out and the old resin stayed in the bag. Then rinse out the tank till its clean. To put the new resin in, I used a large funnel. If you can have two people it is better; one to hold and shake the funnel and one to pour the resin in. It is kind of sticky, but pours well. If you don't have a funnel you can make one by rolling up some heavy paper. It is almost impossible to pour the new resin into the hole without a funnel. You need to make sure you get the tube back into the tank before pouring in the new resin and you should tape the top of the tube so you don't get any resin in it while pouring it in. Good luck!

question: Does Lutron make a remote dimmer for LED lights?
answer: Lutron's "C*L Dimmer" Maestro line is made for use with dimmable LED and CFL bulbs (search model # MACL‑153M). Even though you're not *supposed* to use LED's with this, I would think that as long as you have 60W total worth of bulbs running through it, it will be fine. For example, I currently have 6 recessed can flood lights running on one of these switches...if I switch to 65W-equivalent LEDs that will be roughly 57W...pushing my luck, but I expect it will work (I realize this isn't very helpful until I test it...just saying if it controls a single 60W incandescent bulb just fine, it should theoretically run six 10+ watt dimmable LED bulbs just fine as well. Would be very curious to see if anyone has tried this out that can confirm they were using this model of the Lutron switch and not one of the C*L's.

question: How do I assemble it out of the box? This is my first air hammer and it doesn't tell me anything in the printed materials.
answer: The "tip" if you will is basically a quick (dis)connect attachment for the tips that came with it. Put that on and use the allen screws built into it to tighten it really good. Then you just grab it and slide it down towards the hammer itself, which allows you to insert the tips, then let go and they should be locked in. They won't be locked in tight, because otherwise the hammer isn't able to do it's job and move them, but you should be unable to pull them back out without sliding down the collar again.

question: does it have an indicator to let you know when to replace the filter?
answer: Yes, there IS an indicator for filter life...it's on the top of the unit between the faucet and the filter. BUT....it's not electronic, so there is no "light," per se. It's a mechanical indicator, under a lens, that moves slowly as water passes over it; when enough water has run through the filter, the indicator starts to show red, and when it's completely red, it's time to change the filter. The problem is that it's not electronic, which means that it has no actual light itself, but rather depends on reflection from light outside the filter. I found that while I could sometimes see it at night with the light over the sink turned on, it was much more reliably visible by shining a flashlight down into the little port.

question: For the R40, can the highest output level be activated with just one step (ie, one tap)??

question: Would this be compatible with an Advance RM-2S35-TP Ballast?
answer: Yes, it will work to light (2) F40T12, (2) F40T12/ES, (2) F30T12 or (2) F25T12 (Shoplites). Now as for the physical size of the 2 units The Advance Measures - (6 1/2"L x 2 3/8"W x 1 1/2"H) and the Robertson Measures - (9.44"L x 1.38"W x 1.16"H). So, what you would have to do is slide the one end in the slotted corner like the original one and then mark and drill a new hole in the sheet metal housing and attach the unit with the screw at this point. I have replaced many of this type of ballast with these Robertsons in this fashion. Very simple process to do. Takes and extra minute or two to drill a new hole. Hope this helps!

question: does this charger work on model # G0539 battery?
answer: First: I think that you are reading the serial number, not the model of the battery. Second: If you are asking about charging an 18v NiCad in this charger, the answer is No and yes. If it is a 130260001 (ordinary 18v) it will not fit. There needs to be an extra notch on the front right side of the shaft. AND if you do cut in that extra notch with a Dremel, it still will not charge. I guess that the charger senses the incorrect chemistry. BUT if it is an 18v Diehard (red release pads) 130279004 then the notch is there, it will fit in the charger and will charge properly. I have found that a 19.2v battery will fit into and drive my 18v drills and saws without any noticeable problem. Use that advice at your own discretion. Marty

question: Just why would you want these non-static in watch and computer work? I think I know but would like a bit more detailed answer than I know. :)

Generally speaking, all electronic work is done using ESD (electro-static-discharge) in mind. Google ESD for more info.

question: How well would this work on an Afghan in full show coat & approx. how long would it take to blow &brush him dry. Also would it work well for a Pem Corgi?
answer: I am not a professional groomer so you might want to check with one. Yes, I am sure it would work and assume you line brush when you dry? How long is a question I would be hard pressed to answer. I would think at least 45 mins. Yes,methinks it would work well on a Corgie coat but, again, drying always works best if you line brush. Do you show dogs? If not, line brushing is basically starting at the rear of the dog, holding up the coat with a brush so you get the undercoat so you are going against the lay of the coat. Continue on up the back of the neck or at least to the base of the neck. Then use the dryer so it blows with the lay of the top coat and brush towards the tail until dry. Hope that makes sense. Again, these dryers are great when a dog is blowing coat. I would bath my dogs, put them on a grooming table outside and blow and brush away all the dead undercoat. If course, you should use a grooming arm on the dog or have a person there to hold the dog.

question: What does the Equipment Interface Module do? And is it a requirement to run this thermostat?
answer: The Ecobee thermostat is a two piece unit: the control unit that you put in your hallway and the equipment interface module which you put in your cellar near the furnace. When you buy the thermostat, you get both pieces and you need to use them both. They connect by the cable that your original thermostat used to connect to your furnace and AC, so you don't need to run a new cable. You then connect your furnace and AC to the equipment interface module. Piece of cake, right? WRONG! This is a very flexible and complex unit, and can handle all sort of fancy systems, so you really need to know what you're doing to connect it. I have a separate furnace, AC compressor, and air handler (and a degree in electronics), and it took me about 5 hours with the furnace and air-handler schematics to figure out how to connect this thing. It turned out the original contractors who installed the AC and furnace wiring made mistakes; my old thermostat forgave them but the Ecobee wouldn't. That said...I love this unit. It was worth the time and expense.

question: is this saw a compound saw?

Just let it do the work and don't try to push it through even a 2 X 4 because you'll eat the motor bearings and then have a saw with one really bad Kerf. question: wil this light longer if i use higher capacity NiMh batteries such as eneloops?
answer: Yes, if you get sufficient sun exposure to fully charge the higher capacity battery. It takes six hours to fully charge the 1000MAH that comes with the N200, so a 1500MAH battery (MUST BE NiMH of the AA size) would likely take 9 hours of direct sunlight to fully charge. (In Winter I only get eight hours of light and six hours of 'direct' sunlight, here in Idaho. I wouldn't be benefited by a battery that large.) The thing is, that six hours of light at night is already enough in Winter (let's me burn the lamp from 4 or 5pm to 10 or 11pm) and MORE than enough in Summer (when the sun goes down at 10pm in Idaho), when you may need very little artificial light. So weigh the need for additional light against the cost. I might opt for a second bulb instead of a higher capacity battery. Two bulbs provide a solution that only requires six hours to charge and allows the choice of either longer run time or more light. And at the same time provides a back up unit.

question: Is the used 6120 master code set yet?
answer: The 6120 Electronic Combination Lock is shipped from the factory with a factory master code of 123456#. Instructions can be found here: http://www.sargentandgreenleaf.com/pdf/630-302_6120_op.pdf What I have found is that the codes are stored on the lock itself and not on the keypad. So, if you are only changing the keypad (e.g. in a case where the battery has corroded the contacts on the keypad), then your original codes can be used to open the lock. You can go to the Sargent & Greenleaf support website for further details: http://www.sargentandgreenleaf.com/global-contact.php I hope that this helps you. I have used 6120 locks on two safes in the house for the last 17 years, and they work fine. I had to replace one keypad when a leaking battery corroded the keypad contacts. It is great when you can still obtain a replacement after 17 years!

question: Do you sell a 4-wire 6uf+5uf+4.5uf ceiling fan capacitor?
answer: You can use a five wire capacitor for your four wire fan. All you have to do is connect the two wires on one end to the single wire hooked to your fan. Look at the schematic on the capacitor and you will see the two wires are actually connected inside the case, thus they are really a single wire split into two. Just twist them together and hook it up just like your bad capacitor is connected. Make sure to hook the other three wires up correctly. Look at the diagram and match the capacitance values with how the old one was wired. Do not simply go by the wire colors they may be different.

question: Can someone tell me how to open the battery compartment? I can see it. Just can't get it open.
answer: The battery compartment cover is the bottom part of the black grip on the power button side. At the top of the cover is an arrow (triangle) pointed downward. On the rib just below that arrow, press firmly and in the direction of the arrow at the same time. I put one thumb on the rib, the other thumb on the fingernail of the first thumb, and press hard. When the cover slides about 1/16" away from the top part of the grip, you can relax, lift the cover slightly from the bottom, and slide it off the rest of the way. You have to push so hard, the end of your thumb will hurt. You could lay a toothbrush handle across the rib and push on that. I ground that rib below the arrow most of the way down. I still have to press just as hard, but there is no pain!

question: How can you claim it replaces 80W Fluorescent (2x40W 4ft T-12 tubes) when the product brochure clearly states the 24 watt model replaces a SINGLE 40w
answer: The second page of the brochure was updated in Dec 2013 due to the direct comparison to Fluorescent performance. https://app.box.com/s/gn93fk3r9n32dzkpqblo. The new brochure page 2 image was uploaded to Amazon, but for some reason is not propagating. The LED lights are DIRECTIONAL compared to fluorescent, which is OMNIDIRECTIONAL. This means that all the lumens of the LEDs are going downward in a 120 degree beam, compared to fluorescent, which has more than 1/2 of the lamp lumens in an upward and sideward direction. The reflectors of most shop lights are not efficient in "bouncing" the light properly and many fixture lumens are as much as 50% less than the lamp lumens (fixture efficiency~40-60%). The LED fixture efficiency is 100%, as indicated on the LM79 test report. Also, fluorescents are optimal at 75degrees F and will drop as much as 20% with a 10 degree variation in ambient temperature, and will drop as much as 60% or more at freezing. The LED will maintain its efficacy throughout a wider operating temperature range, and in fact thrives in colder temperatures. As you stated in your "review", the light is as bright as 2x the single 40W fluorescent. That is why the brochure was updated and the claim is made.
