question: Can you plug more strands into one another?
answer: Yes you can. Where we camped several people had at least 2 strands connected together to extend the entire front of their awnings. Their awnings were twice as long as ours. Our awning is 15ft. and one strand worked just great. Several people throughout the campground used the easy up shelters with more than one shelter side by side and then several of these lights hanging from those which looked to be connected strand to strand. YES they are very bright with the 60watt bulb. We did use a lamp dimmer plug/extension cord sold at the local hardware store in order to dim brightness as needed. While it was at full brightness they did attract the flying small bugs that look like flying ants. Once dimmed they went away. They are very useful for finding your camper. They are not tacky or too bright. Half the campers used these ..some with clear globes or all one color. The spiral flourescent bulbs will not dim. We had to use the regular bulbs in order to use purchased dimmer switch. This was the end of August in SC USA/ Surfside beach.

question: My inlet temp is 44 degrees. I'm only concerned with using one shower. Will this supply 105 degrees at 1.75 GPM's?

At 44, you would be able to produce about 2.0 GPM Flow Rate. http://www.ecosmartus.com/products/electric-tankless/eco-18/#product-tab3 I agree with Cliff. I am on my Fourth Tankless: two gas, two electric. This is by far the best design. The internals, wiring size, simplicity, layout are impressive. Best Value for the $ that I can see. My last electric was aweful. A soon as the flow rate would drop in the head, the heater wouldn't kick on. The ECOSmart has a proprietary sensor that kicks the system on even with a low flow rate. That is a great feature, as all three of my other ones required at least 1.0+ GPM to kick on and stay on. Best wishes.

question: I have a very draft house, windows are leaking- its freezing in here all the time, I rent so am not going to redo the place, is this the best to use
answer: This is a good option for garage doors. I wouldn't use it on windows because you couldn't see out. The good old stand-by for leaking windows (besides moving) was clear heavy plastic, which comes in rolls at your hardware store, and either taping or stapling it over the window frame included. The other if you are handy is to make a wooden strip frame for the clear plastic and make a sort of makeshift "storm window" that you can insert inside the window frame. Then you can caulk around the frame to eliminate drafts coming in that way. Years ago when we lived in houses that didn't have the excellent insulated windows we now have, this is how we eliminated cold and drafts from windows. Especially, if we were short on money.

question: What does this mean: "For each gallon of clean water, only 2 gallons of water are wasted"? Where does the wasted water go? How is this economical?
answer: As D.R.Rowe said, the waste water goes down the drain. If the system is only used for drinking water, the waste is quite low because you only waste 2 gallons for every gallon you drink. This is just how RO systems work. The ratio is usually between 1:1 and 1:2, even for very large industrial RO systems. The "waste" water carries away the concentrated minerals and other things that can't pass through the membrane. Without this "waste" water, the membrane would become clogged in very short order. Instead, the waste water (usually called concentrate) flushes and carries away the blocked minerals and contaminants constantly as the system is operating. Keep in mind that the material blocked by the membrane has to go someplace! As for trying to use an RO system to provide your entire house's water supply, that would mean having a lot of waste as well as needing a very large RO system. What people usually do to deal with hard water buildup on fixtures and to also improve the operation of their dishwashers and clothes washers as well as make showers and toilets stay clean longer, etc., is to install a water softener to soften the water used in the house. The RO system is then installed after the softener to remove the sodium that a softener replaces calcium and magnesium with. That way, you get sodium (and other crud) - free drinking water. Your washing, bathing, and toilet water is "softened", but has high sodium in it so you don't want to drink it or cook with it, especially if anyone in the household is on a sodium-restricted diet. You install the water softener so that it does NOT soften your outdoor faucets. That way, you don't waste softened water on lawn and garden irrigation, etc. The sodium isn't good for your lawn or garden anyhow. If you install the softener and RO system yourself, you need to be aware of this and do the plumbing accordingly. If you have a plumber install the softener, they should already know this and install it correctly. They should also install the RO system after the softener so it starts out with softened water as its feed source. Doing this makes the membrane in the RO system last longer.

question: Hi, I have a Zoeller M98 1/2 HP 115v and I think 9.4 amps. Will this switch work with my pump? Or is it to big?
answer: I have been using the HC6000 for the last 6 months, the same thing basically but with two sensors to control when to start and stop pumping instead of the smarts to turn off the pump using a single sensor and current sensing like the HC8000. The HC8000 didn't work for me as it didn't sense when to stop pumping correctly and would only pump the pit out halfway before quitting. That being said, while it was pumping it was drawing ~850 Watts (measured with killawatt power meter) running my Utilitech 0.5 HP sump, pushing up about a 4 foot head over a 110 foot run. That works out to ~7.5 amps. Most of the stamps on all electronics that state current draw overstate the actual need, so I bet you will be safe with the Zoeller. BTW, I had a great experience with the vendor. I had to return the 8000 to get the 6000 and process was easy. I wish the 8000 had worked for me because I loved only having a single wire, but not for me. Something about my setup must have confused it's internals. . . good luck

question: Is it necessary to install an EXPANSION TANK for this hybrid electric water heater?
answer: The need for an expansion tank is based on the type of system. If you have a check valve, you have a closed system in your home. If you have a closed system, you should have an expansion tank. There are many good articles on the web as to why you need it. Mine was closed, and without an expansion tank. When I installed this heater, I added the expansion tank. Now my pressure is constant, and the flow is much quieter in the pipes. It also saves wear and tear on valves and faucets which used to squirt past the seals.

question: What is the power consumption? I do see the 115W rating but does this mean that while having it connected it will constantly be sucking up 115W ?
answer: No. It means the maximum load you can connect to the outlet on the base unit is 10 Amps (115 watts). The total power draw will depend on the loads (appliances, lamps, etc) that you have plugged into the outlet on the unit. When turned off, the base unit itself will likely draw only negligible power from the AC outlet. The whole point of this gizmo is to cut off the power draw from appliances such as TVs, VCRs or DVD players which constantly draw "standby power", even when you think they're turned off, as long as they're plugged in. This remote switch will essentially "unplug" anything connected to it when you press the remote, so there's no more "standby power" being drawn constantly.

question: Should I be concerned that if a large board of any significant weight is used with these, that they will eventually cause the table to warp?
answer: I have both the side and outfeed support on my saw all the time and I find them invaluable. There has never been an issue with the table warping or flexing. My side support does sag noticeably as you extend it from the table even when there is no load on it (must be the angle). If you adjust it for extended height it will be higher than the table as you push it in. What I do take a narrow board 2" wide and 20" long and clamp it to the inside of the side shelf support above the 2 rods. Pull the extension out to the distance desired. Set a level reaching from the table to the side support. Adjust the clamping of the board so that it is even with the table top across its entire length. Keep in mind that you can't hang a lot of weight on this. The outfeed support is sturdier and I have had no real trouble with the sagging. Again it isn't sized to support ripping long boards. I build a 36" outfeed table for my DeWalt that attaches to the outfeed bracket easily handles 8 foot boards. If you have the room to leave your saw set up on the stand, take a look at item 92051 on Rockler.com to make your saw mobile.

question: If this ladder is IA rated 300 lb, and my own weight is (for example) 310 lb, does it mean I cannot use this ladder? Thank you!
answer: Your question posed a need to do a little research on my part because I am about to "pull the trigger" on a combination ladder. So, you must first realize that there are two different, but complimentary sets of Federal Regulations concerning ladder capacity; the engineering/manufacturing ANSI Standard and the workplace safety OSHA Standard. I found the following excerpt regarding the ANSI Standard: "The most recent ANSI A14.1 and A14.2 standards only rate and have test procedures for 300 pound rated ladders. A new ANSI portable ladder standard for 375 pound rated ladders should be out later this year. The source standards for OSHA's portable ladder standards (1910.25 and 1910.26) are, however, ANSI A14.1-1968 and A14.2-1956, respectively. Any ladders designed in accordance with these previous ANSI standards are deemed to be in compliance with the OSHA standards. "Although ANSI has updated its standards since the 1968 and 1956 editions, OSHA has not. However, on April 10, 1990, OSHA published in the Federal Register, Vol. 55, No. 69, at 13360, a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking which proposes amending OSHA's standards for walking and working surfaces and personal protective equipment. OSHA's ladder standards, including 1910.25 and 1910.26, would be replaced by the new proposed standard 1910.23. A copy of the proposed ladder standard is enclosed. "Section 1910.23(c) of the proposed ladder standard reads as follows: (c) Design, construction, maintenance and inspection. (1) Portable ladders shall be capable of supporting without ultimate failure, the following loads: (i) Each non-self-supporting ladder: At least four times (4X) the maximum intended load applied or transmitted to the ladder in a downward and vertical direction when the ladder is placed at a 75 1/2 degree angle from the horizontal. (ii) Each self-supporting ladder: At least four times (4X) the maximum intended load in a fully opened position on a level surface." All of which would say that properly designed and manufactured step ladders under ANSI Standards meet their requirement to have been engineered to 4X the rated maximum working load. Someone answered previously that the working load is not just your weight but also adds the clothes, tools and items attached to the ladder to give one the total working load. So, your question leads to a number of answers which stem from the ANSI Standard for engineering of a step/extension ladder (and all other forms of ladders), Theoretically an A1 ladder is rated for 300lbs with an engineering margin that is many times that number. However other factors apply including the working load and the stability of the ladder (on varying surfaces, etc). For me I plan on acquiring an A1 and will watch my working load and stability closely during use. Hope this helps.

question: does this check a good or not good capacitor?
answer: It depends on what you mean by "good". It will measure the low frequency or DC capacitance and you can decide if the value is within what you consider the proper spec. However, it will not tell you if the capacitor can withstand the the rated voltage. It also will not tell you the leakage rate for the capacitor. To determine the leakage rate you will have to charge it to a specific voltage, measure the voltage before disconnecting it from the voltage source, and then measure it again some time later, using a voltmeter with a very high impedance front end, so that the act of measuring the voltage won't discharge the capacitor. It also won't tell you the capacitance as a function of frequency. I hope that this helps you.

question: Does this vacuum pick up water on the basement floor?
answer: yes, it would but absent a specific reason to use a HEPA vac to do that (eg: the water is full of asbestos) I would just use a cheap shop-vac .. the consumables (filters, etc.) are way to expensive for the Festool to use it as a general purpose vacuum. Credit to the clever Germans the HEPA filter is horizontal at the top so you could (in theory) fill the entire base of the unit with water and not get anything wet, whereas in a standard shop-vac you can only get a few inches before the filter gets soaked. The Festool is a good vac with a very specific purpose (like sanding drywall or lead paint indoors) .. for everything else there are better and cheaper alternatives.

question: If this light was to stay on, how many hours would it last?
answer: We took two of the lights with us to a night outing in Golden Gate Park and with fresh batteries the lights last a full five hours (a little before midnight, one light outlasted the other by about fifteen minutes). The light is not your conventional soft white light but a very bright and crisp light. It is the same light you see in oncoming headlights of newer cars. Great to play cards by, eat dinner or to sit around at night at a patio table. I keep two lamps in a living room book cabinet and they light the entire living room area if on by themselves. I also keep one on auto-light in the bathroom on a high shelf so that when you walk into the bathroom late at night the light goes on offering plenty of light and stays on thirty-seconds after you walk out. If you've a room with few electrical outlets or an area where electricity isn't available, these lamps are excellent. You can get the batteries (Size D) in bulk package from Radio Shack at very reasonable cost.

question: mydeck has been coated with that green copper coat a year ago will that be a problem
answer: Copper naphthenate is nothing new it has been around in exterior wood products for decks since the 80s. Cuprinol, Wittox-C, Osmose Cop-R-Nap were all products that contained copper naphthenate the ingredient that gave this product it's name. Cuprinol, Wittox-C, Osmose Cop-R-Nap all lasted 2 to 3 years on decks made with treated lumber just like all the rest. Remember the company that put out the Deck Restore is the same company that put out your Green Copper coating and you see the negative reviews for that. Wolman has been owned by many companies over the years and put out several coating for decks that all failed in 2 to 3 years. The paint companies keep repackaging the same old stuff with a few new ideas and people buy it I will say this one more time they will all fail on treated wood no matter what and I will bet my cash and my company name on it. As for your question yes it will fade and fail on the deck surface. Read the following on copper naphthenate. Ingredients, including contaminants, inerts, and by-products Copper naphthenate is a copper salt of naphthenic acid. Naphthenic acid is a complex natural mixture of fatty acids found in petroleum. It is a by-product of petroleum refining and has a variable composition.1 Ingredients, including contaminants, inerts, and by-products A typical copper naphthenate product would be about 19% copper naphthenate and 81% secret ingredients.2 The copper naphthenate portion is itself poorly characterized. Its composition depends on the composition of the source petroleum. The naphthenic acids may contain such constituents as cyclopentylacetic acid, alkyl-substituted cyclopentylacetic acids, fused chains of cyclopentylacetic acids, cyclohexylacetic acids, cyclopentanoic acids, and various low-molecular-weight fatty acids.3 It may also be contaminated up to 25% with hydrocarbons such as benzene from the petroleum source.

I used a 4" paint roller to press out the cement, easier than trying to press them down by hand. Just use a normal pressure. Also we did not caulk the seams. They fit tightly agaist each other, that chaulking is a waste of time. labor and $$$ Wish there had been foam tiles like this when we bought our house in 2000! I would have had them up then!! We can afford real tin tiles but these look 100% as good.

question: Can this test female ports as well or do you have to use a short patch cable to connect to a female connector?
answer: To add to Phillip's statement. This testor is designed to test cables. As you can see, the testor consists of a sending unit (the larger device) and a receive (the smaller device). Each device has two ports in which to insert one of the following, either an RJ11 (telephone / MOD6 plugs) or an RJ45 (data / MOD8 plugs). If you were testing a data or telephone cable, it would have a plug at each end, either an RJ11 or an RJ45. If you were testing a patch cable, you would insert one end in the sending unit and the other end in the receiver. If you were testing a cable with a jack installed at one end, and either an RJ11 / RJ45 plug at the other, then you would need a short patch cable to connect one of the devices to the jack end. If you were testing a patch panel to a jack, then you would need two patch cables to test the cable. The unit does not come with patch cables. I hope this answers your question.

question: How much am I suppose to be sanding? I took some 220 grit and then 400. The 400 felt like it was sliding on glass. Also I have an etching design on the bottom of the tub that is lots of circles. Is that a problem?
answer: I found the directions on the box to be quite poor regarding the suggested sanding. The 220 grit was not nearly enough and to my extreme disappointment the paint started to bubble off in a corner of my shower about 15 min after I completed the process. This in turn resulted in about 3 more days of work (waiting for it to dry completely, sanding again, building back the low spots, applying 2 final coats to even everything out) and my final product still doesn't look as good as it could have if the directions had just said to hit it with a harder grit straight away. Rust-O-Leum customer Service was good about helping with replacing the product -- I feel it was their fault due to the poor directions. I ended up using 4 kits in total. I'd recommend scuffing the whole thing with 80 grit DRY sandpaper. The whole tub will look extremely dull and scratched when you are done but that is the whole point. You need to get every bit of glossy surface and/or soap scum off so that the paint can stick. None of the scratches you make are going to show at all when you are done anyway because the paint self-levels and fills all the scratches in. In summary: Again, don't be afraid to scuff it up good with 80 grit (or 100 would work too). Hope this helps you be successful on the first try. I sure wish I would have been.

question: can it mine stone
answer: 'mine stone'? Not quite sure what you mean by 'mine stone', but it can be used in prospecting, where your intention is to strike stone to break it into smaller pieces to make handling and extraction easier. Is it a legitimate tool that a miner would use? Yes. Is it a good tool? Yes. Is it comparable to other tools in the same class? Yes. Could you take it into a mine and use it to dig at ore deposits? Yes. Can you use it to break rocks into smaller rocks? Yes. Keep in mind, it is a 'small' hammer, in that it is not a 28-36 inch pick, but more along the size of a carpenter's hammer. It is designed to work with rock and other stone materials. One end is a single-point rock spike, the other is a square-head hammer for crushing. This tool is NOT primarily designed to drive nails, but is designed to extract ores, precious and semi-precious stones, etc., from native rock (such as digging in creek banks during placer operations, or digging in surface or sub-surface mineral deposits, such as is found in lode operations). If you are seeking minerals or gems (let's say quartz), then this is IDEAL for cracking rocks to get to quartz, opening or shaping geodes, etc. I use mine often, and when placer panning, I carry it on a belt loop holder. If I have large stones that have color (read that as GOLD) in them, I can crack the stone open and crush it down so it will work through my sluice and then extract the gold from the crush. Does this answer what you are asking?

question: I have six areas on my garage floor 18" by 5"by 2 " deep. How much product do I need to purchase?
answer: 2" deep is a huge amount to fill with this product. It is for thin skim or filling of thin cracks. For your application I would wet the area with water and then use a PVA concrete adhesive such as Sikalatex on the recess. When it is still wet use regular concrete mix just a little more water than usual to allow it bed in properly and keep the fill about 1/16" below the garage floor surface. After it has dried for a week or so then you can use a thin coat of this epoxy to level out the filled area and feather it into the surrounding area. You can even sand it a little after it dries for 24 hours...

question: Is this a powered relay? Or if for example I'm trying to power up a lightbulb used as a heating element, do I need to jump power from T1 to T3?

question: Can this product be installed under laminate/floating floor? It says for tile heating. Thanks
answer: laminate flooring is a pulp and paper product layered with either a plastic or wood sheet that is "laminated" onto it ... so, in saying that, most (if not all) pulp and paper products tend to insulate rather than transfer heat. So, it's not so much that you "can't" install it, it's more like will it do you any good to install it? most of the heat will not reach the surface like you want so I would say it's not a good idea to install it under laminate products (wood and plastic is also not a good idea). Tile(both metal and ceramic/porcelain) or concrete is fine. Hope this helps you out. Sheldon

question: works fine until I attach the load wires, then it trips every time, Helpl
answer: There are a couple different possibilities. * There could be an appliance downstream from the outlet that actually has a small ground fault. Try unplugging everything and see if it still trips * There could be a ground wire in an outlet box touching a neutral. To determine this you would need to pull the down stream outlets out of the boxes to inspect. You might be able to just remove the covers and look in with a flashlight, look for ground wires touching the neutral terminals, missing wire nuts, neutral wires with insulation missing, etc. * Another possibility is that a neutral from a different circuit could be connected to the neutral on the load side of the gfci. The neutral downstream from the gfci can only be connected to the same outlets the black wire is. This might happen in a electrical box that has both an outlet and a light switch fed from a different circuit. *You could also have a ground fault in a wall somewhere. A staple pounded into a hot wire somewhere. Not easy to find, or fix, but also not very likely. Hope this helps.

question: Will this motor replace my Sta-Rite Max-E-Pro 1 1/2 HP
answer: I replaced my pump motor with a century motor and it working fine. There are 3 things you need to confirm. The frame number, the voltage and the RPMs. These will be found on the plate on your sta-brite motor and the specifications for the century motor. If the are the same it will work fine. The frame number defines the overall dimensions, the flange mount and the shaft dimensions.

question: Will this work as a direct replacement for a 2100T
answer: The 2100T and 2W are both "2 wire" smoke detectors. This means that the device gets it power from the same two wires it provides an initiating signal to the zone. Therefore "2 wire" detectors must be designed in such a way that its parameters fully match the design parameters of the zone and also of the panel when configured as a smoke zone. Since these two devices are both made by System Sensor and the 2W is intended to replace the 2100 in its line of detectors it is likely that the parameters match. The issue is that "2 wire" detectors must be listed (usually by UL) to work with the specific panel it is being connected to AND the panel must be listed to work with that particular detector. This is called cross listing. Listing is done by the testing agency (i.e. UL) by actually testing the specific detector on the specific panel. It is more common than not that the manufacturer of an older panel has not updated their panel listed by testing a newly released detector with that panel. In addition it is likely the new detector was not tested while being connected to an older panel. Note also, that a particular model panel's listing might be updated to be cross listed with a newer smoke detector but existing units in the field do not automatically have their listings updated - a panel firmware upgrade would be required. Though not knowing the panel being utilized the answer is probably no. It is likely that the 2W will work fine but without the cross listing one cannot be certain of this and installing the 2W in a panel it has not been cross listed for is a violation of NFPA standards and in most jurisdictions against local and/or state statutes.

question: Any reason why I would get the MIMOlite vs the Evolve LFM-20 to control a garage door opener with SmartThings?

Basicly it's 2 devices in one. It's also easier to wire as it has a wall wart you plug in (usually on the celing right where you garage door opener is plugged into). Can be mounted externally and has screw down low voltage pins for the wires. The evolve needs to wire nut a few high voltage wires. Bottom Line its alot better then manually wiring a LFM-20, safer, easier, cost the same and has a sensor input and relay output in one device.

question: How do I adjust the saw blade? It is off and the instructions are terrible for explaining exactly which hex bolt adjusts the blade to make it square.
answer: There is a socket head cap screw on the right side of the bevel gauge. It is embedded in the bevel mechanism housing. The tool that comes with the saw has a socket on one end to take the blade on and off and a hex key on the other that fits this socket screw. Loosen the lever on the back of the saw and then adjust this screw in and out to get the blade square. There are also hex head bolts to the left and right of the bevel gauge that determine the extents of the bevel feature. If you can't get the blade all the way to 45 tilting left or right, then adjust these screws.

question: What is the weight without the battery? I'm comparing it to the Dewalt DCD950B model which is 3.9 lbs. w/o battery

Having used it now for 3-4 months, I can tell you that it is well balanced, not to heavy to do extended overhead work, and is flat out the best all around drill I have ever owned. I love this thing & I do not gush about products often, if ever. If you buy either, I would advise to stay away from the "bit holder" you can purchase as an option. If they made a level you could attach in the same place (maybe they do, I have not really looked), it would be a much better expenditure of funds--even if it's only a $5 option, that is EXPENSIVE when it flat out is so poorly designed that I removed it from the drill and relegated it to the junk drawer. But I digress. I suspect you will not be unhappy with either drill and though I cannot give you an exact answer, I am downright giddy about the one I have & I expect it to offer no less than a dozen years of service (I pulled that number out of my ***). Of course the batteries are super expensive on these models and I am unsure if they can be rebuilt. Point being that I may have to get new batteries before replacing the drill--time will tell. The other side of that is that I have had good luck with batteries in general over the years and have found that if you take care of them, they will take care of you. The batteries I have are the lighter and slightly higher voltage Lithium Ion (came with unit) and they are known to have better tolerances, shelf life, etc. with the caveat being, to try not to drain them down to 100% (I think that there is a chip in the pack which protects them from that anyway) which unlike NiCad and Nmh, will harm the batteries. So a long read without really answering your question. Hope it helps you & if not, maybe somebody else. Note: Although I use my drill primarily on metal, I had an opportunity to use the hammer feature last week to go through some pretty tough concrete to anchor in some handrail. You might think that a cordless drill would not be up to the task. You would be dead wrong. Could not have been more impressed. Regards, Dan

question: Does this unit have to have it's own circuit? It does not say that it does in the instructions, but a local supplier told me if it does.
answer: The unit, when heating, pulls about 12 amps (1440 watts). The circuit you plug it into is generally a dedicated circuit (water heaters and microwave ovens) but it does not have to be as long as you don't plan on plugging in other high amperage appliances into the same circuit. Check your electrical breaker box that feeds the outlet you plan to use, the switch will have a number on the lever, most likely a 15 or a 20 but maybe even a 30. This is the amps which the breaker will trip. Hopefully you have a 20 or higher. For example, if you have a 20 and the heater pulls 12, that leaves 8 amps to spare and if you are at 120 volts x 8 amps, that is another 960 watts before it will trip. If your breaker is at 15 amps, then you cannot add much of anything else that pulls over 2 or 3 amps, to that circuit. You can put some child safety caps on the other plugs to remind you and others that that circuit if full.

question: The RPM on mine is 1000, is this motor okay as a replacement?
answer: This motor is could be 7.5% faster than you old one. But 1000 RPM is a very odd and rare speed, most likely your old motor has the same number of windings as this one and is really moving at 1075 RPM, but the label says 1000. Common ratings for these fan motors are 1050, 1075 and 1100 RPM. I wouldn't worry too much about it, but I do recommend replacing the start capacitor with a new one (that is rated for this motor 5mfd/370V Capacitor) when replacing the motor.

question: How do you know when the filter needs to be changed?
answer: These filters are good for a year or more. I reverse flush mine on the first of every month. The recommendation is every 2 months. You can test your water for chlorine just by buying some very cheap test strips from Lowes or Home Depot. Pool test kits work very well and cost around 20$. Amazon has litmus test strips very easy to use and cost around $8 for 25 tests. question: With a limited budget would it be redundant to buy this dado stack and later a router. That is would you buy one or the other or eventually both?
answer: Eventually you'll find a dado blade set helpful. With the ever shrinking size of plywood today, I'd suggest you first use a router. You should have at least a two amp router that accepts a 1/2" shaft. Make a "t" square guide to keep your cut straight. With the router you can make any width cut but will be limited to maybe a 3/4" depth. If you are making dadoes in a lot of material a dado saw set will be faster but you'll find it challenging to accommodate the weird plywood sizes. Your saw also needs the power to use the dado set as well as the arbor length so you can add or remove blades and or shims to cut the dimension you desire Martin

question: Why the 3/4" LP inlet? I plan 40lb DOT tanks with a Rego switchover regulator, 400k BTU/hr max (plenty!) but the regulators only have 1/2" outlets :-(
answer: As it was explained to me, the gas is working under a low pressure. If you run low pressure though a long 1/2" pipe run, you will starve the heater of enough gas to lower the amount of BTU's it can produce. Yes, the regulator is 1/2" but opens to 3/4" pipe to reduce the friction. I had a short run in my house and did use 1/2" pipe to the heater and used a 1/2" to 3/4" adapter at the heater. Has been working this way for 9 years now with out a hic-up. It is a very reliable heater and have installed several over the years. YMMV

question: what is the difference between 1 and 2 stage furnace and how can I tell which i have?
answer: Single Stage Furnace The gas flame is either on or off. Consequently, the furnace waits for the temperature in the house to get cold--often colder than comfortable--before firing on. Then, the furnace rams the house full of heat until the thermostat shuts the system down. Two-Stage or Dual-Stage Furnace The two-stage furnace is a little smarter than the single stage furnace. Rather than a simple on/off operation, its flame can be on/high, on/low, or off. Adding this second flame setting makes a dramatic difference in energy costs. Two stage furnaces are much quieter than single stage furnaces and slightly higher cost. For a target of 72 degrees, actual temperatures in your house might range as low as 70 degrees and as high as 74 degrees.

question: I am looking at using this over my patio door with lined drapes. I do not want to have to place a 3rd bracket in the middle. Will it hold?
answer: It depends how wide your door is, and what size rod you bought. If it's a double door, then you'll want to add a bracket in the middle, as it'll tend to sag. These adjustable rods are made of two tubes, one of which fits inside the other, and is pushed in or pulled out to make the width you want. So there isn't the strength and rigidity you'd need to span a double door without its sagging in the middle.

question: why can't I use this on a regulated line
answer: This connector is just like what you have on a liquid propane tank, at 80 degrees around 128PSIG, at 130 degrees around 257PSIG. Regulated is usually 0.5 PSI and usually at most 15 PSI, a very different range. The valves, passages, etc are also made for these high pressures and at 0.5 PSI will likely not function or pass enough gas to do much. Then what ever you connect will also have a regulator, which will also not function properly with the low pressure and what ever you connect won't work. You need to bypass the regulator on your BBQ or what ever using the proper hose connection made for regulated pressure, to adapt it to connect to this connector would be vary dangerous because if anyone later connected to a regular tank at full pressure with no regulation massive gas would escape and possibly blow out hoses and lines not made for the pressure.

question: I think I like the white frame 9000 - what's the difference otherwise vs. this one? And, no batter, what happens on power outage?
answer: I think we have the light grey one so I can't answer that question. When the power goes out there are batteries that allow the thermostat to continue to work. However, your furnace/AC will not be working. When the power comes back on the thermostat will re-establish contact with your WiFi and everything will be fine. If you go to the Total Comfort website you can set up an email message to be sent you if the thermostat looses contact with the WiFi. That is almost always because of a power failure. I love that feature as we live in Alaska and spend several months outside of Alaska at a second home in the winter. So I know when the power goes off and it notifies me when the thermostat re-establishes contact with the WiFi when the power comes back on. So if there is a lengthy delay I can call and have someone go and check our home out. Hope this helps.

question: Can this be installed into the wall rather than on top of the wall?
answer: No. Not really. There are three main reasons for this. The first reason is that the water connection lines exit from the back of the unit. Thus, your supply lines would need to be behind the unit to make that connection. With typical 4" stud depth and considering the depth of the unit itself, there wouldn't be enough room to make this connection. Possible solution is if you wanted to drill out holes in the bottom casing of the unit and make the connection from the underside. The second reason is that the connection for the hand held water sprayer exits from the side of the unit. As such, the unit needs to be mounted on the wall for this. Possible solution for this is to box out a niche around the sprayer connection, but that isn't exactly an elegant solution. The third reason is that once the unit is mounted in the wall and sealed you would have no easy access to the back of the unit for maintenance, leak checking or troubleshooting. Access would need to be made available from the back side of the unit and depending on your wall arrangement this may not be possible. It certainly wouldn't be very aesthically pleasing onthe access side.

question: Bacteria Test: How does the bacteria test work?
answer: You put the water sample in the small bottle, being careful not to spill the powder in the bottle, fill to 1/2" below the top (cold water side), shake well, place on shelf and in 48 hrs, if it turns a yellow color, there's bacteria present, violet or blue, no bacteria. It does not tell you specifically which bacteria. Some reviews have reported a yellow/blue result, so it's inconclusive (my tests have all been pretty conclusive). If you get that, you might have your water tested professionally for a conclusive test. Only one test is included for each of the variants.

question: So how is this any different than a non-contact IR thermometer?
answer: The most important difference between this and a non-contact IR thermometer is that once you read a base temperature you can set the device to give a visual representation of any temperature differences. The way it does that is by changing the color of a bright spot of light it projects on the surface you are measuring. That was important to me because I am in the energy conservation business and I can use it to show my customers where cold air is leaking in around doors or windows or where heat is escaping to the outside. The light will go from green to red or from green to blue depending on whether the temperature is going up or down. Nothing beats a visual indication of what is going on and this gives you that. The light registers when you first read a base temperature then when it changes it goes to blue for colder or red for warmer in 1-5-10 degree increments depending on where it is set. Personally I am no fan of Black and Decker products. I avoid them as being cheap foreign made and low quality. However, this thing works for me and I have had it for two years without any problem.

question: Is this the new RED lithium version? Which version is this, the old or new?
answer: Okay when I ordered mine several weeks ago I couldn't find the difference between the $39.99 Battery and the $69 battery, but I have figured it out. Amazon has the same picture for both batteries. The newer battery ($69) should say RED Lithium the older battery says Lithium-Ion. The difference between the Red Lithium XC and the Lithium-Ion XC is 4Wh. (4 watt hours). The Regular small RED Lithium battery is 16watt/hour the Lithium-Ion XC is 28watt/hour and the newer Red Lithium XC is 32 watts. So is the extra 4 watts worth $7.50 a watt?? I'm not sure what the extra benefits are of the RED Lithium other than increased amperage and hype. However for the difference of a sawbuck, and almost doubling the run time is a good deal (between the regular 16wh RED Lithium and the 28wh Lithium-Ion XC).

question: How do you sharpen this knife? I've tried everything and cannot get a good edge.
answer: You cant use ceramic rod sharpeners due to the single bevel grind. It is easy as it is only one angle to worry about instead of two like a hollow grind. But you must use a flat stone. Look into Smith's tri hone stone sharpener it has all 3 grits you need to get an edge. You can use soapy water or honing oil with the stones never use dry. Once you place the knife flat on the stone start lifting the angle edge side of the knife until it stops and start sharpening. There is a video on youtube how to sharpen a mora and the guy used that sharpener thats why I got mine. Hope this helps

question: What sizes are the sockets?
What's the little black pencil shaped thing (It has a clip on it for like a pocket)
answer: The pencil magnet (or any magnet) can be used for two purposes on this iron: locking the temperature and changing the units between F/C. To lock the temperature, just tap the ESD SAFE logo with a magnet while the station is on. A little dot will light up under the Lockout label to show this. To turn off, just tap the ESD SAFE logo again. To change the units: power off the station, turn the temperature knob all the way to maximum, hold the magnet over the ESD SAFE logo, then turn the station on. The F/C dot should toggle.

question: What is the difference between the 40200H and the 40300H? Why the $100 differential in price?
answer: Both the 40200H and 40300H have a helical head with HSS inserts instead of 2-3 full width blades, But the 40200H is heavier and tougher built. Just look at the weight of the machine and you will see that the 40200H is 95 lbs and the 40300H is 66 lbs. The 40200H has snipe lock and 2 threaded rods for height adjustment (and 4 smooth ones for support) whereas the 40300H has no snipe lock and 4 threaded rods. Also the 40300H spins at 10000RPM and the 40200H spins at 9000RPM. The Steel City website titles the 40300H as 13" Portable Planer with Helical Head and the 40200H as 13" Deluxe Portable Planer with Helical Head.

question: How to install?
answer: You need a drill with an extension bit because you need to be able to get some distance between the tool and the cabinet. I did it without the extension and it was challenging on a couple of them because there really wasn't enough room to get the drill level. You just position them at the edge of the cabinet as shown in the picture in listing -- not a big deal! Less than 5 minutes for a set of 2 doors. The key is a power drill with that extension on it! Oh, and if you want to maximize the space in your cabinet's interior, be sure to mount the stops at the top of the cabinet, not the bottom. They DO take up space behind them but if they're at the top, there likely won't be anything back there so you won't lose any of the storage area! I have some that are mounted on the bottom but only on cabinets that I don't load up very much. They were difficult to get to and mounting on the top would have been a little too difficult for me on my ladder.

question: How many wall panel electric heaters will this unit regulate? 1, 2 or more than

question: how do i wire a magnetic switch between power and led strip?
answer: Do it on the low-voltage side of the power supply... i.e. on the LED strip side, not the AC power cord side. Wire the switch in series, meaning pick one of the 2 wires, cut it, strip off a little insulation on both ends resulting (about 0.5 inch), and connect the switch (could solder, or use twist-on caps). If you want the lights to turn on when the magnet is removed, then use a normally-closed switch... if opposite then use a normally-open.

question: How do you hang this lamp without a chain?
answer: Hi, Maybe I can help. The lamp plugs directly into the wall outlet via a very, very long circular, "lamp cord" with a three-pronged plug at the end. The lamp cord is about as thick as the one used by my cable company to wire my cable TV system. It is also less flexible than a typical lamp cord. To attach the lamp to the ceiling the company includes a metal hook that you screw directly into the ceiling, sort of like the hooks you use to hang a plant (only less decorative), AND a three inch long "S" shaped piece of plastic with a small hole at one end. To attach the lamp to the ceiling, first screw in the metal hook. Then, attach the "S" shaped plastic piece to the hook using the small hole on the end. Finally, you thread the lamp cord "in" and "out" of the "S" shaped piece of plastic. The lamp is held in place by the tension created by "threading" the lamp cord through the "S" shaped piece of plastic. Sorry for being "long-winded", but I hoped this helps. BTW, I use mine in my bedroom suspended above the end table with a 40 watt yellow light bulb, and I like it very much. Also, it is very utilitarian looking, not fancy. I happen to like that look.

question: A reviewer complained that this is actually a Fluidmaster 400A. Is that what you got or was that reviewer ripped off?
answer: Fluidmaster makes this model as well as many more for other brand toilets. But Kohler uses a Fluidmaster PerforMax model with a bag of click-in restrictors found in the Fluidmaster Pro45U model kit. Kohler just brands it with a Kohler embossed top. HOWEVER, what makes Kohler-Fluidmaster's version unique is the water inlet towards the bottom of the fill valve is about an inch from the tank bottom. This is so Kohler can use it for regular tanks and foam insulated tanks- smart! Also included are the flow restrictors needed for different types of Kohler toilets. Instructions included to figure that out. So to answer your question, "no", I did not get a regular Fluidmaster 400A fill valve. I received a Fluidmaster PerforMax/Pro45U built to Kohler's specifications. If you check prices the PerforMax, Pro45U and Kohler fill valve are very close in price. For that reason I always choose the Kohler version.

question: How do you use this product without a garden hose hooked to it? We need it at a dry camp with water buckets
answer: in your situation I would do the following....using the flojet pump which is part of the package, you will need to connect this to two hoses - the intake side goes into one of your buckets (pulling water from the bucket - remember this can use 2.9 gpm so hope your buckets are big or you have lots of water available ), the other hose is your cold water intake side for the eccotemp. The pump provides the necessary psi water pressure needed to make the eccotemp operate. I use a similar system here in the Dominican Republic. Water here comes via gravity feed from a 400 gal tank on the roof, but this is not enough psi feed to make the eccotemp operate. Hence the 12v waterpump. This is how I get hot water here without having to use very expensive electricity. Hot water when and where you want it. Has worked flawlessly for past year - 20 gal propane used in 1 year C. Poole

question: Can I use this on my water heater?
answer: This switch is rated to switch 2400 watts of power at 120 Volts. If your water heater has an element that is less than 2400 watts, and runs on a 120 volt circuit, yes you can use this. It is not likely that your water heater meets these requirements. You can, however, use this switch to switch a relay that is rated to turn your water heater on and off. An inexpensive example of this is the Packard C230B. It will switch 220 volts up to 6600 watts and has a 120 volt coil. This is a mechanical contactor. You can also look for a solid state relay that will be quieter and last longer, but cost more.

question: are these clips one piece
answer: Yes they are one piece. You basically have a U shaped part that you slide over the side/edge of the plywood panel. Much as your hand holds the panel with your thumb on one side and your fingers on the other, just so, the clips grip the panel. Typically, you have clips that are designed for 1/2 inch plywood. If you run out of the half and need to use it with 3/8 plywood, a pair of vise grip pliers canbe used to squeeze the U shape part to grip the thinner panels. Now for the rest of the clip. Thinking again in the hand analogy, imagine that your fingers are the point of a V bend in the metal strip that makes the clip. The part of the clip that leaves your finger tips and goes up along the back of your fingers extends beyond your knuckles and has the "teeth". In use, the portion with the teeth are on the outside of the panel- the side near you. As you push the panel into the window opening, the portion of the clip with the teeth will be dragging on the bricks and essentially pulled away - the V is opened up somewhat. Sorry about the long answer.

question: what the different between 2amp and 4amp
answer: Battery should be described as 2ah (amp hour) & 4 ah. The 4ah battery will last about twice as long between charges as the 2ah battery. Two 2ah batteries will allow you to keep working while recharging the other battery. However I have one 4ah battery for my pole saw that lasts as long as I do. There are other pages on Amazon that correctly describe the battery as 2ah or 4ah. You may want to order from a vendor that more accurately describes his product (I looked and didn't find a better description that was compatible with the same charger as the one you are considering). Also confirm that the battery that you order is compatible with the charger. I see that there is ample opportunity to get a mismatch.Good luck. See: http://www.amazon.com/Greenworks-29662-40V-Lithium-Ion-Battery/dp/B00KJ65W8K/ref=pd_sbs_lg_31?ie=UTF8&refRID=0QM0C77332G6JXX5PR6T

question: How wide of a cut can you make with the GR200 and what is the practical cut width limit - i.e. at what width is it better to use the saw blade guard?
answer: I'm assuming that you mean making a cut while spanning the GRR-Ripper over the blade. None of the following measurements allow for blade clearance, so your actual ripping widths will be reduced by that clearance amount. Maximum distance from fence to inside edge of GRR-Ripper is 3-3/8 inches. Attaching the accessory gripper foot against the fence adds an inch, totalling 4-3/8. Mounting the stabilizing leg instead adds just under 2 inches, totalling ~5-5/16. I suppose you could add the flat accessory plate, gaining several inches, but the rig will easily skew against the fence and there is absolutely no reason to pass over the blade at that point anyway; it's just unnecessarily dangerous and the basic GRR-Ripper should be used as a conventional push block alongside the blade. To summarize, you can rip widths from about 1/4 inch (between blade and fence, as shown in their demos, though that gets the blade very close to plastic) up to about 3-1/4 inches with minimal blade clearance if you're very careful. Mounting the accessories takes that width to about 5-1/8. The GRR-Ripper is 3-5/8 outside width, so it's just as easy to go beside the blade at that width, and probably more stable. The height of the GRR-Ripper, when passing alongside the blade, keeps your knuckles farther from danger; mine are about 2-3/8 inches above the surface of the stock, so unless I just wildly throw my hand into the blade, I feel safer than feeding with a conventional push block, or certainly bare hands. If you do call your clearances too close and cut the plastic, there's no harm done beyond some expensive replacement parts. As a side note, if you want to play Jack the Ripper, you can allow the blade to protrude a full inch above your stock before it cuts into the top of your GRR-Ripper. I've said this before, but this is such a great product, superbly made, that I can't imagine risking my hands with unwieldy push sticks and short push blocks. I cut my left index finger with a knife in a moment of utter stupidity and have some joint and nerve damage. Every time I used typical long, wobbling push sticks, I had a thousand questions per second about where the saw was going to throw the wood--or the stick--when something slipped, and where my hands would fall in the confusion. With two GRR-Rippers, I am as comfortable at the saw as I am resting my hands on the kitchen counter. Total stability and confidence. Buy two, use them wisely, and keep your hands to hold your great-grandchildren.

question: This light more of a thrower or a flood?
answer: The SC600 is more of a flood light. Generally, you can get a better idea by looking at the reflector. If it's a smooth reflector, then it'll have a greater hot spot that is used for throw. If it has an orange peel reflector, then the light is dispersed more evenly for better spill and flood. However, it's the shape of of the lens and where the LED is positioned that will determine if it's actually a thrower or not. In the SC600's case, it has a shallow orange peel reflector so it's a better flood light with more spill.

question: I'm a widow and don't know which circuit to flip down for this light. Does the electricity have to be turned off, in order to use this gadget?

question: My sink does not have an extra hole for another faucet.....can I use my main faucet?
answer: It's possible technically, but it's not a good idea. However if it's just a bar or a prep sink, then it becomes more viable provided you have correct expectations. So in short, no, it should not be connected to the cold water feed on your kitchen faucet. There isn't enough water. The system has a 3.2 gallon reservoir tank, which is more than enough for drinking and cooking use, but it's not enough to feed a kitchen faucet which dispenses water at 2.5 gallons per minute. If you were to connect it to your kitchen faucet, turn on the water, and then turn your back for a minute to tend to your kids or answer a text, by the time you turned back around the tank would be dry and you'd have to wait a couple of hours for more water. As an alternative to drilling a new hole you can go to a "tri-flow" faucet with hot, cold, and filtered water inputs. Or if you sink has more than one hole, but the current faucet occupies all the holes, then get a single handle faucet, remove its base-plate, and use the extra hole(s) for the RO faucet (and a soap dispenser if possible).

question: One of the reviews says that using included stopper can cause a permanent rust ring. Can someone verify if this is possible? Very worrisome.
answer: Hi, I think I've used the stopper once or twice since I've had my sink, and when I did use it I never saw any rust at all. The only time I had to deal with a rust issue was when I was cleaning a pan with an SOS pad. I got a tiny bit of metal under one of the feet of the rack that sits in the sink. Stainless steel is very resilient and if you care for it properly it will look good and won't rust. I cleaned the tiny tiny spot of rust with a dab of Barkeepers Helper. I swear by that stuff. Also stay away from egg white on stainless. It doesn't hurt a cooktop because the heat fixes that, but I dropped a spot the size of a dime on my sink. I didn't realize it was the egg white until I tried to clean it after breakfast. When I got the rust stain, and managed to fix that with Barkeepers Helper, I thought I might as well try it on the egg white stain. To my surprise and great happiness it has taken away the spot!! Warning, be careful how much you rub and how hard. Be gentle or you'll leave a tell tail spot where you've been working. Just gently, with a wet micro cloth, put a little water and a little BH on the cloth and work on the spot. Then when you've done, rinse off the area you are focusing on and then rinse out the cloth and wipe down the whole area. You can do this to water spots also. I have very hard water in my area and I manage to get drips down the front of the sink and on my refrigerator, which is stainless. Stainless steel is beautiful, but it does take some care. I hope I haven't bored you will my information, but I like my new kitchen to look like it did when it was installed a year and a half ago, and it does.

question: can I use this pump for my lawn irrigation system it is a 3 zone system with a shallow well
answer: Yes you can use the pump for your lawn irrigiation system. However, there are some control questions you will need to resolve. 1. Is there any chance you could pump your shallow well empty or down to a level where the pickup pipe will be below the level of the water in the well? The pump cannot be ran without water to the input. It is not a self priming pump. 2. Does the irrigation system have an "on-off" timer. If so, then some method will need to be devised to prime the pump. Again, the pump cannot be ran without water at the input. 3. Are there approximately the same number of sprinkler heads in each of the three zones? If there is a large difference in the number of sprinkler heads, the pressure to each zone will vary and un- even results will occur.

question: Hi, I am reading that this doesn't work well on hotel room doors? Has anyone used this for hotel doors in India? Also is it easy to fit?! Thanks!
answer: That information is incorrect. I have stayed at quite a few hotels and most of the time, the lock will fit the door properly. However, doors are not standardized in hotels. The gaps between the door and the door frame vary. For this lock to function, the metal plate has to be able to fit inside the door and the door frame. If the plate will fit in that gap, the lock should work without any problem. It is very easy to check if it will work just by sliding the locking plate into the gap. If it slides in, it should work. Now I did have one door it did not work on when in fact, it slid into that gap. This particular door had an unusually wide dead bolt on it and it would not go through the plate. I can tell you, when you have this lock installed, you can not open the door at all until you remove the wedge, even from the inside of the hotel room. It is dependable and it works but it isn't a universal fit on all hotel doors throughout the world. Take care.

question: Did anyone use this for a 30 gal/ short boy in the drain plug?
answer: This is a sacrificial anode, intended to attract corrosion to itself, rather than to YOUR tank. It is also cuttable to length with a hacksaw. So . . . it should be able to go where your EXISTING anode is. Additional bit of useful info -- when the factory installs the original in the hot water heater, they use high-speed, high-torque wrenching devices. To quote one of the factory reps, semi-jokingly -- it takes 6 men and lots of beer to get it loose. In reality, you will need a hefty socket wrench AND a metal pipe that fits around the handle of the wrench to achieve enough leverage, to loosen the factory set rod. GOOD LUCK!

question: How loud is this heater? (In decibels if anyone knows). Looking for quiet space heater for my acupuncture treatment room. Thank you!
answer: I do not have any information on DB rating of the heater or any way to measure it. However, I can say that the level of sound from the heater is dependent upon the mode it is operating in. When operating at full output, the fan is operating at high speed and thus generates a level of sound consistent with any fan operated room heater which I would classify as moderately noisy. When operating at "idle" speed it is very quiet all of which is dependent upon the thermostat setting relative to room temperature. If you desire a very quiet heater, then I would suggest a radiant type heater that does not have a fan.

question: Does anyone know the answer to this. If i have a fixture that holds 3 bulbs and I only put one bulb in does that save on electricity or not?

They cost more but save you money over time and last a LONG time.

question: what is "active dimming"

question: how to program this product

question: I'm not an electrician. In terms I can understand, how do I wire this?
answer: We'll, I,m not sure what terms you will understand but we'll give it a try. 220volt service consists of 3 wires. 2 colored and 1 white. The colored wires are the "hot"or power wires. The white wire is the "neutral" wire. The relay has terminals on the left side and right side that each have a screw above them. This where the colored wires go, one under each screw. On the opposite side of the relay, there is another pair of screws. This is where the colored wires from the "appliance" or device go. The white wire from the electrical box connects to the white wire from the appliance. The switch that controls the relay connects to the 2 spade connections with the coil of wire underneath them. The colored wire from the switch is the "hot" wire and connects to one of the spade terminals. The other spade terminal connects to a white/"neutral" wire. When the switch is closed, power goes to the relay coil, closes the relay, and that completes the connection between the wires under the screw terminals and the appliance or device. Hope this helps

question: What is the difference between condensing and non condensing? Also, pros and cons between the two?
answer: It extracts the additional heat from the exhaust gases through various means and therefore exhaust cooler gases. Cooling the exhaust gases produces condensation, in this case inside the unit. Since the exhaust gases are now cooler a less expensive venting material can be used, mostly standard PVC schedule 40 is used as it can easily withstand the heat and the corrosive effects of the gases. Since we have captured the residual exhaust heat to. Heat the water we have achieved a higher efficiency in the high 90% (up to 98%).

question: I have bought 6 assorted red & green meters, all marked 3-30 volts. All work on 12 V, but none have measured 24v batts. Any help appreciated, Thanks
answer: How did you try to measure 24 volts? If you used 2 twelve volt batteries in series make sure they were connected one + lead to the other - lead. Or try to measure 3 nine volt batteries snapped together. You should get 27 volts. I think there is a calibration pot on the back of the meter. It is very small and you will need a jewelers screwdriver to adjust it. Make sure the red lead goes to the + termingal of the battery. Try again and let me know. You could have a bad batch of meters. Mine worked very will on my power supply that goes up to 27 volts. One last thing...are the 24 volt batteries you are measuring good batteries? The meter might be telling you that they are not. Hope this was useful. Also be aware that all meters have a percentage of error. Some are + - .1% + - .01%. No matter how expensive the meter it will have error tho very small. The smaller the error, the larger the price. These cheap but beautiful meters are good enough for battery monitoring. I wouldnt use them to build a computer power supply.

question: For supply air readings do you measure the size of the grill or the duct itself
answer: You measure the size of the grill, either inside diameter (duct) or the grill face itself in inches converted to square feet use the ft/min to determine cfm. Some companies use a duct that is modified to fit over the exhaust tubing and convert the exhaust or intake to a circular dimension and then take measurements. Multiple measurements are necessary on a grid pattern, at least 20, which are averaged and taken about 6 inches from the grill face at 90 degrees to the flow. Readings will vary upwards of 10 percent. For accuracy, it is a good practice for one person to measure the flow and the other to write down the data, plus use the averaging method on the instrument itself. The two person rule is a good idea for working off a ladder. The average cost on a call out plus the certified report averages about $1,000, so the anemometer is very handy to check and balance the system prior to having a certified technician do a survey.

question: Need to connect to 12V 9.6Ah alarm system battery. Does anyone know max current it can take? Do I need to put 600 Ohm resister in front of red wire?
answer: As they said - and for new users - voltmeters are in parallel (red to red, black to black) so DO NOT draw current other than their own tiny working about 10~20mA for themselves. Adding a resistor ahead is only done if feeding it more than its operating voltage and for only experts - this unit does3~30V so 12V is perfect within range. (AMPMETERS on the other hand are in series so they must be rated within or for the desired load you use - like water flow IN a hosepipe) (and have special resistors supplied if needed)

question: my light does not turn on. only sometimes if i hold the switch half way down. is the switch defective?
answer: I have bought a dozen of these flashlights over the last five years. Initially, they all had the same problem, the switch would only work if held part way on. The answer below this from R. Hennigh about a loose retaining nut is worth a shot, but for all twelve of mine, here's what I had to do, and what I'd recommend you try first. Unscrew the head and tailcaps of the flashlight and remove the battery. Hold the body tube up towards a window or a lamp...can you see through the tube? If not, take a long drift pin, a long dowel rod, anything that can take a good whack and not break...insert into the body tube from the tail (switch) end...when it contacts the plastic disc obstruction in the body tube, hold the tube tightly, and whack the rod with a hammer...HARD! When you dislodge the black plastic disc with the little brass colored rivet in its center, THROW IT AWAY! It serves no purpose, and stops the flashlight from working. Once removed, reassemble the head-end, re-insert the battery, and twist the switch cap back on...it should work fine now. Those caps were supposed to ensure the battery was inserted the correct way...the rivet is slightly indented on the tube side, and slightly proud on the head side. This would stop the flat negative side of the battery from making contact with the L E D driver circuit and destroying it due to reverse polarity...BUT...most 18650 battery positive end tips DO NOT fit the recess in the disc, so it prevents the flashlight from working AT ALL!! I have bought 12 of these lights...had to "modify" all of them. I carry two on me at all times, I have several in my vehicles, and have given some as gifts. In 5 years, the ONLY problem I've ever had was the initial need to modify the lights. Other than that, they are blindingly bright, highly reliable, light weight, and hold a charge regardless of the temperature of the vehicle they are stored in for months at a time. Good luck, and let me know how you made out!

question: Will the half inch square to quarter inch hex adapter withstand the 150 footpound torque from our impact driver?

question: By the door drawing, we have a LEFT HAND DOOR ..... by the handle drawing, we have a RIGHT HAND lever ..... which set do we order?
answer: M.T. Pawketts, not sure what your skill level is, so if this response is way too basic or wordy for you, I apologize. Hopefully, I won't confuse the issue any more than it already is, but, here goes. First, here is my understanding of how to determine LH or RH: IF, WHEN STANDING ON THE EXTERIOR SIDE OF THE DOOR, FACING YOUR HOUSE, THE DOOR HANDLE IS ON THE LEFT, HINGES ARE ON THE RIGHT, AND THE DOOR PUSHES IN, IT IS A RH DOOR. In my case, I have a right-hand door. Therefore, AS THE HARDWARE IS SHOWN IN THE PICTURE, THE SMALLER LEVERED HANDLE ON THE RIGHT shows the handle pointing to the right, which is EXACTLY OPPOSITE OF THE SET I BOUGHT FOR MY RIGHT-HAND DOOR. The smaller levered handle should actually point TOWARD THE DOOR'S HINGES, and not hang over the doorframe moulding, of course. AS PICTURED, THE HARDWARE WOULD BE FOR A LH DOOR! By the way, I have had the Schlage digital keypad locks on all three of my exterior doors - front, side, and back doors - for a good long while now, and they have operated flawlessly, with batteries seeming to last forever. They are ruggedly constructed, look great, and are precision made, as compared to others out there. They were well worth what I paid for them. I hope this helped. Good luck with your purchase and installation! wbc

question: Is it really worth it? Meaning for basic household usagae and to simply charge and use batteries is a charger like this worth the money?
answer: Most of our batteries are rechargeables, with the exception of the battery backups for our smoke alarms. So for us it is worth it since we have probably a hundred rechargeables in various devices. Since we've had our rechargeables for years, many are reaching the end of their life. This charger allows us to determine which batteries are no longer any good and not worth the time trying to recharge (without realizing we had been trying to charge the same battery over and over). It has also allowed us to recover a few batteries we thought might be bad but just needed to be discharged. If you have less than a couple dozen rechargeable batteries, then you should look at a more basic charger.

question: Does the radon level stay the same or it could be various? My radon level was 1 for half yearbut it goes to 1.8 recently. Because of the bad raining?
answer: Yes, your radon levels can vary. My daughters readings have averaged from about 5 to about 8. You want to be at 4 or below. Hers seem to be affected by the level of activity in the home as well as the season. She lives in southern Minnesota, which is a heaven for radon. Her brother lives less than a mile from her and his radon levels are below 2. If you are under 2, count your blessings because you will not have to mitigate. We will be installing a radon mitigation system in her home this summer. Hope this helped.....Dennis Owens

question: Would this model be appropriate for renovating kitchen cabinets?
answer: Probably. It is a classic quarter sheet sander so inside corners would either need a specialized sander or the old sanding block and elbow grease. Note: it is NOT a classic circular motion orbital sander, its motion is more elliptical than circular. That being said, it still works fine. I've used it on a kitchen table and it did a great job. Note: non orbit sanders MUST be used across the grain while orbital (or elliptical) sanders work fine either way. I would suggest getting "non clogging" sandpaper since this has a vacuum bag and non clog works best with this sort of thing. Finally, remember to use a tack rag or a faintly moistened towel to remove ALL the wood dust before you stain or paint or glue. Cleanliness is a must.

question: What are the deminsions?
I just purchased the DCD760KL 18 volt Lithium Compact Drill, Will my battery fit this saw?
answer: All Dewalt 18volt batteries fit Dewalt 18volt tools. The only thing to be concerned about is the charging. DO NOT use a NiCad charger for charging a Lithium battery. The charger will over heat and fuse the battery and charger to become one. You can use a Lithium charger for a NiCad with no effect on the charger or battery. The Lithium chargers are yellow and the NiCad chargers are Black.

question: I have three wires at the end of the cord: Yellow with green stripe, brown, and black. What is what?
answer: In America, answers stating that yellow/green stripe is "ground" are correct (green wire in USA). Regarding the other two wires (brown and blue), even though it's AC and to remain standardized, the "brown" wire is considered "hot" (Black wire in USA), and the "blue" wire is considered "neutral" (white wire in USA). Thus, "green/yellow" wire connects to USA "green", "brown" wire connects to USA "black", and "blue" wire connects to USA "white". If you're confused, my apologies...just Wikipedia it...Wiki even has pictures!!! To summarize, green/yellow to GREEN, brown to BLACK, and blue to WHITE. Just a footnote,the other connection will work....it's just not "standard".

question: Can I use this on 120 year old barn wood planks? I want to polyurethane afterwards too; no filler or paint desired...
answer: I would think as long as the wood is structurally sound overall you could use it. You need to remove all the rotted wood that can easily be scraped away and get to the good wood that is too hard to remove. Then use the hardener. Then poly coat it the next day. This should not be confused with products that supposedly seep into the rotted wood and harden it all up....this is used to harden the wood not quite rotted so the damage does not continue. Whether you fill the areas removed is up to you.

question: For all the negative comments, it seems to me it would let the breeze through and still keep a non-aggressive cat indoors. Yes? No? Thanks, Andy

The frame is made out of that "Slinky" like metal that in can fold up. Kind of like a child's play tent if you have ever seen one of those? The problem is does not come out of the package well where it will keep the shape of a door. It kind of will bend at the top or bottom and not stay flat to the door unless it is modified or hooked shut. When it is hooked shut, that means it can only be unhooked from the same side. In addition, it would need to be hooked at the top and bottom. I wouldn't buy one. Your better off buying the cheapest screen door you can find that actually has a latch and firm frame. I have been through SEVERAL Magic Mesh's variations and screens. I have now decided to just buy an actual screen door for my garage. I wish I had done that initially instead of wasting the money on these products that either don't last long or have annoying "complications". Good Luck.

question: Does this product come with any screws at all? Or is it just the jig.
answer: it comes with a few of several commonly used sizes... a sampling. But for any significant project you will need more of whatever size. You can order the Kreg screws on Amazon... or just wait and drill a couple of pilot holes in scraps to get the hang of your jig and the your particular project... including the required screw size and length for what you are doing... then get screws (cheaper) at the big box stores. I recommend the later course... make sure the right size and get them less expensive... using the sampling to compare for local screw sizing. It is a great jig... screws are good but pricy... other wood/deck screws fine for most projects. Hope that helps.

question: can this be rewired to run off of 12 VDC?
answer: Theoretically it could be wired for 12 VDC; but it would involve more work than it is worth and probably would result in destroying some LED segments. The light source is made up of a grid of smaller LED modules in series / parallel all very close together. This grid of LED modules is connected to a heatsink that dissipates the heat to the lamp housing. Separating the LEDs for a different voltage is not something worthwhile or recommended. There are 12 volt DC LED floodlights available ready to go.

question: Makita 18 volt BGA452Z Grinder Cut off wheel: Has anyone else had issues with this machine ?

I would agree it is one of the few 18volt tools that does not completely replace the need for a 120volt tool but I find it extremely useful and bought one for my father and brother who are also contractors for Christmas last year. question: would a stock cpu cooler work? (intel)

Just remember that heat kills LED devices, so I would reccomendations doing homework and making sure the cooler is designed for at least 120 was of heat disipation. Then you know it will be safe. And as always, if you run the LED at 2 to 4 volts under rating you can actually barely tell and yet extend the life of the LED for much longer. Best of luck to you and if you have the choice always choose an active fooling device over a passive for this high output LED due to the increased heat output.

question: Is this just copper sulfate which can be bought pure for much less?
answer: It may very well be. I'm no chemist and years ago a plumber told me on the sly after having to enlist his services to clear our sewer line for the umpteenth time that copper sulfate would do the trick. He didn't tell me the amount to use and I was a C- chemistry student in school. He retired about that time and I went along calling "Roto-Rooter" until I found this stuff in a catalog and bought it. I have a bottle that I'm going to dump in my system for the six month dose and the label indicates it is 99% Copper sulfate pentahydrate and 1% "other ingredients". I have used it for years now and have never had to make a service call to have my line "snaked". I've stayed with it because it has worked for me all these years and also because my ignorance of chemistry keeps me from wanting to use an inappropriate dose of copper sulfate that might screw up the pipes leading to the sewer and cost a large out of pocket expense for repairs. I hope that's helpful. Good luck!
