question: the picture is too large and covers the description. What's the input voltage?
answer: I'm not sure what the "input voltage is 110-240V" means, but please disregard that! The rated voltage drop across the LED module is stated to be 30-34V. But everyone using LEDs should be aware that the correct way to drive any LED is to regulate (limit) the current through the LED, not drive them with a constant voltage. LEDs, at their simplest, behave like any diode in most ways. When forward biased, they begin to pass current once their forward voltage is reached. But since no device is ideal, they do exhibit something of a voltage versus current characteristic over a small region. But make no mistake, an LED is NOT a resistor, and the current through it will NOT be directly proportional to the forward voltage applied. Instead, as you increase the applied voltage, the current through the device will start off very near to zero and will stay that way until you reach some threshold. At that point, some conduction will begin, and the current will rise as you increase the forward voltage. But even this will not be a linear curve. These multi-LED modules exhibit a more forgiving voltage versus forward current curve than a single LED might, but still, you need to treat them like what they are, which is an array of LEDs connected in series or series parallel in the case of larger modules. I don't know what the forward voltage rating is for each of the individual LEDs used in these modules, but typical blue LEDs have a forward voltage drop of something like 3.2 Volts when driven with a reasonable forward current. Further, high power LEDs are typically driven at 350mA or less to achieve the best luminous efficacy. These modules appear to contain 100 individual LEDs. If we go with 3.2V (which is nothing more than a guess since the LEDs in these modules could well be a completely different type), and we assume a forward voltage of 30-34 Volts for these modules, and we decide that there's 100 individual LEDs in the module, we come up with approximately 10 LEDs in series to get the 32 Volts. So the modules could contain ten strings of 10 LEDs each. 10 LEDs in series in each string, with ten of those strings connected in parallel to form the array of 100 LEDs. This would give us the 30-34 Volts that the manufacturer states. And close inspection of one of the modules seems to show ten strings of ten LEDs. If you look closely, you can see tiny lead bonds along opposite sides of the power connections. And between the LEDs, there appear to be bond wires connecting the individual dice in series to form the strings of ten LEDs each. So it's a reasonable guess that what we have are ten strings of ten LEDs. And I don't see any kind of resistors in the module. That doesn't mean that there couldn't be any, perhaps included to help balance the current through the ten strings. So-called "sharing resistors". But such resistors would also reduce the efficiency of the system, so perhaps they're not needed as long as the LED dice are fairly well matched and kept at the same temperature. And that brings me to a major point about why you don't want to simply drive one of these modules with a constant voltage. The forward voltage drop across an LED (any diode, really) changes with temperature. Indeed, one way of measuring temperature is to simply pass a known current through a diode and measure the forward voltage drop. This is used inside some CPU chips for the on-chip temperature monitoring, etc. So, since the forward voltage drop of an LED is temperature dependent, it makes sense that we'll never know how much current we're forcing through the LEDs if we apply a regulated voltage and ignore everything else - unless we're prepared to regulate the temperature of the LED dice! Sounds like a pain to me. So the traditional (and proper) way to drive an LED is to regulate the CURRENT through the LED. Normally we start with a power source that can provide a voltage somewhat higher than the highest voltage we expect the LED to require. Then we design in an active current regulation system OR simply install a series resistor to limit the current to the approximate value we want. Again, using a resistor to limit the current is somewhat inefficient. That didn't matter much when we were simply driving a low-power LED display from, say, a 5 Volt source. We'd just put in current limiting resistors that kept the LED current to the desired range, and didn't worry too much about the waste. But in the case of a high power LED, we're obviously somewhat concerned with efficiency or we wouldn't be messing with an LED to begin with. So the usual way this is done in commercial LED lighting is to use a switching regulator circuit designed to provide a set current to whatever the load is. This way, the LEDs can change their forward voltage drop with temperature, and we don't care because the current regulator holds the forward current constant. And this is what we really want to do with these LED modules, too. I'm not saying you can't get away with experimenting with them using nothing more than an adjustable voltage power supply, as long as you're careful. And indeed, over a reasonable range of voltages, these modules seem to be quite forgiving. BUT, we need to keep in mind that simply finding a voltage that seems to work for us under one set of conditions on our bench, isn't a substitute for actually regulating the current through the modules. What if you come up with a voltage that gives you the desired (maximum) current of 3.5 Amps through the module. And you build a light based on that. Then you take it out, and the temperature isn't the same as it was on the bench? What if the forward voltage drops of the LEDs go down a bit? Now, your chosen voltage may be forcing far too much current through the LED module, and you may fry it. Or the opposite could be true, and the forward voltage of the LEDs might go up. In that case, if it goes up enough, the light output might drop off to virtually nothing because the current dropped down to some very low value - all simply because the temperature of your LED module wasn't the same as it happened to be when you were experimenting on the bench. I see that Amazon shows their "folks who bought this often also bought this other thing", and that indicates that a lot of people are buying, to go with this LED module, a particular step-up voltage converter module with only voltage regulation. So I have to think that a lot of people (like me) envision running these LEDs from a 12 Volt power source, like a sealed lead acid battery or maybe a car power system. And again, we may get away with doing that using only the voltage regulated step-up module. But be advised that you are not really building a reliable design if you do that. The pros would use a step-up module that can provide a voltage above the 34 volts, and which has the ability to limit its output current to the desired level. The website for the LED maker shows a forward current of 3500mA (3.5 Amps) for these units. Ideally, we'll get or build a step-up converter that can be adjusted to, say, 36 Volts output, and then set the current limit to 3.5 Amps. (Assuming we want the full 100 Watt power to the LED module). That way, over a reasonable range of temperatures, our LEDs will receive the correct drive current. If we want them to run dimmer, and save power, we can simply turn down the current limit on the power supply. I do see some constant voltage, constant current modules for sale, too. They cost more, of course, but that's what we really need to properly drive these LEDs. Sorry for the long reply, but based on what I see, a LOT of people seem to think that LEDs require a constant voltage drive. That's not the case. We want a constant current drive, and let the voltage be whatever it will be at that current and temperature. The manufacturer states the typical forward voltage drop for the module so we'll know that our LED power supply must provide AT LEAST that much voltage to the LED module. But I'm sure they assume we'll all use a proper current-limited supply or a series resistor to limit the current to a safe and more-or-less constant current.

question: How much overspray? Do you still cut in walls at ceilings with a brush or tape off ceiling. How sharp is the edge of the spray.
answer: There is overspray with any airless sprayer. How much preparation and shielding will depend on your experience with a sprayer. I've been using airless spray guns for 25 years. I haven't purchased one of these yet, but I'm sure it has a different feel than a regular spray gun since you'll be holding a much bulkier unit in your hand. Drop cloths, painter's plastic, cardboard and spray shields are always a painter's friend. I can use an airless sprayer and shooting ceilings and only get 1/2" to 1" of overspray around the top of the walls - but that's because I can hold my gun at an angle that allows me better aim - this unit I'm sure would create a much larger spray pattern in ceiling-wall corners.

question: I contacted RPM International and they told me this product is not rated for exterior use. It would be nice to have this info a little more available.
answer: I used it on some interior detailed brass statues They look great, and I expect the Brass Lacquer will preserve there brilliance for many years. I have a Copula on top of my Garage with a copper roof an a copper flying Goose weather vein on top. I haven't properly lacquered the roof yet but I did bring in the Goose & cleaned it very good & applied 2 coats of the Lacquer in October 2013 an it still looks great. It was the first time I had even thought about a protective coating to show off the copper finish. It seems a shame people purchase cooper or brass decorative outside attachments for their homes, as myself, and feel it the norm to let them fade to Patina (oxidation). When you can coat it and keep the cooper or brass luster you bought it for. I can't wait to Lacquer the Cupola roof. Longevity is a question an abuse from the elements, but for as good as it looks, it seems worth putting on the Spring Clean-up list. Hope this helps. Ya can't loose by trying. A proper cleaning & prep is the key before applying.

question: Is this product UL rated/tested? My understanding is that if you have a fire without a UL-rated device insurance may not cover damages.
answer: This outlet set, I believe, meets UL standards. More importantly, most local and state building codes forbid non Romex type power lines running behind wallboards , ie through the walls. The Arlington box is one of several devices that meet this standard. I used 14 g Romex to connect the outlets with the external line cord. I could then plug it into a surge suppressor for safety. In addition I added 2.5 Carlon tubing (Smurf Tubing) in order to fascilitate feeding the low voltage cables. This is additional fire safety, but more importantly facilitated threading all the cables through the wall and allows removal and replacement in the future. The boxes are well designed, are rugged and tolerate a lot of pulling and tugging. They are recessed and allow the plugs to recess so the TV will mount close to the wall. The plastic/ rubber dampers also allow easy threading of lines while blocking air leaks. This is very important if your walls have outside exposure as through the attic, etc. The building code might make for a violation when getting inspections for mortgages or when selling the home. True a fire would probably be bad if out of compliance.

question: I can't insert a 3/8 or 1/2' square chisel in the bushing. do I need a diff bushing or diff size chisel?
answer: You need to use Delta mortise/drill sets. Off brands won't fit. I had this for a few years and sold it along with all the chisels because of many problems, chisel size being one. I sold it and went to General International. Much better tool, fewer problems and more features, like a tilting head. Highly recommended by Fine Woodworking magazine. Delta used to be good but then they got bought out. The other problem this creates is that you can no longer find factory service people in the States (at least in the Midwest). I have a Delta planer, joiner, and Unisaw. I like them but can't get service. Even letters to the company president were never answered. Go with General. You will be happier. Capn John

question: How well would it work to paint over black plastic drums? These will be used to plant garden plants in so they will be out in the weather year around.
answer: As Krylon Fusion is advertised as "Bonds to Plastic" and "The no-prep, superbond paint for Plastic", I'd guess that it should work well on 'plastic drums' used for outdoor garden planters. I used Krylon Fusion to paint Trangia (polythene) fuel bottles (originally red) with green Fusion paint, even after online research told me "paint would not stick to polythene." I wanted to visually distinguish 'alcohol fuel bottles' from 'coleman fuel bottles'. Due to the polythene material, I allowed a longer (overnight) drying time, and applied two coats. I've been very pleased and impressed with the results, and the paint seems to be fairly resistant to fuel that spills onto the paint. I don't know your plastic drum composition, but I'd guess Krylon Fusion should work pretty well for your use and outdoor environment.

question: easy for women to install?
answer: The only tool you need in order to install this knob set is a Phillips head screwdriver (probably a #2 size). If you are replacing an existing knob set, then you'll also need tools to remove the old one. I was replacing a 25-year old Kwikset knob set, and all it required was the same screwdriver to remove it. On the other hand, if you are installing this knob set on a new door (that's never had a knob set installed), then you will need a number of other tools (hole saw, chisel, drill, etc.) to do the new installation. I bought three of these to replace three existing knob sets; it took less than two hours to do all three. Two of mine had matching keys; I re-keyed the third one to use their key, so I only have to keep up with one key as my knob lock key. It doesn't require much strength to remove or install these, so any adult should have no problem. If you find that you want to invert the key cylinder position, look on YouTube for a video that shows how to do it.

question: What is the height and width of unit?
answer: Hey Debbie! It is 16 inches in height and 12 inches wide. In addition, I would suggest that you look to install a Honeywell Ultraviolet Light (also available on Amazon.) This light kills bacteria and viruses that pass through air system. This especially important during the summer if you have central air. There is water (sitting in the dark) in the evaporated air conditioning coil area that breeds bacteria and viruses. It is not that expensive and can be installed easily. Once installed the bulb is easy to change when it burns out over time. Unless you are very handy.... I suggest you have a professional heating and air tech install the humidifier and/or the ultraviolet light. One more thing... should you install the humidifier, remember that the filter pad is held in a plastic cage and the replacement pad is separate from the plastic cage. I accidentally threw out the pad with the cage... thinking it was one piece. Unfortunately, that plastic cage is almost as expensive as buying a new unit. I learned the hard way!

question: could anybody tell me exactly what kind of bulb this take. Sometimes I have found that the replacement bulb is almost as much as the whole fixture

These bulbs are readily available at most any store that carries bulbs and cost much less than the fixture.

question: How exactly does this install? I really have no idea how (or where) this installs.

question: Does a whole house humidifier only goes on when air handlers are on and is this enough to put adequate moisture in house? Have 4 zones.
answer: Yes it only goes on with the fan running.... providing you install a "sail" switch in the return duct. The unit I purchased had the sail switch included. It should provide enough moisture for all 4 zones but, look on the specs for the square footage. I believe it should give the square foot capacity. It is important to note that you will need a cold water line connected to the unit and that this unit incorporates a low voltage solenoid valve that requires an 110v ac outlet for the transformer to plug into. This unit works great and it also comes with a humidistat that must be installed in the return duct or in a main room. I also installed a UV light from Honeywell that kills airborne germs and virus. These are available on Amazon and are easily installed. Also one more thing.... do not throw away a used humidifier pad with the cage that holds it. The cage is separate from the pad. I made this mistake and I had to purchase another one.... which was very expensive. One more thing I forgot to mention.... you will need a place to drain the water from the unit as it is working. This could be a floor drain, sump pump, or possibly a sink. Good luck!

question: What is the difference between surface mount and face mount?
answer: I don't know how helpful this will be. I perceive that both "wings" (the parts that are actually screwed into the cabinet and door) of a surface mount hinge are visible when the door is closed. A face mount hinge is screwed into the cabinet frame and the inside of the cabinet door, so that only part of the hinge is visible when the door is closed. I needed this type of hinge because it was the same as the previous hinges and the holes were in the cabinets. Additionally, the thickness of the door must be considered in measuring for either type. This photo of the hinge is one dimensional and does not portray the depth of the hinge, that is, the part that will be flush against the cabinet door edge. Not simple to clearly explain! A picture is worth a thousand words. I suggest Googling both kinds of hinges and/or visiting a hardware store to take a look. Come back here to purchase - better prices! Good luck!

question: Is the piece that the "little white disc" fits available seperatly or do you have to get the whole flush valve assembly?
answer: I ordered each (flush valve and plastic socket wrench adapter) separately from Amazon, but the "little white disc" was out of stock. To my surprise, the disc was included with the flush valve that I purchased, so I cancelled the order for the "little white disc," which supposedly would not arrive for at least a month. It turns out, however, that I was able to use a wide putty knife, which turned out to be precisely the same width as the throat of the flush value, to rotate and remove/replace the flush values, without even using the little white disc. The flush value works perfectly. Took a little time to get the chain set at precisely the right length, but now all works well. Good luck.

question: Can this be installed in an IC can?
answer: Absolutely. I installed mine in IC cans. The "IC" just means "insulation contact", so the can has a heat sensor that trips the power if the can gets too hot - to prevent a fire. Retrofitting the IC can to a halogen bulb or an LED equivalent means there will be less heat generated than the incandescent flood or spot light you are replacing.

question: Can Mighty Putty be used to bond plastic to plastic and plastic to metal? What about fabric and silicone? Thanks.
answer: First, be careful of how old the mighty putty is. It dries with age and mixing becomes difficult and incomplete. Secondly, might putty isn't really a "bonder" per se. If you can wrap it completely around something, then yes, but mainly mighty putty is good for when you are missing a piece or part of something that needs to be repaired in order to mold the shape or form that is missing and needed to be repaired. And it IS very waterproof. I have repaired dishwashers with parts that have held up for years. For fresh mighty putty get water weld at Walmart or Autozone.

question: Can I use Renaissance Micro-Crystalline Wax Polish on antique oak furniture?
answer: Best wax I have ever used and good for many, many things. As a matter of fact, I haven't encountered much that it cannot be used on (except biscuits - wouldn't recommend that!). As David, says it will actually fill the exposed grain in wood (previously finished) with continued applications - I have done that same thing on an oak desk surface... My son said he waxes the windshield on his pickup truck and remarks how it will shed rain water and windshield wipers are much more effective - not greasy like the the other rain 'proofer'. I tried it as a weather proofer on some new leather boots....they remained darker due to the 'wetting' of this wax so as the manufacturer says - try it inconspicuously first. One more bourbon and I'm ready to try it on a biscuit too! "Cracking wax, Gromit!"

question: i dug a well about 12 feet below grade and my water tank is 12 feet above grade will this pump have enough lift to fill my water tank .

It would just be less efficient than a larger pump with higher head rating. It also depends on how often the pump will run. Forcing the pump to push a higher column of water than its rated would probably make it wear out sooner.

question: What are the minimum and maximum AWG wire size this tool will accommodate!
answer: The largest size die size 300 mm2 is equal to 600 MCM. Good tool for price but it doesn't release automatically like higher priced ones when crimped. Stop pumping lever when dies touch, hydraulic ram has enough force to damage dies and tool if over crimped. I made a little conversion chart and laminated to keep with tool for AWG conversion. Mine came with the following dies. 6AWG=16 mm2 4AWG=25 mm2 2AWG=35 mm2 1AWG=50 mm2 1/0=55 mm2 2/0=70 mm2 3/0=95 mm2 4/0=120 mm2 300MCM=150 mm2 350MCM=185 mm2 500MCM=240 mm2 600MCM=300 mm2

question: Is this mask effective against smoke from wildfires (in surrounding cities, not fighting the fire)? How about use while spray painting? Thanks!!
answer: SMOKE: This mask is made to protect you from particulate such as airborne dirt, drywall dust, or smoke or paint particles. It cannot protect you from the poisonous gases contained in smoke, such as odorless carbon monoxide. If you are in a nearby city, as you say, you should be just fine, since the poisonous gasses will be heavily diluted by fresh air and the particulate is filtered out by the mask. Smokejumpers often go in with oxygen tanks strapped on, but forest fire smoke is not nearly as nasty as most paint fumes. PAINT FUMES: I've used these masks for sanding and painting on 3 cars and a rototiller, but remember: these masks cannot protect you from dangerous fumes in a non-ventilated paint shop. They stop solid particles, but not poisonous gasses. Professional paint shops use far more sophisticated equipment, such as air scrubbers and circulation fans, to make the air safe. So, a summary: Wear this mask for the particulate protection, and always keep your face UPWIND of paint fumes. They are great masks, and far better than any cheap mask. These would even be useful if there were a volcanic eruption in the Pacific and all that dust wafted across the US for weeks afterward, which it would. If you wear no mask for drywall sanding, you are BEGGING to get particulate into your lungs where you could wind up in the hospital with bronchitis or worse. Don't ask me how I know that. I won't even buy cheap masks now. /tvg

question: The existing holes on my door are 8-1/2" apart. Will this door handle fit those holes?
answer: Asiago, I'm assuming you mean the holes that the existing handset and deadbolt are mounted in, so the answer would be yes. The handle itself uses one of the holes, usually the lower door hole, for the internal latching mechanism actuated by the thumb. The bottom of the handle is attached and stabilized by a large wood screw. Your deadbolt will generally occupy the other large hole, usually the upper hole. If you use the Camelot digital lock for your deadbolt, vice the handle style shown, it will only require a few inches of clearance between the bottom of the deadbolt digital keypad and the top of the door handle bezel, so it sounds like you should have plenty of clearance. One discovery I made (in going from an older Kwikset lockset to the Schlage) was that I needed to enlarge the holes about another quarter inch to accommodate the larger Schlage handset and deadbolt, but that is no big deal if you have a hole saw. The job is a whole lot easier if you have a locksmith's jig, but easy enough to hand-hold if you have to. Caution - if you hand-hold, be very careful and don't let the saw get away from you when it bites into the wood, as it will "take off," and could really damage the exterior of your door, so go lightly and hold on tightly. Important - I recommend using the fastest drill motor speed and a light touch when sawing, as it tends to be MUCH more difficult if you try to use the variable-speed drill at a lower speed. Good luck!

question: Anyone know how well this works with PVC pipe? I don't think it should be an issue but just thought if anyone had any issues
answer: I've used the Floodstop products for self, family and friends on all types of approved water supply lines including PVC without any issues. Other Floodstop products are used for washing machines (Highly recommended) , ice makers and can be adapted to virtually any device that uses a water supply line, such as a whole house water filtration system. (No, I do not work for Floodstop) On a maintenance note, I recommend a manual check of the valve operation and backup battery voltage at least twice a year. I've had valves fail, particularly on hot water heaters. Could be heat, contamination or some other problem. This usually occurs after many years of use.
